Sec. 3-10. - Prohibited premises by persons under age twenty-one-Posted notice. 
    It shall be unlawful for the holder of a license or permit issued pursuant to the Iowa Alcoholic Beverage Control Act for premises where more than fifty (50) percent of the business conducted is the sale or dispensing of alcoholic beverages and for any person employed with respect to such premises to knowingly permit or fail to take reasonable measures to prevent the entry onto such premises of any and all persons who have not yet attained the age of twenty-one (21), unless said person is accompanied by his or her parent or legal guardian, or unless the premises are covered by a class A liquor control license. It shall be the duty of the licensee and of the person or persons managing such premises to cause to be posted and maintained at all times an easily readable notice in the English language stating that persons less than twenty-one (21) years of age are prohibited from entering the premises. 
(Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-11. - Beer brand signs prohibited. 
    No signs or other matter advertising any brand of beer shall be erected or placed upon the outside of any premises occupied by a licensee or permittee authorized to sell beer at retail. 
(Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Note- Formerly § 3-40. 
Secs. 3-12-3-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES, PERMITS AND CONTROL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference -Parks and recreation; alcoholic beverages, § 15-4. 

Sec. 3-21. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide administration of licenses and permits and for local regulations and procedures for the conduct of the sale and consumption of beer and liquor, for the protection of the safety, morals and general welfare of this community. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-22. - Definitions. 
    Where words and phrases used in this article are defined by state law, such definitions shall apply to their use in this article and are adopted by reference. Those definitions so adopted that need further definition or are reiterated, and other words and phrases used in this article shall have the following meanings: 
(a)  Club: Any nonprofit corporation or association of individuals which is the owner, lessee or occupant of a permanent building or part thereof, membership in which entails the prepayment of regular dues and is not operated for a profit other than such profits as would accrue to the entire membership. 
(b)  Commercial establishment: A place of business which is at all times equipped with sufficient tables and seats to accommodate twenty-five (25) persons at one (1) time, and the licensed premises of which conform to the ordinances of this city. 
(c)  Grocery store: Any retail establishment, the business of which consists of the sale of food, food products or beverages for consumption off the premises. 
(d)  Hotel or motel: A premises licensed by the Iowa Department of Inspections and Appeals, and regularly or seasonally kept open in a bona fide manner for the lodging of transient guests, and with twenty (20) or more sleeping rooms. 
(e)  Legal age: Twenty-one (21) years of age or older. 
(f)  Person of good moral character: Any person who meets all of the following requirements: 
(1)  The person has such financial standing and good reputation as will satisfy the state administrator that the person will comply with the Iowa Alcoholic Beverage Control Act and all other laws, ordinances and regulations applicable to the person's operations under law. 
(2)  The person is not prohibited by the provision of section 3-42 from obtaining a liquor license, wine or beer permit. 
(3)  Is a citizen of the United States and a resident of Iowa, or licensed to do business in Iowa in the case of a corporation. In the case of a partnership, only one (1) partner need be a resident of Iowa. 
(4)  The person has not been convicted of a felony. However, if the conviction of a felony occurred more than five (5) years before the application for a license or permit, and if the rights of citizenship have been restored by the governor, the state administrator may determine that the person is one of good moral character notwithstanding such conviction. 
(5)  If such person is a corporation, partnership, association, club or hotel or motel, the requirements of this definition shall apply to each of the officers, directors and partners of such person, and to any person who directly or indirectly owns or controls ten (10) percent or more of any class of stock of such person or has an interest of ten (10) percent or more in the ownership or profits of such person. For the purpose of this provision, an individual and his spouse shall be regarded as one (1) person. 
(g)  Pharmacy: A drugstore in which drugs and medicines are exposed for sale and sold at retail or in which prescriptions of licensed physicians and surgeons, dentists or veterinarians are compounded and sold by a registered pharmacist. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-23. - Eligibility for liquor control license or beer permit. 
    Upon meeting the requirements imposed by state law and the ordinances of this city, a person who is of good moral character as defined by state law and this article may apply for a liquor control license or a beer permit. In the case of a club, corporation or partnership, the officers of the club or corporation and the partners or a partnership shall be persons of good moral character as defined by state law and this article. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-24. - Conditions for approval of license or permit. 
    An applicant for a liquor control license or wine or beer permit, as a further condition for approval by the city council, must give consent in writing on the application, that members of the fire, police and health departments and the building inspector may enter upon the premises during business hours without warrant to inspect for violations of the provisions of state law and of this article. However, a warrant is required for inspection of private records, a private business office or attached living quarters. 
(a)  No liquor control license or beer permit shall be approved for premises which do not conform to all applicable laws, ordinances, resolutions and health and fire regulations. 
(b)  No licensee shall have or maintain any interior access to residential or sleeping quarters unless permission is granted by the state administrator in the form of a living quarters permit. 
(c)  The premises for which a Class B beer permit or Class C liquor control license is sought must be located within a district now or hereafter zoned for business purposes and conform to the zoning requirements of this city. 
(d)  The premises of a Class B beer permit holder or a Class C liquor control license holder shall, at the time of the application, be equipped and thereafter continue to be equipped with sufficient tables and seats to accommodate twenty-five (25) persons at one (1) time. 
(e)  All permits and licenses provided for in this article shall be displayed in a conspicuous place on the premises of the holder of the permit or license and shall at all times be subject to inspection. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-25. - Beer permits-Classes. 
    Beer permits shall be classed as follows: 
(1)  Class B permit. A class B beer permit shall allow the holder to sell beer at retail for consumption on or off the premises. 
(2)  Class C permit. A class C beer permit shall allow the holder to sell beer at retail for consumption off the premises only. Such sales shall be in original containers only. No Class C permit shall be issued to any person except the owner or proprietor of a grocery store or pharmacy. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-25.1. - Wine permits-Classes. 
    Wine permits shall be classified as follows: 
(1)  Class B permit. A Class B wine permit shall allow the holder to sell wine at retail for consumption off the premises only. Such sales shall be in original containers only. 
(Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-26. - Liquor licenses-Classes. 
    Liquor control licenses shall be classed as follows: 
(1)  Class A license. A class A liquor control license issued to a club shall authorize the holder to purchase alcoholic liquors from those licensees, permittees or manufacturers described in Iowa Code 123.30(3)(a), and to sell such liquors and beer to bona fide members and their guests by the individual drink for consumption on the premises only. 
(2)  Class B license. A class B liquor control license issued to a hotel or motel shall authorize the holder to purchase alcoholic liquors from those licensees, permittees or manufacturers described in Iowa Code 123.30(3)(b), and to sell such liquor, wine and beer to patrons by the individual drink for consumption on the premises only, however, beer may also be sold for consumption off the premises. Each such license shall be effective throughout the premises described in the application. 
(3)  Class C license. A class C liquor control license issued to a commercial establishment must be issued in the name of the individual or individuals who actually own their business and shall authorize the holder or holders to purchase alcoholic liquors from those licensees, permittees or manufacturers described in Iowa Code 123.30(3)(c), and to sell such liquors, wine and beer to patrons by the individual drink for consumption on the premises only, however, beer may also be sold for consumption off the premises. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-27. - Reserved. 
Sec. 3-28. - Separate locations-Class B or C beer permits. 
    Every person holding a class B or class C permit having more than one (1) place of business where such beer is sold shall be required to have separate license for each separate place of business, except as otherwise prohibited by state law. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-29. - Application contents-Bond. 
    A verified application for the original issuance or the renewal of a liquor control license, a wine permit or a beer permit shall be filed at such time, in such number of copies, and in such form as the state administrator of alcoholic beverage control shall prescribe, on forms prescribed by him. The application shall be accompanied by the required fee and bond and be filed with the city council for approval or disapproval. The bond to be submitted shall be in a form prescribed by the state administrator and in the following amounts: 
(1)  Five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) with any liquor control license and conditioned upon the payment of all taxes payable to the state under the provisions of the Iowa Alcoholic Beverage Control Act and compliance with all provisions of the act. 
(2)  Five hundred dollars ($500.00) with any beer or wine permit and conditioned upon the faithful observance of the Iowa Alcoholic Beverage Control Act. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-30. - Investigation of applicant. 
    Upon receipt of an original application for a liquor license or beer permit by the city clerk, it shall be forwarded to the chief of police, who shall conduct an investigation and shall submit a written report on the applicant as to the truth of the facts averred in the application and a recommendation to the city council as to the approval of the license or permit. It shall be the duty of the building administrator, chief of police and director of public works to inspect the premises to determine if they conform to the requirements of the city, and no license or permit shall be approved until or unless an approving report has been filed with the city council by such officers. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-31. - Simplified application for renewal. 
    Upon timely receipt of an application for the renewal of a liquor license or beer permit, it shall be forwarded to the chief of police only, who shall conduct an investigation and shall submit a written report on the applicants to the truth of the facts answered in the application and a recommendation to the city council as to the approval of the license or permit. In the event that the chief of police recommends denial of the renewal, a hearing as provided in section 3-46 may be conducted before the city council. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-32. - Proof of financial responsibility. 
    Every liquor control licensee and class B beer permittee shall furnish proof of financial responsibility either by the existence of a liability insurance policy or by posting bond in such amount as determined by the Iowa Beer and Liquor Control Department. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-33. - License and permit fees. 
    The fees to be submitted with the respective applications, as described in this chapter, shall be in the amounts established in section 25-15 (1) through (6). 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 837, § 1, 11-11-92; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-34. - Nature of license or permit. 
    A liquor control license or beer permit shall be a purely personal privilege and be revocable for cause. It shall not constitute property nor be subject to attachment and execution nor be alienable nor assignable, and in any case it shall cease upon the death of the permittee or licensee. However, the state administrator may, in his discretion, allow the executor or administrator or a permittee or licensee to operate the business of the decedent for a reasonable time not to exceed the expiration date of the permit or license. Every permit or license shall be issued in the name of the applicant and no person holding a permit or license shall allow any other person to use same. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-35. - Action by council. 
    The city council may conduct a hearing pursuant to section 3-46 in the event there are any objections to renewal of a liquor license or a beer permit and may act on new applications or renewals for such licenses and permits by motion or resolution. Action taken by the city council shall be so endorsed on the application and thereafter the application, fee and bond shall be forwarded to the Iowa Alcoholic Beverage Control Commission for such further action as is provided by law. 
Sec. 3-36. - Expiration of license or permit. 
(a)  All liquor control licenses and beer permits, unless sooner suspended or revoked, shall expire one (1) year from date of issuance. 
(b)  Six-month or eight-month seasonal licenses or beer permits may be issued for a proportionate part of the license or permit fee. No seasonal license or permit shall be renewed except after a period of two (2) months. Seasonal licensing shall be only as permitted by state regulation. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-37. - Refunds. 
    Any such licensee or permittee, or his executor, administrator or any person duly appointed by the court to take charge of and administer the property or assets of the licensee or permittee for the benefit of his creditors, may voluntarily surrender such license or permit to the Iowa Beer and Liquor Control Department and, when so surrendered, the department shall notify the city, and the department and the city, or the city by itself in the case of a retail beer permit, shall refund to the person so surrendering the license or permit a proportionate amount of the fee paid for such license or permit as follows: If surrendered during the first three (3) months of the period for which said license or permit was issued, the refund shall be three-fourths (3/4) of the amount of the fee; if surrendered more than three (3) months but not more than six (6) months after issuance, the refund shall be one-half (1/2) of the amount of the fee; if surrendered more than six (6) months but not more than nine (9) months after issuance, the refund shall be one-fourth (1/4) of the amount of the fee. No refund shall be made, however, for a liquor control license or beer permit surrendered more than nine (9) months after issuance. No refund shall be made to any licensee or permittee upon the surrender of his license or permit if there is at the time of said surrender a complaint filed with the department or the city, charging him with a violation of this chapter or provisions of the Iowa Beer and Liquor Control Act. If, upon hearing on any such complaint, the license or permit is not revoked or suspended, then the licensee or permittee shall be eligible, upon surrender of his license or permit, to receive a refund as provided in this chapter. But if his license or permit is revoked or suspended upon such hearing, he shall not be eligible for the refund of any portion of his license or permit fee. No refund shall be made for seasonal licenses or permits. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-38. - Transfer of license or permit. 
    The council will, in its discretion, authorize a licensee or permittee to transfer the license or permit from one location to another within the city, provided that the premises to which the transfer is to be made would have been eligible for a license or permit in the first instance and such transfer will not result in the violation of any law or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-39. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 908, adopted August 10, 1994, moved former § 3-39, "Prohibited sales and acts," to § 3-4. 
Sec. 3-40. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 908, adopted Aug. 10, 1994, moved former § 3-40, "Beer brand signs prohibited" to § 3-11. 
Sec. 3-41. - Suspension and revocation. 
    A liquor license or beer permit may be suspended for a period up to one (1) year, or revoked, for violations of law including city ordinances, following notice and hearing, and shall be revoked in accordance with the provisions of state law for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Misrepresentation of any material fact in the application for such license or permit; 
(2)  Violation of any of the provisions of the Iowa Alcoholic Beverage Control Act; 
(3)  Any change in the ownership or interest in the business operated under a class A, class B or class C liquor control license, or any wine or beer permit which change was not previously reported to and approved by the city and the Iowa Alcoholic Beverage Control Commission; 
(4)  An event which would have resulted in disqualification from receiving such license or permit when originally issued; 
(5)  Any sale, hypothecation or transfer of such license or permit; 
(6)  The failure or refusal on the part of any licensee or permittee to render any report or remit any taxes to the Iowa Alcoholic Beverage Control Commission under the state act. 
(7)  Operation of the establishment in such manner as to create a nuisance. Nuisance includes but is not limited to the following: 
a.  Loud music and other noise emanating from the premises in question that can be heard inside other buildings whose doors and windows are closed. 
b.  The gathering of loud or unruly groups in any area outside the premises under the control of such permittee when such gathering blocks or hinders access to one's automobile or otherwise interferes with the reasonable use of sidewalks, streets, and adjacent property. 
c.  Accumulations of litter and vegetation upon the premises of such licensee or upon sidewalks, streets and adjacent property when such litter can reasonably be deemed to be from the establishment of the permit holder. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-42. - Effect of revocation. 
    Any liquor control licensee, wine permittee, or beer permittee whose license or permit is revoked under the Iowa Alcoholic Beverage Control Act shall not thereafter be permitted to hold a liquor control license or beer permit in the state of Iowa for a period of two (2) years from the date of such revocation. The spouse and business associates holding ten (10) percent or more of the capital stock or ownership interest in the business of a person whose license or permit has been revoked shall not be issued a liquor control license, wine permit or beer permit, and no liquor control license or wine permit or beer permit shall be issued which covers any business in which such person has a financial interest for a period of two (2) years from the date of such revocation. In the event a license or permit is revoked, the premises which had been covered by such license or permit shall not be relicensed for one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-43. - Appeal and hearing. 
    The right of appeal to a hearing board shall be afforded a liquor control licensee, wine permittee or beer permittee whose license or permit has been suspended or revoked. Any applicant who feels aggrieved by a decision of the state administrator or city disapproving, suspending or revoking issuance of a liquor control license or beer permit may, provided he has exercised his right of appeal to a hearing board as provided by state law, appeal from said decision within ten (10) days to the district court of Henry County, Iowa. The city may appeal a decision of a hearing board in accordance with the terms of the Iowa administrative procedure Act within thirty (30) days to the district court of Henry County. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Sec. 3-44. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 908, adopted Aug. 10, 1994, moved former § 3-44, "Consumption in public places" to § 3-2. 
Sec. 3-45. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 908, adopted Aug. 10, 1994, moved former section 3-45, "Persons under legal age" to §§ 3-8, 3-9 and 3-10. 
Sec. 3-46. - Hearing procedure. 
    The following procedure shall be followed for holding a hearing in the event one is held in connection with a renewal application under sections 3-31 and 3-35, or for a suspension or revocation of a license or permit under section 3-41: 
(1)  Notice shall be sent to the licensee or beer permittee of the time and place of the hearing by certified mail at least ten (10) days before the date of the hearing. The notice shall include the purpose of the hearing and a short summary of the grounds upon which a suspension, revocation, or denial of the renewal of the license or permit has been recommended. 
(2)  The hearing shall be held before the city council, and the mayor shall be the presiding officer of the hearing and make all procedural rulings in connection with the hearing. The hearing shall be open to the public; however, no member of the public may give evidence except under oath. 
(3)  The city clerk shall subpoena persons to appear at the hearing upon the request of the parties or the city council and shall further require such persons to produce such books, records, papers, documents, or other materials which shall be relevant to the council's determination or likely to lead to the discovery of relevant information. Upon failure of any person to respond to such subpoena, the mayor may direct the city attorney to bring action in district court to enforce such subpoena. 
(4)  The city attorney's office or agency representative shall present the case on behalf of the police department or other city or county agency which has recommended suspension, revocation, or denial of the renewal of the license or permit. Such agency shall have the burden of proof in substantiating the grounds therefor by circumstantial and/or direct evidence and shall, after opening statements by the parties, present its evidence first. 
(5)  The renewal applicant or licensee or permittee shall then present its evidence, and rebuttal evidence may be submitted by the opposing parties at the discretion of the council. 
(6)  All witnesses before the council shall testify under oath, which shall be administered by the city clerk, and all witnesses shall be subject to cross-examination by the parties and members of the council. 
(7)  Irrelevant, immaterial, or unduly repetitious evidence shall be excluded. A finding shall be based upon the kind of evidence upon which reasonable, prudent persons are accustomed to rely for the conduct of their serious affairs, any may be based upon such evidence, including hearsay evidence, even if it would be inadmissible in any jury trial. However, the rules of privilege recognized by law shall be given effect. 
(8)  After submission of the evidence, the parties may make closing statements and the city council shall then, by majority vote, determine whether a suspension, revocation, or denial or the renewal of a license is warranted. Such determination shall be based solely on the evidence adduced at the hearing and the council, at its discretion, may direct the city attorney to draw up certain findings of fact and conclusions of law for incorporation into the decision for adoption. The determination shall be based on proof by a preponderance of the evidence. 
(9)  The renewal applicant or licensee or permittee, at his or her own expense, may make arrangements with the city clerk to have a verbatim transcript made of the hearing upon written notice to the city clerk five (5) days before the date of the hearing. 
(10)  The renewal applicant or licensee or permittee shall have the right to appeal to the Iowa Beer and Liquor Control Department Hearing Board as provided by state law in the event of an adverse decision. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Note- Formerly § 3-47. 
Sec. 3-47. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(b)  The conviction of any liquor control licensee, wine permittee or beer permittee for a violation of any of the provisions of subsection 3-41(1)-(7) shall, subject to subsection (b) of this section, be grounds for the suspension or revocation of the license or permit by the state commission or the city. However, if any liquor control licensee is convicted of any violation of section 123.49(2) paragraphs (a), (d), or (e) of the Code of Iowa, or any beer permittee is convicted of a violation of section 123.49(2), paragraph (a) of the Code of Iowa, the liquor control license or beer permit shall be revoked and shall immediately be surrendered by the holder, and the bond of the license or permit holder shall be forfeited to the state commission of alcoholic beverage control. 
(c)  If any licensee, beer permittee or employee of such licensee or permittee shall be convicted of a violation of section 3-4(5) or a retail beer permittee shall be convicted of a violation of subsection 3-4(6), the city shall, in addition to the other penalties fixed for such violations by this section, assess a penalty as follows: 
(1)  Upon a first conviction the violator's liquor control license or beer permit shall be suspended for a period of fourteen (14) days. 
(2)  Upon a second conviction within a period of two (2) years the violator's liquor control license or beer permit shall be suspended for a period of thirty (30) days. 
(3)  Upon a third conviction within a period of five (5) years the violator's liquor control license or beer permit shall be suspended for a period of sixty (60) days. 
(4)  Upon a fourth conviction within a period of five (5) years, the violator's liquor license or beer permit shall be revoked. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 1, 12-5-84; Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-10-94) 
Secs. 3-48, 3-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SOCIAL HOST 

Sec. 3-50. - Purpose; findings. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to protect the public interest, welfare, health, and safety within the City of Mount Pleasant by prohibiting the services to and consumption of alcoholic beverages by persons under the age of twenty-one (21) at premises located in the city. The city council finds that the occurrence of social gatherings at premises where alcoholic beverages are served to or consumed by persons under the age of twenty-one (21) is harmful to such persons themselves and a threat to public welfare, health, and safety. The city council further finds that persons under the age of twenty-one (21) often obtain alcoholic beverages at such gatherings and that persons who are in control of such premises know or have reason to know of such service and/or consumption and will be more likely to ensure that alcoholic beverages are neither served or consumed by persons under the age of twenty-one (21) at these gatherings. Based on these findings, the city council has deemed it necessary to enact the following regulations in the City of Mount Pleasant. 
(Ord. No. 1198, § 1, 12-29-2008) 
Sec. 3-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alcoholic beverage: Any beverage containing more than one-half (1/2) of one (1) percent of alcohol by volume including alcoholic liquor, wine, and beer. 
    Emergency responders: Firefighters, law enforcement officers, emergency medical service personnel, and other personnel having emergency response duties. 
    Enforcement services: The salaries and benefits of emergency responders for the amount of time actually spent responding to or remaining at an event, gathering, or party and administrative costs attributable to the incident; the actual costs for medical treatment for any injured emergency responder, and the costs of repairing any damage to equipment or vehicles. 
    Event, gathering, or party: Any group of three (3) or more persons who have assembled or gathered together for a social occasion or other activity where an underage person has consumed or possessed an alcoholic beverage. 
    Parent: Any person having legal custody of a juvenile: a) as natural parent, adoptive parent, or stepparent; b) as a legal guardian; or c) as a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of the court. 
    Person: Any individual, partnership, corporation, or any association of one (1)) or more individuals. 
    Premises: Any home, yard, farm, field, land, apartment, condominium, hotel or motel room, or other dwelling unit, or a hall or meeting room, park, or any other place of assembly, public or private, whether occupied on a temporary or permanent basis, whether occupied as a dwelling or specifically for a party or other social function, and whether owned, leased, rented, or used with or without permission or compensation. 
    Social host: Any person who aids, conducts, allows, entertains, organizes, supervises, controls, or permits an event, gathering, or party. This includes, but is not limited to: a) The person(s) who owns, rents, leases, or otherwise has control of the premises where the event, gathering, or party takes place; b) the person(s) in charge of the premises; or c) the person(s) who organized the event. If the social host is a juvenile, then the parent(s) of that juvenile will be jointly and severally liable for any violation of this chapter. 
    Underage person: Any individual under the age of twenty-one (21). 
(Ord. No. 1198, § 1, 12-29-2008) 
Sec. 3-52. - Prohibited acts. 
    It is unlawful for any social host to host an event, gathering, or party on premises when the person knows or reasonably should know that an underage person has consumed an alcoholic beverage, or possessed an alcoholic beverage with the intent to consume it, and the person fails to take reasonable steps to prevent the possession or consumption by the underage person. A social host who hosts such an event, gathering, or party does not have to be present at the time the prohibited act occurs. 
(Ord. No. 1198, § 1, 12-29-2008) 
Sec. 3-53. - Exceptions. 
    This chapter does not apply to conduct solely between an underage person and his or her parents while present in the parents' household, to legally protected religious observances, and to situations where underage persons are lawfully in possession of alcoholic beverages during the course and scope of employment. 
(Ord. No. 1198, § 1, 12-29-2008) 
Sec. 3-54. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by officers of the police department. The police department shall have primary but not exclusive enforcement responsibility for this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1198, § 1, 12-29-2008) 
Sec. 3-55. - Violations. 
    Violations of this chapter are declared to be municipal infractions. A two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) civil penalty shall be imposed for a social host's first offense. A five hundred dollar ($500.00) civil penalty shall be imposed for a social host's second offense or subsequent offense. In addition, the city may seek reimbursement for enforcement services provided by emergency responders related to the event, gathering, or party. Multiple violations of this chapter may be considered by the city for purposes of approving licenses applied for by the social host, or for any other requirements that are subject to approval by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1198, § 1, 12-29-2008) 
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 707, adopted Mar. 23, 1988, amended Ch. 4, Animals and Fowl, in its entirety and added new provisions, with similar matter, as herein set out in §§ 4-1-4-29. Former Ch. 4, containing §§ 4-1-4-9, 4-21, 4-22, 4-34-4-41 and 4-69-4-82, originated from the 1969 Code, §§ 7.48.010-7.48.050, 7.48.070 and 7.48.080. 
Cross reference- Animal noises declared a nuisance, § 13-2(e); unlawful to ride a horse on pedestrian walkways, grass lawns or cultivated areas in city parks, § 15-3(a); unlawful to hunt or trap animals in city parks, § 15-9; unlawful for privately owned animals to run at large in city parks, § 15-11; schedule of fines for municipal infractions, § 25-24. 
State Law reference- Dog licensing and regulation, I.C.A. § 351.1 et seq.; municipal home rule powers, I.C.A. § 364.1; provisions relating to injuries to animals, cruelty to animals and animal exhibitions and fighting, Iowa Criminal Code, Ch. 1, §§ 1701-1703. 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms are defined as follows: 
    Animal means any live vertebrate creature, domestic or wild, including any dog, both male and female, and any cat, both male and female. 
    Animal control center means any facility designated by the city council to impound animals. 
    Bite means any puncture, laceration, abrasion, scratch or any other break in the skin of a human caused by an animal. 
    Board of health means the Henry County Board of Health, or its representatives. 
    Cat means any male or female animal of the family Felis catus, whether neutered or not. 
    Dog means any male or female animal of the family Canis familiaris, whether neutered or not. 
    Hearing ear dog means any dog which is owned by a deaf or partially deaf person and which has been properly trained to aid its owner. 
    Humane officer means any person designated by the State of Iowa or its governmental subdivisions and agencies, including, but not limited to, the board of health, or any peace officer, or such person approved by the city council upon the recommendation of the chief of police, to supervise or enforce any laws or regulations governing the control, care or conservation of animals. 
    Identification tag means a rabies vaccination tag for cats and dogs. 
    Kennel means any premises wherein any person engages in the business of boarding, breeding, buying, selling, letting for hire, or the training of dogs or cats, and is licensed by the State of Iowa for such purpose. 
    Kennel dog means dogs which are kept or raised solely for the purpose of breeding or sale and which are kept in constant confinement in a kennel. 
    Neutered means any animal which, through a surgical procedure, has been rendered incapable of siring or bearing offspring. 
    Owner means any person, partnership or corporation owning, keeping or harboring one (1) or more animals. An animal shall be deemed to be harbored if it is fed or sheltered for three (3) consecutive days or more. 
    Potentially vicious dog is a dog that: 
(1)  When unprovoked, on two (2) separate occasions, has engaged in any behavior that has required a defensive action by any person to prevent bodily injury when the person and dog were off the property of the owner or keeper of the dog; 
(2)  When unprovoked, has attacked or bitten a person; 
(3)  When unprovoked, has inflicted a serious injury or caused the death of a domestic animal, either on public or private property other than the property of the owner or keeper; or 
(4)  When unprovoked, chases or approaches a person or domestic animal upon the streets, sidewalks, or any public or private property other than the property of the owner or keeper, in a menacing fashion or apparent attitude of attack. 
    Seeing eye dog means any dog which is owned by a legally declared blind or partially sighted person and which has been properly trained at a special school to guide its owner in going from place to place. 
    Service animal means guide dogs, signal dog, or other animal individually trained to provide assistance to an individual with a disability. Animals are considered service animals regardless of whether they have been licensed or certified by a state or local government. A service animal is not a pet. 
    Stray means any dog, cat or other animal running at large with no indication of ownership. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88; Ord. No. 859, § 1, 1-13-93; Ord. No. 860, § 1, 1-13-93; Ord. No. 885, § 1, 11-10-93; Ord. No. 1216, § 2, 1-27-2010; Ord. No. 1256, § 1(2), 11-14-2012; Ord. No. 1291, § 1(4), 2-25-2015) 
Sec. 4-2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1(1) of Ord. No. 1256, adopted Nov. 14, 2012, repealed § 4-2, which pertained to license tag, and derived from Ord. No. 707, § 1, adopted March 23, 1988; Ord. No. 859, § 2, adopted Jan. 13, 1993; and Ord. No. 885, § 2, adopted Nov. 10, 1993. 
Sec. 4-3. - Rabies vaccination tag. 
    The owner of all dogs and cats six (6) months old or older shall obtain a current rabies vaccination for such animals from a licensed veterinarian and obtain a tag evidencing the same. The vaccination tag shall be attached to a substantial collar or harness on the animal by the owner and shall at all times be kept on the animal for which the vaccination was given. The owner of a dog or cat may, at his or her option, have the thigh or ear tattooed to evidence such vaccination in lieu of attaching a tag thereto. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88) 
Sec. 4-4. - Dogs and cats at large. 
(a)  Dogs which are properly identified, as required by law, shall be deemed under restraint if: 
(1)  The dog is on the premises of the owner, or a person given charge of the dog by the owner, and is either: 
a.  Accompanied by and obedient to the commands of the owner or the person given such charge; or 
b.  Confined on those premises by an adequate protective fence or by a leash, cord or chain that does not allow the dog to go beyond the owner's real property line. 
(2)  The dog is off the premises of the owner, and it is: 
a.  Accompanied by and obedient to the commands of the owner or a competent, responsible person; or 
b.  On a leash, cord or chain, not more than six (6) feet in length, and under the control of a person competent to restrain and control the dog; or 
c.  Confined within a motor vehicle. 
(3)  It is properly housed in a veterinary hospital or kennel. 
(b)  Dogs shall be deemed to be at large if they do not have the necessary identification tags, or if they are not under restraint by one (1) of the methods set forth in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Cats shall be deemed at large if they do not have the necessary identification tags, or if they are on private property not owned by the owner of the animal without permission of the person owning such property or the person in charge thereof. 
(d)  Cats shall not be deemed at large when on public property if: 
(1)  Accompanied by and obedient to the commands of the owner or a competent responsible person; or 
(2)  On a leash, cord or chain, not more than six (6) feet in length, and under the control of a person competent to restrain and control the cat. 
(e)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, any animal shall be deemed at large at any time when attacking persons, attacking domestic animals or destroying property. Furthermore, any female dog or cat in heat shall be deemed at large at any time, except: 
(1)  When housed in a building which is completely enclosed; or 
(2)  When housed in a veterinary hospital or kennel; or 
(3)  When on the premises of the owner; provided the area on which such animal is located is completely enclosed by a fence or other structure having a height of at least forty-two (42) inches; 
(4)  Nothing in these provisions, however, shall be construed as prohibiting any owner of a female dog or cat in heat from walking such animal with a leash, cord or chain, not more than six (6) feet in length, or from transporting such animal within a motor vehicle. 
(f)  Any owner of any dog or cat, which is found to be at large, shall have committed a simple misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88; Ord. No. 859, § 3, 1-13-93; Ord. No. 1257, § 1, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 4-5. - Liability for damages. 
    The owner of an animal found to be at large pursuant to section 4-4(e) shall be responsible for all damages to the injured party. A failure to pay damages shall constitute a simple misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 928, § 1, 4-12-95) 
Sec. 4-6. - Enabling animals to leave premises of owner. 
    It is unlawful for any person, except the owner or his or her agent, to open any gate or door on any premises or otherwise to entice or enable any animal to leave said premises. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88) 
Sec. 4-7. - Animals on private property. 
    No owner shall permit or allow his or her animal to be on private property not owned by the owner of the animal without the permission of the person owning such property or the person in charge thereof. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88) 
Sec. 4-8. - Animals in business zone. 
    No owner shall permit or allow his or her animal to be in the B-2 Central Business District Commercial District without being on a leash, enclosed in a carrier or confined in a vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88; Ord. No. 1291, § 1(2), 2-25-2015) 
Sec. 4-9. - Animals in food establishments. 
    No owner shall permit or allow his or her animal to be on or in any building, store, restaurant or tavern where food or food products are sold, prepared or dispensed to people other than the owner thereof. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88) 
Sec. 4-10. - Tying animals. 
    No owner shall permit or allow his or her animal to be tied by any person to a utility pole, parking meter, building, structure, fence, sign, tree, shrub, bush or other object on public property, or tied on private property without the consent of the owner or person in charge thereof. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88) 
Sec. 4-11. - Exceptions to sections 4-7 through 4-10. 
    Sections 4-7 through 4-10 shall not apply to service animals while such dogs are acting in such capacity. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88; Ord. No. 1291, § 1(3), 2-25-2015) 
Sec. 4-12. - Solid waste removal. 
    Any person who shall walk or ride an animal on public or private property shall provide for the disposal of the solid waste material by immediate removal of the waste. A violation of this section shall be a municipal infraction. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88; Ord. No. 859, § 5, 1-13-93; Ord. No. 885, § 5, 11-10-93) 
Sec. 4-13. - Chasing people or vehicles. 
    No owner shall permit or allow his or her animal to run after or chase persons, bicycles, autos or other vehicles. A violation of this section shall be a municipal infraction, unless such dog or cat has caused injury or damage to person or property, wherein the same shall be a simple misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88; Ord. No. 859, § 6, 1-13-93; Ord. No. 885, § 3, 11-10-93; Ord. No. 885, § 5, 11-10-93; Ord. No. 885, § 6, 11-10-93) 
Sec. 4-14. - Number of animals permitted. 
    No person shall keep dogs, cats or other animals in such numbers or in such manner that their presence shall disturb the peace and comfort of any neighborhood, or cause a menace or detriment to public health. A violation of this section shall be a municipal infraction. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88; Ord. No. 859, § 7, 1-13-93; Ord. No. 885, § 7, 11-10-93) 
Sec. 4-15. - Noisy animals. 
    No owner or person in control of any animal(s) shall permit his or her animal to annoy or disturb other persons in the area, without justification, by excessive or continuous barking, howling or emitting other loud noises. 
    It shall be a municipal infraction to have the above occurred based upon any of the following: 
(1)  Complaints of two (2) or more persons of different households. 
(2)  Complaint of one (1) person which is verified by a responding police officer or other city employee. 
    The first verified violation shall cause a warning to be issued to the violating party. A second verified violation shall result in the filing of a municipal infraction, the fine for the same being described in section 25-24 of Chapter 25 entitled "Schedule of fines for municipal infractions." 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88; Ord. No. 906, § 1, 7-13-94) 
Sec. 4-16. - Impoundment. 
(a)  Any dog or cat or other animal at large in the city shall be taken by a humane officer and impounded at an animal control center, and be confined there in a humane manner. 
(b)  If, by an identifying tag, the owner of such dog, cat or other animal can be determined, the humane officer shall give written notice of the impoundment to such owner. If the animal does not have a rabies vaccination tag, then such written notice shall be given in not less than two (2) days to the owner. 
(c)  All dogs found without identification shall be kept for not less than five (5) days unless sooner redeemed by the owner. Dogs with identification shall be kept not less than seven (7) days from the date of the written notice to the owner unless sooner redeemed by the owner. At the expiration of the required holding period, any animal not claimed or reclaimed shall become the property of the city and shall be humanely disposed of, or given to an appropriate person or party for adoption. 
(d)  All cats and other animals found without identification shall be kept for not less than two (2) days unless sooner redeemed by the owner. Cats and other animals found with identification shall be kept not less than seven (7) days from the date of the written notice to the owner unless sooner redeemed by the owner. At the expiration of the required holding period, any animal not claimed or reclaimed shall become the property of the city and shall be humanely disposed of or given to an appropriate person or party for adoption. 
(e)  It shall be lawful for any person who finds an animal at large on public or private property to seize and hold the animal. Any person so seizing and holding an animal may restrain the animal on their premises by an adequate protective fence or by a leash, cord or chain that does not allow the animal to go beyond their real property line. The person seizing and holding the animal shall immediately notify the humane officer and shall be responsible for the humane treatment of the animal while it is under that person's custody. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88; Ord. No. 885, § 8, 11-10-93; Ord. No. 1256, § 1(3), 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 4-17. - Reclaiming impounded animals. 
(a)  With proper identification, the owner of an impounded animal shall be entitled to resume possession of such animal, before the disposal of such animal by the city on the following conditions: 
(1)  He or she shall present proof of current identification tag(s), or he or she must obtain such identification tags for such animal; and 
(2)  He or she must pay all penalties, fines and all costs and charges incurred by the city for the impoundment and care of his or her animal. 
(b)  Fees for the care of impounded animals shall be set by the city council and may be revised as necessary. 
(c)  The owner of any impounded animal, which has not been vaccinated, upon satisfactory proof of ownership may redeem his or her animal by making a deposit of ten dollars ($10.00) with the animal control center and be allowed twenty-four (24) hours to get such animal vaccinated against rabies and distemper. If the owner fails to procure a vaccination certification within twenty-four (24) hours, the deposit shall be forfeited; and the animal shall be impounded again. Upon presentation within the twenty-four-hour time period of a certificate of vaccination issued under this chapter, the deposit shall be refunded. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88) 
Sec. 4-18. - Animal bites. 
(a)  The owner of any dog or cat or other animal which has bitten or attacked any person, or any person having knowledge of such bite or attack, shall immediately report such fact to the humane officer. The report shall include the name and address of the person bitten or attacked and, if known, the time and location of the bite or attack, the description of the animal and the name and address of the owner of such animal. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of every physician or nurse to immediately inform the humane officer, followed, within twenty-four (24) hours, with a written report of the name and address of any person treated by him or her for bites inflicted by an animal, together with such other information as will assist in the prevention of rabies or other disease, and the identification and apprehension of the biting animal. 
(c)  Upon demand by the humane officer, the owner shall forthwith surrender any animal, which has bitten or attacked any person, for supervised quarantine at an animal control center at the expense of the owner. The animal shall remain confined for a minimum period of fourteen (14) days under the observation of a licensed veterinarian. 
(d)  When evidence is presented that such animal is currently inoculated against rabies, the humane officer, at his discretion, may give a written order to confine the animal in the home of its owner, or in such a manner so as to prohibit the animal from coming into contact with or biting any other person or animal, for a minimum of fourteen (14) days; provided, however, that the owner is willing to comply with the terms of the order, and the owner has the means to adequately confine the animal. It shall be unlawful for any owner to fail to comply with such an order. 
(e)  Any animal which has bitten or attacked any person shall be examined by a licensed veterinarian, and a written report of the animal's clinical condition shall be forwarded to the humane officer within twenty-four (24) hours. 
(f)  At the end of the confinement period, the veterinarian shall reexamine the animal and submit to the humane officer a written report of the animal's final clinical condition, recommending whether or not the quarantine should be terminated. 
(g)  No owner of any animal known to have bitten any person shall euthanize, sell, give away or transport from this city, or otherwise dispose of such animal, until a written release from the required quarantine for such animal is obtained from the humane officer. 
(h)  All expenses incurred in the confinement and examination of any animal, pursuant to the provisions of this section, shall be borne by the owner of such animal. 
(i)  When rabies has been diagnosed in an animal under quarantine, or rabies is suspected by a licensed veterinarian, and the animal dies while under such observation, the health officer shall immediately take the head of such animal to the state health department for pathological examination and shall notify the proper public health authorities of reports of human contacts and the diagnosis. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88) 
Sec. 4-19. - Proper care. 
    No owner shall fail to provide his or her animals with sufficient good and wholesome food and water, proper shelter and protection from the weather, veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering, and with humane care and treatment. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88) 
Sec. 4-20. - Cruel treatment prohibited. 
    No person shall beat cruelly, ill treat, torment, overload, overwork or otherwise abuse an animal, or cause, instigate or permit any dogfight, cockfight, bullfight or other combat between animals, or between animals and humans. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88) 
Sec. 4-21. - Abandonment prohibited. 
    No owner of an animal shall abandon such animal. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88) 
Sec. 4-22. - Motor vehicle striking an animal. 
    The operator of any motor vehicle which strikes a domestic animal shall stop at once and render such assistance as may be possible and shall immediately report such injury or death to the animal's owner. In the event the owner cannot be ascertained and located, such operator shall at once report the accident to the humane officer. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88) 
Sec. 4-23. - Poisonous substances. 
    No person shall expose any known poisonous substance, whether mixed with food or not, so that the same shall be subject to be eaten by any animal; provided that it shall not be unlawful for a person to expose on his own property common rat poison mixed only with vegetable substances. This section shall not apply to licensed pest control operators, or registered sanitarians or representatives of the board of health. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88) 
Sec. 4-24. - Sanitation of premises. 
    All structures, pens, coops or yards, wherein animals or fowl are confined, shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition at all times, devoid of vermin and free from offensive odors. The police department and building and zoning administrator may, at any time, inspect, or cause to be inspected, any structure or premises and issue any such order as may be necessary to enforce the provisions of this section and any other relevant or pertinent rule, regulation or ordinance. It shall be unlawful for any owner to fail to comply with such an order. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88; Ord. No. 1291, § 1(1), 2-25-2015) 
Sec. 4-25. - Restrictions on certain animals. 
    Wherever it is allowed under the zoning ordinances: 
(a)  The owner of any cow, bull, mule, donkey, horse, goat, sheep, swine, rabbit, chicken, duck, turkey or other domestic animal shall not: 
(1)  Allow such animal to run at large; or 
(2)  Keep such animal in any outdoor enclosure or pasture, the exterior boundary of which is less than fifty (50) feet from: 
a.  The dwelling house of another; 
b.  A commercial establishment; 
c.  A church; or 
d.  A school. 
(b)  Subsection (a)(2) of this section shall not include dogs and cats and shall only apply prospectively from November 1, 1987; but anyone prior to November, 1987, who kept the above-enumerated animals in any outdoor enclosure of which the exterior boundary is less than fifty (50) feet from the above structures, shall be prohibited from maintaining such usage at the time it is declared a legal nuisance by the court. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88; Ord. No. 859, § 8, 1-13-93; Ord. No. 885, § 9, 11-10-93) 
Sec. 4-26. - Riding animals on public ways. 
    No person may ride any animal on any city sidewalk. No person may ride any animal on any public ground, except on a public street, without first obtaining written consent from the chief of police. No person may ride any animal on the private property of another without first obtaining written consent to do so from that property owner. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88) 
Sec. 4-27. - Animal traps. 
    No person may set traps in the city for the purpose of apprehending wild or domesticated animals. This section does not prohibit: 
(1)  Trapping mice, rats or other household vermin; or 
(2)  The setting of traps to destroy moles and other underground pests, so long as the traps used may be triggered only by subsurface action; or 
(3)  The setting of traps in the line of duty by the humane officer, or with written permission from and the supervision of the humane officer or licensed pest control operators. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88) 
Sec. 4-27.1. - Dangerous animal-Defined. 
    Dangerous animal means: 
(1)  Any animal which is not naturally tame or gentle, and which is of a wild nature or disposition, and which is capable of killing, inflicting serious injury upon, or causing disease among human beings, or a domestic animal which attacks or bites without provocation, or a domestic animal which has demonstrated a propensity to attack or bite, if such propensity is known to the owner, or ought reasonably to be known to the owner, or a domestic animal which has known tendencies as a species to attack or bite. 
(2)  Any animals declared to be dangerous by the city council. 
(3)  The following animals which shall be deemed to be dangerous animals per se: 
a.  Lions, tiger, jaguars, leopards, cougars, lynxes, cheetahs, and bobcats; 
b.  Wolves, coyotes and foxes; 
c.  Badgers, wolverines, weasels, and skunks; 
d.  Raccoons; 
e.  Bears; 
f.  Monkey and chimpanzees; 
g.  Alligators and crocodiles; 
h.  Scorpions; 
i.  Snakes that are venomous or constrictors; 
j.  Gila monsters; 
k.  Any crossbreed of such animals which have similar characteristics to the animals specified above; 
l.  Reserved. 
m.  Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 859, § 9, 1-13-93; Ord. No. 885, § 10, 11-10-93; Ord. No. 933, § 1, 6-14-95; Ord. No. 926, § 1, 4-12-95; Ord. No. 1180, § 1, 5-25-2007; Ord. No. 1216, § 1, 1-27-2010; Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 5-23-2012) 
Sec. 4-27.2. - Same-Keeping prohibited. 
    No person shall keep, shelter, or harbor, for any purpose within the city, a dangerous animal except as provided in section 4-27.3 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 859, § 10, 1-13-93; Ord. No. 885, § 11, 11-10-93) 
Sec. 4-27.3. - Same-Exceptions. 
    The prohibition contained in section 4-27.2 of this Code shall not apply to the keeping of dangerous animals in the following circumstances: 
(1)  The keeping of dangerous animals in a public zoo, public aquarium, and bona fide educational or medical institution, humane society, or museum where they are kept as live specimens for the public to view, or for the purpose of instruction, research or study. 
(2)  The keeping of a dangerous animal for exhibition to the public by bona fide traveling circus, carnival, exhibit or show licensed to perform in the city. 
(3)  The keeping of dangerous animals in a bona fide, licensed veterinary hospital for treatment. 
(4)  The keeping of dangerous animals by a wildlife rescue organization with appropriate permit from the Iowa Conservation Commission. 
(5)  Any dangerous animals under the jurisdiction of and in the possession of the Iowa Conservation Commission, pursuant to Chapter 109 or 109A of the Iowa Code. 
(6)  The entry into and display at an approved dog show, while properly confined in a cage or on a leash and personally restrained by a handler or owner of the dog. 
(Ord. No. 859, § 11, 1-13-93; Ord. No. 885, § 12, 11-10-93; Ord. No. 1275, § 1, 1-22-2014) 
Sec. 4-27.4. - Same-Regulation of keeping. 
(a)  Every person, firm or corporation keeping, sheltering, or harboring a dangerous animal as permitted under section 4-27.3 shall at all times keep such animal securely confined within a cage or other enclosure approved by the community services officer. 
(b)  No person, firm or corporation owning, keeping, sheltering or harboring a dangerous animal as permitted under section 4-27.3 shall permit or allow such animal to enter upon, be placed in, or traverse any public property, park property, public right-of-way, public waterway or lagoon, or public sewer system, or any business establishment licensed by the city, or the property of another, except when such animal is being transported while caged or confined. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the persons permitted to keep dangerous animals under 4-27.3 to report to the police department when any dangerous animal is found missing. 
(d)  No person shall keep or harbor a dangerous animal which has demonstrated a propensity without provocation to attack or bite. 
(Ord. No. 859, § 12, 1-13-93; Ord. No. 885, § 3, 11-10-93; Ord. No. 1247, § 2, 5-23-2012) 
Secs. 4-27.5-4-27.7. - Reserved. 
Sec. 4-27.8. - Dangerous animals-Escape; general prohibition and duty. 
    No person shall aid or cause any dangerous animal, whether owned by such person or not, to escape confinement or impoundment, whether such confinement or impoundment be upon such person's property or that of another, by opening any gate, door or window or making any opening of any fence, enclosure of structure, or by unleashing or releasing such animal. 
(Ord. No. 859, § 13, 1-13-93; Ord. No. 885, § 14, 11-10-93) 
Sec. 4-27.9. - Same-Seizure, impoundment and disposition. 
(a)  In the event that a dangerous animal is found at large and unattended upon public property, park property, public right-of-way, public waterway, lagoon, or public sewer system, or the property of someone other than its owner, thereby creating a hazard to person or property, such animal may, in the discretion of the chief of police or his designee, be destroyed if it cannot be confined or captured. The city shall be under no duty to attempt the confinement or capture of a dangerous animal found at large, nor shall it have a duty to notify the owner of such animal prior to its destruction. In the event that an animal is subject to an action under section 4-27.2, or subsection (b) herein, the community service officer shall be authorized to immediately impound said animal at an approved animal control center. All impoundment fees shall be at the expense of the losing party, which fees shall include the actual cost of feeding and care of the animal. 
(b)  Upon the complaint of any individual that a person is keeping, sheltering, or harboring a dangerous animal as defined in section 4-27.1, the community services officer shall cause the matter to be investigated; and if, after investigation, the facts indicate that the person named in the complaint is keeping, sheltering or harboring a dangerous animal in the city, the community service officer shall order the person named in the complaint to safely remove such animal from the city, permanently place the animal with an organization or group allowed under section 4-27.3 of this Code to possess dangerous animals, or destroy the animal, within three (3) days of the receipt of such notice. The order described herein shall be contained in a notice which conforms to the requirements of the Mt. Pleasant Administrative Code (chapter 2, article VIII). Additionally, such order may be effective immediately pursuant to section 2-229, chapter 2, article VIII of the Mt. Pleasant Administrative Code, where such dangerous animal has previously caused serious physical harm or death to any person, in which case the community service officer shall cause the animal to be immediately seized and impounded or killed if seizure and impoundment are not possible without risk of serious physical harm or death to any person. 
(c)  The order to remove a dangerous animal issued by the community services officer may be appealed to the city council. In order to appeal such order, written notice of appeal must be filed with the city clerk within three (3) days after receipt of the order contained in the notice to remove the dangerous animal. Failure to file such written notice of appeal shall constitute a waiver of right to appeal the order. 
(d)  The notice of appeal shall state the grounds for such appeal and shall be delivered personally or by certified mail to the city clerk. The hearing of such appeal shall be scheduled within seven (7) days of the receipt of notice of appeal. The hearing may be continued for good cause. The hearing shall be conducted in the manner described in chapter 2, article VIII of the Mt. Pleasant Administrative Code. After such hearing, the city council may affirm or reverse the order of the community services officer. Such determination shall be contained in a written decision and shall be filed with the city clerk within three (3) days after the hearing, or any continued session thereof. 
(e)  If the city council affirms the action of the community services officer, the city council shall order in its written decision that the individual or entity owning, sheltering, harboring or keeping such dangerous animal, remove such animal from the city, permanently place such animal with an organization or group allowed under section 4-27.3 to possess dangerous animals, or destroy it. The decision and order shall immediately be served upon the person or entity against whom rendered in the same manner as the notice of removal. If the original order of the community services officer is not appealed or is not complied with within three (3) days of the order of the city council after appeal has been served, the community services officer or the police department is authorized to seize and impound such dangerous animal. An animal so seized shall be impounded for a period of seven (7) days. If at the end of the impoundment period the person against whom the decision and order of the community services officer or city council was issued has not petitioned the county district court for a review of the order, the community services officer shall cause the animal to be disposed of by sale, permanently place such animal with an organization or group allowed under section 4-27.3 to possess dangerous animals, or destroy such animal in a humane manner. All impoundment fees shall be at the expense of the owner of the dangerous animal, which said fee shall be the actual cost of the feeding and care of the animal. 
(Ord. No. 859, § 14, 1-13-93; Ord. No. 885, § 15, 11-10-93; Ord. No. 927, § 1, 4-12-95; Ord. No. 947, § 1, 1-10-96) 
Sec. 4-28. - Enforcement. 
    The civil provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by the community services officer or any police officer. It shall be a violation of this chapter to interfere with, hinder, molest or abuse such officer in the exercise of such powers. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88; Ord. No. 859, § 15, 1-13-93; Ord. No. 885, § 16, 11-10-93) 
Sec. 4-29. - Violation; penalties. 
(a)  Unless otherwise stated, all violations set forth in this chapter are simple misdemeanors and punishable as provided in section 1-8 of the Municipal Code. If any violation is continuing, each day's violation shall be deemed a separate violation. 
(b)  Any violation which is described as being a municipal infraction shall be subject to the penalties described in section 25-24(b)(1). 
(Ord. No. 707, § 1, 3-23-88; Ord. No. 859, § 16, 1-13-93; Ord. No. 885, § 17, 11-10-93) 
Sec. 4-30. - Procedure for declaration of potentially vicious dog. 
(a)  The community service officer may find and declare an animal potentially vicious based upon the following: 
(1)  The written complaint of a citizen that the animal has acted in a manner consistent with the definition of "potentially vicious dog;" 
(2)  Dog bite reports filed with the police department; 
(3)  Actions of the dog witnessed by an law enforcement officer; or 
(4)  Other substantial evidence. 
(b)  The declaration of a potentially vicious dog shall be in writing and shall be served on the owner in one (1) of the following methods: (i) personally, (ii) by certified mail to the owner at the owner's last known address, or (iii) if the owner cannot be served personally or by mail, by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in Henry County, Iowa. 
    The declaration shall state: 
(1)  The description of the animal; 
(2)  The name and address of the owner of the animal, if known; 
(3)  The location of the animal, if not in the custody of the owner; 
(4)  The facts upon which the declaration of potentially vicious dog is based; 
(5)  The owner's right to a hearing if the person objects to the declaration; 
(6)  The restrictions placed upon the animal as a result of the declaration of potentially vicious dog; and 
(7)  The penalties for a violation of such restrictions. 
(c)  The owner may object to the declaration of potentially vicious dog by requesting a hearing before the chief of police by submitting a written request to the chief of police within twenty (20) days after the date of mailing of the declaration, or within twenty (20) days after the publication of the declaration. 
(1)  If the chief of police finds that there is insufficient evidence to support the declaration, it shall be rescinded, and the restrictions imposed thereby annulled. 
(2)  If the chief of police finds sufficient evidence to support the declaration, the city clerk shall provide the owner with written notice of such determination within five (5) working days after the hearing. 
(3)  Upon service of notice and pending hearing, the owner shall confine the dog in a fenced enclosure on the owner's premises. It is unlawful for the owner of the potentially vicious dog to allow or permit such dog to go beyond the premises of the owner unless such dog is securely leashed and humanely muzzled or otherwise securely restrained. 
(4)  If it is determined by the chief of police or law enforcement officer that probable cause exists to believe the dog in questions poses an immediate threat to public safety, then the community service officer or law enforcement officer may seize and impound the dog pending the hearing to be held pursuant to this section. The owner or keeper of the dog shall be liable to the city for the costs and expenses of keeping the dog if the dog is later determined to be potentially vicious. When a dog has been impounded and it is not contrary to public safety, the community service officer shall permit the animal to be confined at the owner's expense in a city-approved kennel or veterinary facility. 
(Ord. No. 1216, § 3, 1-27-2010) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1216, § 3, adopted Jan. 27, 2010, set out provisions intended for use as §§ 4-30.1-4-30.5. In order to preserve the style of this Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been redesignated as §§ 4-30-4-34. 
Sec. 4-31. - Notification of status of potentially vicious dog. 
    The owner shall immediately notify the police department when a dog which has been classified as potentially vicious: 
(1)  Is loose or unconfined; 
(2)  Has bitten a human being or attacked another animal; 
(3)  Is sold or given away, or dies; or 
(4)  Is moved to another address. 
    Prior to a potentially vicious dog being sold or given away, the owner shall provide the name, address and telephone number of the new owner to the police department. The new owner shall comply with all the requirements of sections 4-30 through 4-33. 
(Ord. No. 1216, § 3, 1-27-2010) 
Editor's note- See editor's note to § 4-30. 
Sec. 4-32. - Exceptions to classification. 
    No dog may be declared potentially vicious if: 
(1)  Any injury or damage was sustained by a person who, at the time of the injury or damage was sustained, was committing a willful trespass or other tort upon premises occupied by the owner or keeper of the dog, or was teasing, tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the dog, or was committing or attempting to commit a crime; 
(2)  The dog was protecting or defending a person within the immediate vicinity of the dog from an unjustified attack or assault; or 
(3)  The injury or damage was sustained by a person or a domestic animal, which at the time of the injury or damage was sustained, was teasing, tormenting, abusing or assaulting the dog. 
    No dog may be declared potentially vicious if the injury or damage to a domestic animal was sustained while the dog was working as a hunting dog, herding dog or predator control dog on the property of, or under the control of, its owner or keeper, and the damage or injury was to a species or type of domestic animal appropriate to the work of the dog. 
(Ord. No. 1216, § 3, 1-27-2010) 
Editor's note- See editor's note to § 4-30. 
Sec. 4-33. - Disposition of potentially vicious dog. 
(a)  A potentially vicious dog shall be properly vaccinated. 
(b)  A potentially vicious dog, while on the owner's property, shall at all times be kept indoors or in a securely fenced yard from which the dog cannot escape and into which children cannot trespass. A potentially vicious animal may be off the owner's premises only if restrained by a substantial leash, or appropriate length, and if the dog is under the control of a responsible adult and is humanely muzzled. 
(c)  If a potentially vicious dog dies, or is sold, transferred or permanently removed from the city, the owner of the dog shall notify the police department of the changed condition and new location of the dog in writing within two (2) working days. 
(Ord. No. 1216, § 3, 1-27-2010) 
Editor's note- See editor's note to § 4-30. 
Sec. 4-34. - Penalty. 
    A person who violates an order of the community service officer pursuant to the terms of sections 4-30, 4-31, 4-32 or 4-33, shall be guilty of a simple misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 1216, § 3, 1-27-2010) 
Editor's note- See editor's note to § 4-30. 
Chapter 5 - BICYCLES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 891, adopted Jan. 12, 1994, amended this chapter to read as set out in §§ 5-1-5-12. The chapter formerly consisted of §§ 5-1-5-15 and was derived from Ord. Nos. 495, 531 and 898. 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 12; bicycle registration fee, § 25-17. 

Sec. 5-1. - License required. 
    Every person living within the city who owns a bicycle may cause the ownership thereof to be registered at the office of the police department or such office or location as the police department may designate. 
    A record of all bicycles registered shall be maintained by the chief of police and shall include the number of each license, the date issued, the name and address of the owner, the name of the manufacturer and serial number of the frame of the bicycle, and a record of all bicycle fees. 
    The fee to be submitted with the application for registration, as described in this section, shall be in the amount established in section 25-17. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 1, 1-12-94; Ord. No. 980, § 1, 1-8-97) 
Sec. 5-2. - Inspection of bicycles. 
    A police officer or such person as may be designated by the chief of police may inspect each bicycle before licensing same and may refuse a license for any bicycle which he determines to be in an unsafe mechanical condition or which does not have proper lighting or warning devices. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 1, 1-12-94) 
Sec. 5-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 981, adopted Jan. 8, 1997, amended the Code by repealing § 5-3. Prior to such amendment, § 5-3 pertained to alteration of identification devices and was derived from Ord. No. 891, § 1, adopted Jan 12, 1994. 
Sec. 5-4. - Lights and reflectors required. 
    All bicycles operated within the city limits shall from sunset to sunrise display a white light on the forward part of the bicycle or on the person operating the bicycle, visible from a distance of at least three hundred (300) feet, such light to have illuminating power. There shall also be displayed on the rear part of the bicycle at least one (1) red reflector or a red light visible from a distance of at least three hundred (300) feet. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 1, 1-12-94) 
Sec. 5-5. - Parking. 
    No person shall park a bicycle in any manner which may cause damage to public or private property. Bicycles must be parked in such manner as to not obstruct pedestrian traffic or motor vehicle traffic. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 1, 1-12-94) 
Sec. 5-6. - Rights of pedestrians and sidewalk riding. 
    Pedestrians upon sidewalks shall have the right-of-way at all times over persons using or operating bicycles upon any sidewalks. 
    Nothing in this section shall authorize the use or operation of a bicycle on a sidewalk that is otherwise prohibited in section 12-103 or in any other provisions of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 1, 1-12-94) 
Sec. 5-7. - Riding on roadways and bicycle paths. 
    Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall ride as near to the right side of the roadway as practicable, and shall exercise due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction. Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride in such a manner as to obstruct vehicular traffic and shall not ride more than two (2) abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles. Wherever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and shall not use the roadway. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 1, 1-12-94) 
Sec. 5-8. - Emerging from alley or driveway. 
    The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall, upon approaching a sidewalk or sidewalk area extending across any alleyway, yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians approaching on the sidewalk or sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on the roadway. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 1, 1-12-94) 
Sec. 5-9. - Traffic laws apply to persons operating bicycles. 
    Every person operating a bicycle upon the roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by the laws of this state declaring rules of the road applicable to a vehicle or by the traffic ordinances of this city applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except as to special regulations in this chapter and except as those provisions of law and ordinances which by their nature can have no application. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 1, 1-12-94) 
Sec. 5-10. - Methods of riding. 
    A bicycle rider shall not ride other than a astride a permanent and regular seat attached to the bicycle. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 1, 1-12-94) 
Sec. 5-11. - Carrying extra passengers. 
    Extra passengers shall not be carried upon a bicycle at any time except upon a suitable device constructed over the rear wheel for that purpose or for a tandem bicycle built for two (2) or more passengers. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 1, 1-12-94) 
Sec. 5-12. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a simple misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 1, 1-12-94)
