Sec. 6-16. - Adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted by reference that publication known as the International Building Code, Edition 2012, including Appendix A, B, C and E through K, International Residential Code, 2012 Edition, including Appendix A through K, and M through Q, and all published by the International Code Council; and each and all regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said International Building Code and International Residential Code, on file in the office of the city are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this section, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed below: 
International Building Code Section 903.2.8 Group R. An automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3 shall be provided throughout all buildings with a Group R fire area, except for any residential buildings with three or fewer residential units. 
International Residential Code Section R313.1 and R313.2 Townhouses and One-and Two-family dwellings automatic fire systems. The mandatory fire sprinkler systems requirements for townhouses and one-family or two-family dwelling units is hereby deleted. 
International Residential Code Section R501.3 entitled Fire protection of floors is not adopted and incorporated into the Mount Pleasant Municipal Code. 
(Code 1969, § 15.04.010; Ord. No. 582, § 1, 9-1-82; Ord. No. 683, § 1, 2-11-87; Ord. No. 772, § 1, 3-14-90; Ord. No. 1145, § 1, 4-27-2005; Ord. No. 1188, § 1, 12-12-2007; Ord. No. 1200, § 1, 5-27-2009; Ord. No. 1248, § 1(2), 7-25-2012; Ord. No. 1353, § 1, 7-25-2018) 
State Law reference- Power of city to adopt nationally recognized code by reference, I.C.A. § 380.10. 
Sec. 6-17. - Definition. 
    As used in the code adopted by reference herein, the term "city" shall mean the City of Mount Pleasant, Iowa. 
Sec. 6-18. - Permit fees. 
    A person desiring a permit required by the provisions of the code adopted by reference herein shall pay such fees as are established in section 25-1(a) and (b). 
(Ord. No. 839, § 1, 11-11-92) 
Sec. 6-19. - Preexisting uses.

Sec. 6-20. - Violations.

Sec. 6-21. - Alternate materials and methods of construction. 
    The building and zoning administrator may issue a building permit for a satisfactory alternate method of construction when a contractor can show a requested construction method not allowed by the International Building Code or International Residential Code, as amended, as a customary and proven reasonable practice within the construction community. 
(Ord. No. 721, § 1, 8-10-88; Ord. No. 1248, § 1(3), 7-25-2012) 
Sec. 6-22. - Modular, manufactured, and mobile homes. 
    Modular/manufacture/mobile homes shall be installed according to the manufacturer's installation instructions, the city building code, and state and federal requirements, as applicable. 
    Modular/manufacture/mobile homes shall be installed by installers licensed by the State of Iowa, or by unlicensed individuals under the direct supervision of a licensed individual, as permitted by state code. Licensed installers shall not perform work that is not permitted by their license. 
(Ord. No. 1346, § 1(Amd. 6), 3-14-2018)

ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICAL CODE[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Permit, examination and license fees, §§ 25-5-25-7; electrical distribution system in mobile home parks, App. C, § 29. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-32. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms, as used in this article, shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them in this section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    Inspector: The electrical inspector. 
    Owner: The owner, lessee or person in charge of the premises wherein or whereon electric wires, appliances, machinery, generators, or motors and fixtures are installed or are to be installed. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.040), 10-2-74) 
Sec. 6-33. - Adoption of National Electrical Code. 
    There is hereby adopted by reference that publication known as the National Electrical Code, 2014 Edition, as published by the National Fire Protection Association, with amendments approved by the State of Iowa. Copies of such code are available in the office of the city's building and zoning administrator. 
(Ord. No. 435, § (15.08.020, 15.08.030), 10-2-74; Ord. No. 491, § 1, 1-4-78; Ord. No. 615, § 1, 2-15-84; Ord. No. 737, § 1, 4-12-89; Ord. No. 797, § 1, 4-24-91; Ord. No. 1297, § 1(Amd. 3), 3-10-2015) 
State Law reference- Power of city to adopt nationally recognized code by reference, I.C.A. § 380.10. 
Sec. 6-34. - Scope. 
    Nothing contained in this article or the code adopted by reference herein shall apply to the installation of radio wires and equipment; unless the same extend over streets, alleys, or public ways, doorbells, and signal devices, telephone or telegraph wires unconnected with lighting or power lines, or connected with such light and power lines by fixtures approved by the provisions hereof or other ordinances of the city, or to transmission lines upon the public highways, powerhouses and substations furnishing the public with electricity, and in charge of a full-time engineer. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.320), 10-2-74) 
Sec. 6-35. - Commercial power companies. 
    No person shall furnish commercial electrical service to another before giving written notice of his intent to do so to the inspector. No such person shall install an electric meter without giving such notice. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.350), 10-2-74) 
Sec. 6-36. - Connections to electrolier systems. 
    No person shall cut any cable, wire or connection forming a part of any electrolier system installed or maintained by the city, or make any private connection therewith, without the consent of the council. The person securing such consent shall give due notice giving the inspector an opportunity to be present when such cut-off connection is made; the same shall be made in a manner satisfactory to the inspector and only upon payment of such inspection fee as is established by the council. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.370), 10-2-74) 
Sec. 6-37. - Violations. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this article or the code adopted herein shall be guilty of a municipal infraction. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.380), 10-2-74; Ord. No. 1297, § 1(Amd. 2), 3-10-2015) 
Secs. 6-38-6-44. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 6-45. - Electrical inspector generally. 
(a)  The inspector shall be under the supervision of the building and zoning administrator and shall possess an adequate knowledge of the technical science of electricity and a basic understanding of the provisions of this article. 
(b)  The inspector shall not actively engage in the electrical business, nor complete with the class and kind of work he may be called upon to examine, nor shall he be directly or indirectly connected with any person so engaged in the electrical business. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(5.08.050), 10-2-74) 
Sec. 6-46. - Records, reports, etc. 
    The inspector shall keep or cause to be kept a complete daily record of all permits issued, inspections made, fees collected or other official work performed each month. He shall make a monthly and annual report thereof to the building and zoning administrator. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(5.08.050), 10-2-74) 
Sec. 6-47. - Permit fees. 
    All electrical permit fees collected by the inspector shall be turned over to the city. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(5.08.050), 10-2-74) 
Sec. 6-48. - Electrical appeal board and electrical board of examiners. 
(a)  There is hereby established an electrical appeal board. There is hereby established an electrical board of examiners. 
(b)  Both boards shall be composed of three (3) members appointed by the council for terms of three (3) years. The same persons shall serve on both boards. 
(c)  The inspector shall be an ex officio nonvoting member of both boards and shall serve as secretary to both. 
Sec. 6-49. - Appeals from decision of inspector. 
    Any person affected by any action, interpretation or notice issued by the electrical inspector with respect to this code may, in writing, appeal to the electrical appeal board for consideration in accordance with the procedures set forth in the Mt. Pleasant Administrative Code (chapter 2, article VIII). 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.060, 15.08.150(I), (J)), 10-2-74; Ord. No. 948, § 1, 1-10-96) 
Sec. 6-50. - Orders to correct conditions. 
(a)  If the inspector finds that electrical wiring or installations are unsafe to life or property, or are in violation of any of the provisions of this article, he shall order the person owning, using, or operating them to place them in a safe and secure condition which conforms to the provisions of this article within such reasonable period of time as may be fixed by the inspector. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to obey such an order. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.070), 10-2-74) 
Sec. 6-51. - Disconnection of current. 
(a)  The inspector shall order electrical service discontinued to any premises, wire, apparatus or device which: 
(1)  Is not in compliance with any of the provisions of this article; 
(2)  Presents a danger to persons or property; 
(3)  Interferes with, or hampers the work of, the police or fire departments. 
(b)  Upon receipt of such an order the person furnishing electricity to such premises, wire, apparatus or device shall cease to do so. 
(c)  After the issuance of such an order it shall be unlawful for any person to furnish electricity or reconnect any electricity to any premises, wire, apparatus or device without written permission of the inspector. The inspector shall not grant such permission until the condition which caused him to order the electrical service discontinued has been corrected. 
(d)  All electrical service equipment that has been disconnected involuntarily shall be inspected by the city electrical inspector before it is energized. All electrical service equipment that has been disconnected for more than one hundred eighty (180) days, whether voluntarily or involuntarily, shall be inspected by the city electrical inspector before it is energized. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.110, 15.08.350), 10-2-74; Ord. No. 1339, § 5, 11-21-2017) 
Secs. 6-52-6-58. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS 

Sec. 6-59. - Permit required. 
    Permits and inspections for all installations and alterations are required, unless all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The installation/alteration is performed by a licensed electrical contractor, residential electrical contractor or their employees. 
(2)  The installation/alteration does not in any way involve work within a new or existing switchboard or panel board. 
(3)  The installation/alteration does not exceed thirty (30) amps. 
(4)  The installation does not exceed two hundred seventy-seven (277) volts, single phase. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.330), 10-2-74; Ord. No. 1296, § 1(Amd. 2), 3-10-2015) 
Sec. 6-60. - Permit application. 
    A person desiring the permit required by the provisions of this division shall apply in writing and shall state the location of the premises, the name of the applicant and the name of the owner, and a general description of the nature and extent of the work. When deemed necessary by the inspector, the applicant shall also file, as a part of his application, plans and specifications showing in detail the location and nature and character of all electrical work proposed to be done under the permit. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.330), 10-2-74) 
Sec. 6-61. - Temporary permits. 
    While the work of installation, alteration or extension of any electrical apparatus or wires in, over or about any premises is in progress, the inspector may issue a temporary permit for the use of electrical current in writing. Such temporary permit shall be issued only upon the agreement that all temporary wiring shall be removed by the person installing it at the expiration of the permit, but in no case shall the time for temporary use of electrical wiring exceed six (6) months. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.330), 10-2-74) 
Sec. 6-62. - Compliance as prerequisite to permit issuance. 
    The inspector shall not issue a permit required by the provisions of this division unless the work it is for complies with the provisions of this article and all other ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.330), 10-2-74) 
Sec. 6-63. - Permit and inspection fees. 
    A person desiring an electrical permit shall pay to the city at the time of the permit application such permit and inspection fees as are established in section 25-5. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.330), 10-2-74; Ord. No. 840, § 1, 11-11-92) 
Sec. 6-64. - Notice of completion and inspection of work. 
    In order to give an opportunity for an inspection when work is completed, the electrical permit holder shall give the inspector notice that the installation, alteration or extension of any electrical apparatus or wires in, over or about any premises is ready for inspection. The inspector shall make such inspection within forty-eight (48) hours after receiving such notice. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.10), 10-2-74) 
Sec. 6-65. - Refusal to permit inspection. 
    Any person who refuses to permit the inspector to make any lawful inspection shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.070), 10-2-74) 
Sec. 6-66. - Covering or concealing work. 
    Except as permitted by the inspector, no electrical wiring or work which is within the scope of the provisions of this article shall be covered or concealed until it has been inspected and approved by the inspector. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.300), 10-2-74) 
Secs. 6-67-6-73. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE 

Sec. 6-74. - Required. 
    Except as otherwise provided, no person shall make any connection from any electrical apparatus or wires to any wire supplying electricity without a certificate of compliance issued by the inspector. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.340), 10-2-74) 
Sec. 6-75. - Issuance. 
    The certificate required by the provisions of this division shall not be issued for any electrical apparatus or wires which are not in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 435, § 1(15.08.340), 10-2-74) 
Secs. 6-76-6-82. - Reserved.

ARTICLE V. - PLUMBING CODE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 20; plumbing permit fees, § 25-2. 

Sec. 6-148. - Adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted by reference that publication known as the International Plumbing Code, 2012 Edition, including Appendices A and B, published by the International Code Council. 
(Code 1969, § 15.20.010; Ord. No. 744, § 1, 3-14-90; Ord. No. 1188, § 2, 12-12-2007; Ord. No. 1248, § 1(5), 7-25-2012) 
State Law reference- Power of city to adopt nationally recognized code by reference, I.C.A. § 380.10 
Sec. 6-149. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions are added to those adopted in the most current Uniform Plumbing Code, or are modified from those definitions for sections 6-149 through 6-153 only. 
    Approved backflow prevention assembly for containment is a backflow prevention assembly which is listed by the University of Southern California-Foundation for Cross Connection Control and Hydraulic Research as having met the requirement of ANSI-ANWA Standard C510-89, "Double Check Valve Backflow-Prevention Assemblies" for containment. This listing shall include the limitations of use based on the degree of hazard. The backflow prevention assembly must also be listed by the International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical Officials. 
    Approved backflow prevention assembly for containment in a fire protection system is a backflow prevention assembly to be used in a fire protection system which meets the requirements of Factory Mutual Research Corporation (FM) and Underwriters Laboratory (UL) in addition to the requirements of the city. 
    City as used in this code shall mean the City of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa. 
    Containment is a method of backflow prevention which requires a backflow prevention assembly on certain water services. Containment requires that the backflow prevention assembly be installed on the water service as close to the public water supply main as is practical. 
    Customer is the owner, operator or occupant of a building, or property which has a water service from a public water system, or the owner or operator of a private water system which has a water service from a public water system. 
    Degree of hazard is the rating of a cross connection or a water service which indicates if it has the potential to cause contamination (high hazard) or pollution (low hazard). 
    Water service, depending on the context, is the physical connection between a public water system and a customer's building, property or private water system, or the act of providing potable water to a customer. 
(Ord. No. 1009, § 1, 2-25-98) 
Sec. 6-150. - Proposed water service. 
(a)  No person shall install, or cause to have installed, a water service to a building, property or private water system unless the water service is protected by an approved backflow prevention assembly for containment. 
(b)  The city shall require the submission of plans, specifications and other information deemed necessary for a building, property, or private water system to which a water service is proposed. The city shall review the information submitted to determine if cross connections will exist and the degree of hazard. 
(c)  For any new building, property or private water system, the owner shall install, or cause to have installed, an approved backflow prevention assembly for containment as directed by the city before water service is initiated. "New" for the purpose of this section shall mean a building, property or private water system which, prior to the enactment of this section, did not have water service. 
(d)  Reconstruction of an existing water service shall be treated as a new water service for the purposes of the backflow prevention provisions of this code. 
(e)  For any existing building, property or private water system with a water service, the city or it's designee, shall install an approved backflow prevention assembly in accordance with all applicable regulations, and such assembly and installations shall be at the city's expense. "Existing" for the purpose of this section shall mean a building, property or private water system which, prior to the enactment of this section, had water service. 
(f)  After the initial installation of the backflow prevention assembly as described in paragraph (e) of this section, the owner shall be responsible for all repairs to the device or replacement of the device, whichever is applicable. 
(Ord. No. 1009, § 1, 2-25-98) 
Sec. 6-151. - Existing water services. 
(a)  The city shall adopt the standards which it uses to determine the degree of hazard for a water service. These shall consistent with the standards published by the Iowa department of public health. 
(b)  Each customer shall survey the activities and processes which receive water from the water service and shall report to the city if cross connections exist and the degree of hazard. 
(c)  The city may inspect the plumbing of any building, property or private water system which receives water service to determine if cross connections exist and the degree of hazard. 
(d)  If a customer refuses to install a backflow prevention assembly for a containment when it is required by the city, the city may order that water service to the customer be discontinued until an appropriate backflow prevention assembly is installed. 
(Ord. No. 1009, § 1, 2-25-98) 
Sec. 6-152. - Backflow prevention assemblies for containment. 
(a)  Backflow prevention assemblies for containment shall be installed immediately following the water meter or as close to that location as deemed practical by the city. 
(b)  A water service determined to present a high hazard shall be protected by an air gap or an approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly. 
(c)  A water service determined to present a low hazard shall be protected by an approved double check valve assembly or as in 6-153 (b). 
(d)  A water service to a fire protection system shall be protected from backflow in accordance with the recommendations of American Water Works Association Manual M14. Where backflow prevention is required for a fir protection system, an approved backflow prevention assembly for containment in a fire protection system shall be used. 
(Ord. No. 1009, § 1, 2-25-98) 
Sec. 6-153. - Backflow incidents. 
(a)  The customer shall immediately notify the agency providing water service when the customer becomes aware that backflow has occurred in the building, property or private water system receiving water service. 
(b)  The city may order that a water service be temporarily shut off when a backflow occurs in a customer's building, property or private water system. 
(Ord. No. 1009, § 1, 2-25-98) 
Sec. 6-154. - Permit fees. 
    A person desiring a permit required by the provisions of the code adopted by reference herein shall pay such fees as are established in section 25-2(a) and (b). 
(Code 1969, § 15.20.040; Ord. No. 843, § 1, 11-11-92; Ord. No. 1009, § 1, 2-25-98) 
Sec. 6-155. - Preexisting uses. 
    The provisions of the plumbing code adopted by reference herein shall not apply to preexisting uses, except for such sections which specifically state otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 1009, § 1, 2-25-98) 
Sec. 6-156. - Violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of this article or the Code adopted by reference herein. 
(Ord. No. 1009, § 1, 2-25-98) 
Secs. 6-157-6-166. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - DANGEROUS BUILDINGS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Nonamendatory Ord. No. 776, §§ 1-12, adopted May 9, 1990, has been treated by the editor as superseding former Art. VI, §§ 6-167-6-172, pertaining to similar provisions, and has been codified herein as a new Art. VI, §§ 6-167-6-178. Formerly, Art. VI originated from the 1969 Code, §§ 16.30.010-15.30.050 and 15.30.070. 
Cross reference- Historic preservation commission, § 2-70 et seq.; building and zoning administrator, § 6-201; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8. 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate dangerous buildings, ICA § 364.12(3); collection of costs, ICA § 364.12(3)(h). 

Sec. 6-167. - Declaration of policy and legislative intent. 
    The city council finds that it is essential to the public welfare and safety to deal effectively with the hazards presented by buildings which pose an immediate threat to persons and other property in the city. At the same time, the city council affirms its commitment to conserve the city's building resources. It is the policy of the city and the intent of this article that all municipal actions affecting dangerous buildings shall be the least destructive alternative that is both cost effective and consistent with safety to persons and other property. 
(Ord. No. 776, § 1, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 6-168. - Definitions of words and phrases. 
    The following words and phrases when used in this article shall, for the purposes of this article, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Building: any building or structure or any member, components, appurtenance or exterior ornamentation thereof within the city. 
    Dangerous building: All buildings which are an immediate danger to persons or other property because of such building's physical condition, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Whenever any portion or member or appurtenance of a building is likely to fail, become detached or dislodged or to collapse. 
(2)  Whenever any portion of a building or any member, appurtenance or ornamentation on the exterior thereof is not of sufficient strength or stability or is not so anchored, attached or fastened in place so as to be capable of resisting a wind pressure or earthquake forces equal to one-half (1/2) that required by applicable codes for new buildings. 
(3)  Whenever a building or structure or any portion thereof by reason of: 
a.  Deterioration or decay; 
b.  Noncode conforming construction; 
c.  The removal, movement or instability of any portion of the ground necessary for building support; or 
d.  Any other cause. 
Is likely to collapse partially or completely. 
(4)  Whenever the exterior walls or other vertical structural members of a building list, lean or buckle to such an extent that the building or structure is unstable or overstressed as defined by applicable codes. 
(5)  Whenever a building or structure is determined by the fire marshal or fire chief to be a fire hazard. 
(6)  Whenever any portion of a building or structure remains on a site after seventy-five (75) percent of the structure has been destroyed by demolition, destruction, collapse or burning of the building. 
    Owner: All persons who hold an equitable, legal or possessory interest in a building, including tenants, and who have the right to make repairs. 
(Ord. No. 776, § 2, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 6-169. - Inspection. 
    Whenever the building and zoning administrator has reasonable cause to believe that a building in the city is dangerous, the building and zoning administrator may inspect that building. The inspection shall take place at a reasonable time, and the owner shall be given reasonable opportunity to consent to the inspection. The owner without penalty may refuse to allow access to the building. In such case, the building and zoning administrator may apply to the Iowa District Court for a search warrant. 
(Ord. No. 776, § 3, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 6-170. - Building and zoning administrator's order. 
(a)  Whenever the building and zoning administrator inspects a building and finds it to be dangerous as defined in this article, the building and zoning administrator shall give to the owner of the building an order to correct those conditions which make the building dangerous. The corrective action ordered by the building and zoning administrator shall be the least destructive alternative that is both cost effective and consistent with safety to persons and property and may be the demolition of the structure. The building and zoning administrator order shall not prescribe specific construction, design, methods, techniques or materials. The order shall state the address and legal description of the property, and shall conform to the additional notice requirements of the Mt. Pleasant Administrative Code (chapter 2, article VIII). 
(b)  Notice of the order shall be served upon the owner in writing delivered either by personal service as in civil actions or by certified mail, return receipt requested. The period within which the owner is required to comply with the order of the building and zoning administrator shall begin as of the date the owner is served with such notice or the last date of publication of the notice. The building and zoning administrator may cause the notice to be recorded in the office of the Henry County Recorder. 
(c)  Whenever the building and zoning administrator issues an order affecting a building, a copy of the order along with a brightly colored placard labeling the building as dangerous shall be posted at each entrance to the building. Such order and placard shall remain posted until the required corrective actions are completed. Such order and placard shall not be removed without the written permission of the building and zoning administrator. 
(Ord. No. 776, § 4, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 6-171. - Appeal. 
    Any person affected by any action, interpretation or notice issued by the building official with respect to a dangerous building, may appeal the decision of the building official to the city council. Such appeal shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures set forth in the Mt. Pleasant Administrative Code (chapter 2, article VIII), with the additional requirement that notice of the appeal hearing shall be published as provided in Section 362.3 of the Code of Iowa. The burden of proof shall be upon the building and zoning official to show by a preponderance of the evidence that the building is dangerous. 
(Ord. No. 776, § 5, 5-9-90; Ord. No. 948, § 1, 1-10-96) 
Sec. 6-172. - Same-Compliance with. 
(a)  The owner of a building who receives an order pursuant to section 6-170 shall comply with that order. 
(b)  The filing of an appeal to the city council shall stay any further action by the city until the appeal is decided by the city council unless the building and zoning administrator has issued an emergency order pursuant to section 6-178. 
(c)  If the owner of the building does not appeal the building and zoning administrator's order and does not comply with such order, the building and zoning administrator shall request an order from the city council. The city council shall set such a request for hearing regarding the corrective action only and proceed as provided in subsection 6-173(d). 
(Ord. No. 776, § 6, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 6-173. - City council hearing regarding corrective action. 
(a)  If the owner does not appeal the building and zoning official's order and does not comply with such order, then the matter shall be set for hearing regarding corrective action. Alternatively, if the owner does appeal the building and zoning official's order and loses at the hearing described in section 6-172, then the city council shall proceed at the hearing to address the corrective action necessary to remedy the problem, including demolition. 
(b)  The city council shall allow argument and evidence to be submitted by the historical preservation commission and any other not-for-profit or governmental body with interests and responsibilities in the historical preservation of buildings and structures. Depending on the nature and severity of the defects which caused the building to be found dangerous, the city council may order corrective action, which shall be the least destructive alternative that is both cost effective and consistent with safety to persons and other property. The order of the city council with respect to corrective action shall be supported by written findings of fact and conclusions. 
(c)  A city council determination that a building is dangerous shall be filed in the office of the Henry County Recorder. 
(Ord. No. 776, § 7, 5-9-90; Ord. No. 948, § 1, 1-10-96) 
Sec. 6-174. - Violations. 
    It shall be a simple misdemeanor for any person to fail to obey a council order for corrective action. Each day of such noncompliance shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 776, § 8, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 6-175. - Right to take corrective action. 
    In case the owner fails, neglects or refuses to comply with the council's order to take corrective action with respect to a building or structure or portion thereof, the city council may, in addition to any other remedies, take bids for the corrective action and cause to have done the ordered work. A statement of the cost for such work will be transmitted to the council. 
(Ord. No. 776, § 9, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 6-176. - Costs. 
    Costs incurred under section 6-175 shall be paid by the city. Such costs shall be charged to the owner of the premises involved and may be: 
(1)  Levied against the land on which the building or structure is located and shall be collected in the manner provided in section 364.12(3)(h), Code of Iowa, as amended.; or 
(2)  Collected through a civil action for damages against the owner of the building or structure involved as provided in Section 364.12(4), Code of Iowa, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 776, § 10, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 6-177. - Transfer of Ownership. 
    Whenever the ownership of a building found by the council to be dangerous is transferred or assigned, the new owner shall notify the building and zoning administrator of the transfer. Upon request of the new owner, a hearing shall be held before the council to determine a council order regarding the disposition of the building as provided in subsection 6-173(d). 
(Ord. No. 776, § 11, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 6-178. - Emergency orders. 
    Whenever the building and zoning administrator inspects a building and finds it to be dangerous and further finds that the condition of the building presents a serious and imminent threat to the lives of persons within or without the building, the building and zoning administrator shall, in addition to the order in section 6-170 herein, give to the owner and occupants of the building an emergency order to vacate and secure the building. The emergency order shall be served upon the owner as provided in subsection 6-170(b) herein and shall be served upon the building. The emergency order may not be appealed by may be modified by the city council after hearing as provided in section 6-172 herein. It shall be a simple misdemeanor for any person to fail to obey an emergency order to vacate and secure a dangerous building. Each day of noncompliance shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 776, § 12, 5-9-90) 
Secs. 6-179-6-183. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - MOVING BUILDINGS 

Sec. 6-184. - Permit required. 
    No person shall move any building on, through or over any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place without a permit issued by the building and zoning administrator. 
(Code 1969, § 15.24.010; Ord. No. 1220, § 1(1), 5-12-2010) 
Sec. 6-185. - Permit application. 
    A person desiring the permit required herein shall apply in writing, stating the proposed route and the number of days it is intended that the building shall occupy any portion of a street, alley, sidewalk or other public place. 
(Code 1969, § 15.24.010) 
Sec. 6-186. - Permit fee. 
    A person desiring a permit required by the provisions of this article shall pay such fee in the amount established in section 25-1(b)(5). 
(Ord. No. 855, § 1, 11-11-92) 
Sec. 6-187. - Bond. 
    Every person applying for a permit under this article shall submit with his application either a cash bond, or a bond with a lawful surety to be approved by the building and zoning administrator, conditioned on his complying with the provisions of this article and all applicable ordinances and hold the city harmless from any claim which may be made against it by reason of the occupation of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place, by the building or structure moved. The bond shall be in such amount as may be required by the building and zoning administrator; provided that in no event shall the bond be less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
(Code 1969, § 15.24.030; Ord. No. 1220, § 1(2), 5-12-2010) 
Sec. 6-188. - Lights and warnings. 
    Whenever a street or alley is blocked by a structure which is being moved, warnings to that effect shall be placed so as to warn vehicles and persons from entering that portion of the street so blocked. The person moving any structure through the streets shall keep warning signs and lanterns or lights at night on it so as to guard against any person or vehicle colliding with it. 
(Code 1969, § 15.24.040) 
Sec. 6-189. - Cutting of wires. 
    Whenever it is necessary to interfere with wires or cables of a public utility in moving a building, the terms of any special or franchise ordinance governing the same shall apply, and the bond therein specified shall be given. If no such terms apply, then the mayor shall estimate the expense of fixing the wires, and the cash deposit to be given shall be used to cover such expense. 
(Code 1969, § 15.24.050) 
Sec. 6-190. - Notice to fire chief. 
    The fire chief shall be given at least six (6) hours notice if any building or structure which is to be moved approaches any fire alarm wire or pole which bears fire alarm wires. 
(Code 1969, § 15.24.060) 
Secs. 6-191-6-199. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - CONSTRUCTION BOARD OF APPEALS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Appointive position of the building and zoning administrator, § 2-18(6); zoning administrator, App. D, § 19.02.040. 

Sec. 6-200. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a construction board of appeals. 
(Ord. No. 703, § 1, 2-15-88) 
Sec. 6-201. - Appointment of members; building and zoning administrator; terms; vacancies. 
(a)  The mayor, subject to the approval of the city council, shall appoint the members of the construction board of appeals. The makeup of the board shall consist of three (3) members who shall be residents of the city and shall include one (1) general contractor, one (1) person who is either a plumbing or mechanical contractor, and one (1) lay person from the general public with an understanding and knowledge of construction. Two (2) members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any business or vote. 
    The building and zoning administrator shall be an ex officio member of the board without a vote and shall perform the duties of secretary thereto. The building and zoning administrator shall be responsible for the coordination of the board's activities. 
(b)  The terms of the membership shall be for three (3) years each and shall be staggered so that no more than one (1) member's term expires in any one (1) year. Vacancies shall be filled by the mayor's appointment, subject to the approval of the council, for the unexpired term of any member whose term becomes vacant. Nominations of persons to fill vacancies may be submitted to the mayor by the construction board of appeals. 
(Ord. No. 703, § 1, 2-15-88) 
Sec. 6-202. - Meetings and hearings. 
    All meetings and hearings of the construction board of appeals shall be held at the call of the chairman or upon request by a quorum of the board, and in no case shall they be less frequent than twice each calendar year and at such other times and places as the board may determine in order to properly transact its business. 
    All meetings or hearings conducted by the board shall be open to the public. The board shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon each question or time of business, or, if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and shall also keep current and accurate records of its meetings and hearings and other official actions. Findings of fact shall be included in the minutes of each meeting, and any reasons for approval or denial of any case or item brought before the board shall be specified. One (1) copy of the minutes of any meeting or hearing conducted by the board shall be filed in the office of the building and zoning administrator and shall be of public record, and one (1) copy shall be submitted to the city council. The board shall adopt its own rules of procedure and policies, not in conflict with this Code or with the Iowa Statutes, and may select or appoint such officers as it deems necessary. The city council shall provide a suitable place in which the board shall conduct its required business. 
(Ord. No. 703, § 1, 2-15-88) 
Sec. 6-203. - Compensation; expenses. 
    The construction board of appeals shall serve without compensation, except for necessary incidental expenses that are incurred while carrying out the board's business. In order for the board to receive payment for expenses incurred, the board shall cause to have itemized the expense requests in writing and submit same to the council for review and recommendation, before same is authorized and approved for payment. 
(Ord. No. 703, § 1, 2-15-88) 
Sec. 6-204. - Authority; duties and appeals generally. 
    The construction board of appeals is authorized to perform the following duties and functions in order to carry out the provisions of this chapter. 
(1)  Hear and decide appeals requested by any person regarding the technical interpretation of the provisions of the city's adopted building, plumbing, mechanical, electrical and housing codes, or other related codes as may hereafter be adopted from time to time, and appeals from persons aggrieved by any order or decision rendered by the building and zoning administrator, or such other designated person, in regard to the above codes. Appeals shall be in accordance with the procedure set forth in the Mt. Pleasant Administrative Code (chapter 2, article VIII). 
(2)  Keep accurate and up-to-date records and minutes of all meetings, hearings and business conducted by the board. 
(Ord. No. 703, § 1, 2-15-88; Ord. No. 948, § 1, 1-10-96; Ord. No. 1294, § 1(1), 2-25-2015) 
Secs. 6-205-6-215. - Reserved.
