Chapter 6.5 - CABLE TELEVISION REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The editor has included the provisions of Ord. Nos. 893 and 894, both adopted Feb. 9, 1994, as Arts. II and III of a newly created Ch. 6.5. Neither ordinance specifically amended this Code. 
Cross reference- Cablevision advisory committee, § 2-61 et seq.; CATV franchises, App. A, Arts. I, IV, V. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 6.5-1-6.5-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REGULATION OF RATES 

Sec. 6.5-16. - Adoption of FCC Rules and Regulations. 
    The City of Mt. Pleasant (hereinafter called "the city") has the legal authority to administer and shall enforce against any non-municipally-owned cable television system operator, as permitted therein, the provisions of Part 76, Subpart N of the Rules and Regulations of the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) concerning cable rate regulation, 47 C.F.R. section 76.900 et seq., as they currently read and hereafter may be amended, which are herewith incorporated by reference. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 1, 2-9-94) 
Sec. 6.5-17. - Public proceedings authorized. 
    Any rate regulation proceedings conducted under section 6.5-16 shall provide reasonable opportunity for consideration of the view of any interested party, including but not limited to the city or its designee, the cable operator, subscribers and residents of the franchise area. In addition to other provisions required by the laws of the state and the city for such proceedings, and in order to provide such opportunity for consideration of the views of any interested party, the city shall take the following actions: 
(1)  The city shall publish notice as provided in I.C.A. § 362.4, and shall mail, by certified mail, to the cable operator a notice of the intent to conduct a public proceeding on basic service tier rates and/or changes for equipment to receive such basic service tier, as defined by the FCC. 
(2)  This notice shall state, among other things, that cable television rates are subject to municipal review and explain the nature of the rate review in question; that any interested party has a right to participate in the proceeding; that public views may be submitted in the proceeding, explaining how they are to be submitted and the deadline for submitting any such views; that a decision concerning the reasonableness of the cable television rates in question will be governed by the FCC Rules and Regulations; and that the decision of the city is subject to review by the FCC. 
(3)  The city shall conduct a public proceeding to determine whether or not the rates or proposed rate increase is reasonable. The city may delegate the responsibility to conduct the proceeding to any duly qualified and eligible individual(s) or entity. If the city or its designee cannot determine the reasonableness of a proposed rate increase within the time period permitted by the FCC Rules and Regulations, it may announce the effective date of the proposed rates for an additional period of time as permitted by the FCC Rules and Regulations, and issue any other necessary or appropriate order and give notice accordingly. 
(4)  In the course of the rate regulation proceeding, the city may require additional information from the cable operator that is reasonably necessary to determine the reasonableness of the basic service tier rates and equipment charges. Any such additional information submitted to the city shall be verified by an appropriate official of the cable television system supervising the preparation of the response on behalf of the entity, and submitted by way of affidavit or under penalty of perjury, stating that the response is true and accurate to the best of that persons knowledge, information and belief formed after reasonable inquiry. The city may request propriety information, provided that the city shall consider a timely request from the cable operator that such proprietary information shall not be made available for public information, consistent with the procedures set forth in section 0.459 of the FCC Rules and Regulations. Furthermore, such proprietary information may be used only for the purpose of determining the reasonableness of the rates and charges or the appropriate rate level based on a cost-of-service showing submitted by the cable operator. The city may exercise all powers under the laws of evidence applicable to administrative proceedings under the laws of the state and of the city to discover any information relevant to the rate regulation proceeding, including, but not limited to, subpoena, interrogatories, production of documents and deposition. 
(5)  Upon termination of the rate regulation proceeding, the city shall adopt and release a written decision as to whether or not the rates or proposed rate increase are reasonable or unreasonable, and, if unreasonable, its remedy, including prospective rate reduction, rate prescription and refunds. 
(6)  The city may not impose any fines, penalties, forfeitures or other sanctions, other than permitted by the FCC Rules and Regulations, for charging an unreasonable rate or proposing an unreasonable rate increase. 
(7)  Consistent with FCC Rules and Regulations, the city's decision may be reviewed only by the FCC. 
(8)  The city shall be authorized, at any time, whether or not in the course of a rate regulation proceeding, to gather information as necessary to exercise its jurisdiction as authorized by the Communications Act of 1934, as amended, and the FCC Rules and Regulations. Any information submitted to the city shall be verified by an appropriate official of the cable television system supervising the preparation of the response on behalf of the entity, and submitted by way of affidavit or under penalty of perjury, stating that the response is true and accurate to the best of that person's knowledge, information and belief formed after reasonable inquiry. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 2, 2-9-94) 
Sec. 6.5-18. - Filing of FCC form. 
    The city shall file with the FCC the required certification form (FCC Form 328) on September 1, 1993, or as soon thereafter as appropriate. Thirty (30) days later, or as soon thereafter as appropriate, the city shall notify the cable operator that the city has been certified by the FCC and that it has adopted all necessary regulations so as to begin regulating basic service tier cable television rates and equipment charges. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 3, 2-9-94) 
Sec. 6.5-19. - Notice of change of rates. 
    With regard to the cable programming service tier, as defined by the Communications Act of 1934, as amended, and the FCC Rules and Regulations, and over which the city is not empowered to exercise rate regulation, the cable operator shall give notice to the city of any change in rates for the cable programming service tier or tiers, any change in the charge for equipment required to receive the tier or tiers, and any changes in the nature of the services provided, including the program services included in the tier or tiers. This notice shall be provided within five (5) business days after the change becomes effective. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 4, 2-9-94) 
Sec. 6.5-20. - Cable official. 
    The city may delegate its powers to enforce this article to municipal employees or officers ("cable official"). The cable official will have the authority to: 
(1)  Administer oaths and affirmations; 
(2)  Issue subpoenas; 
(3)  Examine witnesses; 
(4)  Rule upon questions of evidence; 
(5)  Take or cause depositions to be taken; 
(6)  Conduct proceedings in accordance with this article; 
(7)  Exclude from the proceeding any person engaging in contemptuous conduct or otherwise disrupting the proceedings; 
(8)  Hold conferences for the settlement or simplification of the issues by consent of the parties; and 
(9)  Take actions and make decisions or recommend decisions in conformity with this article. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 5, 2-9-94) 
Secs. 6.5-21-6.5-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CUSTOMER SERVICE STANDARDS 

Sec. 6.5-31. - Adoption. 
    The City of Mt. Pleasant (herein called "the city") has the legal authority to adopt and enforce customer service standards for the cable television system in the city as permitted by the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992. Upon review of the customer service standards adopted by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) on March 11, 1993, by MM Docket No. 92-263 of the FCC, and deeming it in the best interest of the city, the city council herewith adopts by reference the above-mentioned customer service standards for cable television service effective at least ninety (90) days from passage of this article [February 9, 1994] or date of written notification to the cable operator, whichever is later. 
(Ord. No. 894, § 1, 2-9-94) 
Sec. 6.5-32. - Notification to cable operator. 
    The city clerk shall notify the cable operator by registered mail with return receipt that the city has adopted customer service standards for cable television service to become effective at least ninety (90) days from passage of this article [February 9, 1994] or date of written notification to the cable operator, whichever is later. 
(Ord. No. 894, § 2, 2-9-94) 
Sec. 6.5-33. - Establishment of rules and regulations. 
    The cablevision committee appointed by the council [see § 2-61 et seq.] shall establish rules and regulations and procedures regarding the process to remedy possible violations of the customer service standards by the cable operator. The council or commission shall provide for notice and opportunity for hearing for both the customers and the cable operator in such process. 
(Ord. No. 894, § 3, 2-9-94) 
Sec. 6.5-34. - Repeal of conflicting ordinances. 
    All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this article are repealed to the extent of such conflict. 
(Ord. No. 894, § 4, 2-9-94) 
Sec. 6.5-35. - Severability. 
    If any section, provision or part of this article shall be adjudged invalid or unconstitutional, such adjudication shall not affect the validity of the article as a whole or any section, provision, or part thereof not adjudged invalid or unconstitutional. 
(Ord. No. 894, § 5, 2-9-94) 
Sec. 6.5-36. - Effective date. 
    This article shall be in effect at least ninety (90) days from passage of the article or date of written notification to the cable operator, whichever is later, after its final passage, approval or publication as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 894, § 6, 2-9-94) 
Sec. 6.5-37. - Reduction of rates authorized. 
    If after notice and opportunity for hearing the city determines that the cable operator is not in complete compliance with all the provisions of the customer service standards, the cable operator shall reduce the rate for the basic tier of cable service by twenty-five (25) percent until such time that the city has been satisfied that the cable operator is in compliance of all the provisions of the customer service standards. In addition, the cable operator shall pay to the city the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each day that the cable operator fails to be in compliance of all the provisions of the customer service standards after the date that the city council has passed a resolution stipulating the sections where the cable operator is in noncompliance. 
(Ord. No. 894, § 7, 2-9-94) 
Chapter 7 - CEMETERIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 875, § 1, adopted June 23, 1993, amended Ch. 7 to read as set out herein. Prior to such amendment, Ch. 7 consisted of §§ 7-1-7-18, which contained similar provisions and derived from those ordinances as are listed in the Code Comparative Table of this Code. 
Cross reference- Cemetery rates and charges, § 25-18. 
State Law reference- City cemeteries generally, I.C.A. § 566.14 et seq.; death certificates generally, I.C.A. § 144.26 et seq. 

Sec. 7-1. - Supervision. 
    Subject to the direction of the mayor and council, the park and recreation director shall have supervision and control over all city cemeteries. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93) 
Sec. 7-2. - Procedure for lot purchase. 
    Purchase of a cemetery lot shall be arranged through the cemetery attendant. Advance purchases require payment in full within thirty (30) days of the lot selection or such lot shall be subject to resale by the cemetery attendant. Immediate need purchases require payment in full on the date of selection. A completed transaction shall be documented by the issuance of a cemetery deed by the city clerk. The resale of any lot shall be prohibited, except by the written permission of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93) 
Sec. 7-3. - Rates and charges. 
    Persons desiring to purchase a lot in the city cemetery, or to open a grave, or have a foundation installed, shall pay such rates and charges as are established in chapter 25, section 25-18(a) through (f). 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93) 
Sec. 7-4. - Ownership rights. 
(a)  The lot owner has the right to use a purchased lot for burial purposes only, and such rights shall be subject to the rules and regulations of this chapter. 
(b)  Wherever reference is made elsewhere in this chapter, the term "lot owner" shall include the titleholder or his or her spouse, heirs, designees or transferees, all as described in this section. 
(c)  The ownership rights in a cemetery lot shall be for the benefit of the lot owner, or for the benefit of his or her spouse or heirs, as designated in writing to the city clerk by the lot owner. 
(d)  If the lot owner is deceased, then the surviving spouse shall have the first right of interment, or the right to designate the use of the lot for the benefit of an heir of the lot owner. Such designation shall be submitted in writing to the city clerk by the surviving spouse, if applicable. 
(e)  If the lot owner leaves no surviving spouse, then the heirs of the lot owner may determine which heir shall have the right of interment, or which heir has the authority to designate the use of the lot for the benefit of an heir of the lot owner. Such determination or designation shall be submitted in writing to the city clerk. Failure to submit a written agreement will result in the use of the lot by an heir of the lot owner in the order of need. 
(f)  If the lot owner bequeaths his or her interest in a cemetery lot by last will and testament, then a certified copy of the lot owner's last will and testament shall be delivered to the city clerk. In all other instances, the persons subject to this section shall produce satisfactory evidence of descent. 
(g)  A lot owner is prohibited from transferring his or her ownership rights in a lot to a nonfamily member. The lot owner under such circumstances may convey the unused lot to the city by way of quit claim deed, and the city shall provide reimbursement to the lot owner in an amount equal to the original purchase price of said lot. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93) 
Sec. 7-5. - Irrevocable trust funds. 
    An amount equal to forty (40) percent of the sums received from the sale of lots in cemeteries owned and controlled by the city shall be held in an irrevocable trust. The City of Mount Pleasant shall be designated as the trustee of the irrevocable trust fund for perpetual care. The perpetual care trust fund shall be exclusively for the care of the cemetery, and subject to Iowa Code Chapter 523I. Trustee shall invest and reinvest the assets of the perpetual care trust fund only in such manner and in such investments as are permitted under I.C.A. Ch. 523I, as amended, and any related rules which may now exist or which may be promulgated hereafter. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93; Ord. No. 1310, § 1, 9-9-2015) 
Sec. 7-6. - Perpetual care. 
    Perpetual care by the city shall mean the permanent care of the lots or cemetery, including mowing, raking and cleaning the grounds, pruning trees and shrubbery, and such other general upkeep. Perpetual care does not include the planting of flowers or other ornamental plants on a burial lot. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93) 
Sec. 7-7. - Grave depths. 
    Graves located in a city cemetery shall be excavated to a depth that conforms to the state board of health, or such other agency, or laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93) 
Sec. 7-8. - Authority for opening graves. 
    No person, other than the cemetery attendant, shall have the authority to direct the opening of a grave located in the city cemetery. Any person desiring such action shall give twenty-four (24) hours' notice to the cemetery attendant. The opening of the grave shall be performed by the city staff. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93) 
Sec. 7-9. - Foundations and monuments. 
(a)  The foundation for a monument shall be concrete, and shall be not less than forty (40) inches in depth for a single monument, nor less than forty-eight (48) inches in depth for a two-piece monument. The foundation shall be inspected by the cemetery attendant prior to the pouring of the concrete. Unless otherwise designated, all foundations shall have a four-inch collar around the monument, and shall be level with the surface of the ground. If this is not done, then the removal of the monument will be required for the inspection. This is to be completed at the installer's expense and at the attendant's convenience. 
(b)  Monuments, headstones, statuary or other memorials in the city cemetery shall be made of granite, marble, bronze or other material equally substantial and desirable, and shall be kept in good condition and repair by the lot owner. If not so kept, the cemetery attendant shall have the authority to repair the same, with the cost to be charged to the lot owner. 
(c)  The setting of a monument, headstone, statuary or other memorial shall require prior confirmation by the cemetery attendant. Placement shall not extend beyond the boundaries of the designated lot, nor shall placement create interference with future grave openings. The setting materials, equipment, clean-up procedure and other related procedures shall be subject to the direct supervision and approval of the cemetery attendant. 
(d)  No slab-type grave covering of any material or type shall be allowed in a city cemetery. 
(e)  A temporary marker is allowed at the time of interment, provided it is replaced with a permanent marker within twelve (12) months of interment. If a temporary marker becomes unsightly as determined by the cemetery attendant, it shall be removed by the city with the costs for the same being charged to the lot owner. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93; Ord. No. 1032, § 1, 11-24-98) 
Sec. 7-10. - Mausoleum. 
    The construction of a mausoleum requires prior permission from the council. Application shall be made in writing, and shall contain complete plans and specifications, including, but not limited to, method of construction, materials, and labor. The city shall have the right to prohibit the erection of any structure that it deems unsafe, objectionable or offensive. 
    If any mausoleum shall fall into a state of dilapidation or decay, or shall be determined by the council to be offensive or in any way injurious to the appearance of the cemetery, no adequate provision having been made by the owner for repair and preservation of such structure, the city shall have the right to remove the offensive or objectionable structure, and to inter any body contained therein, in the lot on which such structure was located, maintaining such lot thereafter in good and similar condition as done with other lots in the cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93) 
Sec. 7-11. - Burial container. 
    A burial container shall mean the underground sealable container in which a casket is placed. A sealable burial container which measures twenty (20) inches by thirty-two (32) inches or less may be constructed of rigid plastic. A sealable burial container which measures in excess of twenty (20) inches by thirty-two (32) inches shall be constructed of concrete or a minimum of twelve (12) gauge metal. Ash remains shall be placed within a vitreous clay pipe section. No interment will be permitted in wooden containers. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93; Ord. No. 1202, § 1, 5-27-2009) 
Sec. 7-12. - Supervision of laborers. 
    All laborers employed in the construction of monuments, or other markers described in this chapter, shall be subject to the control and direction of the cemetery attendant. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93) 
Sec. 7-13. - Excess materials. 
    Materials used in connection with stone or marble work shall be removed at the completion of the work. A failure to remove excess materials will result in its removal by the cemetery attendant, with the costs jointly and severally assessed to the lot owner and the contractor. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93) 
Sec. 7-14. - Funeral processions. 
    All funeral processions or other processions within the grounds of the cemetery shall be subject to the direction and control of the cemetery attendant. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93) 
Sec. 7-15. - Interment. 
(a)  No burial shall take place until arrangements have been made for the proper burial container, as described in section 7-11. The city may refuse interment when the container has not been provided within twelve (12) hours of the burial. 
(b)  The funeral director shall be responsible for the payment of the interment charges. 
(c)  Notification of a pending service shall be provided to the cemetery attendant by the funeral director, or such other responsible person, no less than twenty-four (24) hours prior to the scheduled interment. Gravesite information shall also be contained in such notice. 
(d)  If the lot owner desires to change the location of a grave to another lot owned after the opening of a grave, then the lot owner shall be required to pay for the duplicated grave opening. 
(e)  No interment of any body other than a human being will be permitted. 
(f)  A parent and infant, or twin infants, or two infants, buried at the same time may be buried in the same lot. A double depth grave is not allowed. 
(g)  Removal of a body from a grave must be done in the manner prescribed by the laws of the state. 
(h)  Interments shall not be scheduled on Sundays or city holidays unless prior permission is granted by the cemetery attendant. Interments shall be scheduled at not less than thirty-minute intervals. On weekdays, the last scheduled interment shall be at 3:00 p.m. If permission is sought for interment at a later time, then an additional fee shall be charged for such service as described in chapter 25, section 25-17(b)(7) and (c)(3). 
(i)  During inclement weather (to be determined by the attendant) it shall be mandatory to use the on-site chapel for services at the cemetery, as opposed to the graveside service. This is for the safety and well being of all parties concerned. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93; Ord. No. 1032, § 1, 11-24-98) 
Sec. 7-16. - Decorations, hedges, trees, fences, urns, etc. 
(a)  All cut flowers, plastic or silk flowers, potted plants, or other decorations will be removed by the cemetery staff when they become unsightly. 
(b)  Decorations shall not be permitted on a wooden trellis nor in glass, tin or ceramic containers, except tin or plastic containers designed for cemetery use. No temporary or permanent vase or urn which is more than one and one-half (11/2) feet tall or more than six (6) inches in diameter shall be permitted. Artificial flowers may not be placed in the ground by their stems. 
(c)  The planting of trees, shrubs or perennials shall require the prior approval of the council. Trimming and pruning requirements shall be the responsibility of the city. 
(d)  The lot owner shall be responsible for trimming the grass away from any decorations placed on the burial lot. A failure to do so will result in removal of the decoration by the cemetery staff. 
(e)  A clean-up of the cemetery will take place in the months of April and October. Notice of the clean-up shall be published in the newspaper of general circulation, and signs shall be posted at the main gates of the cemetery. All decorations, except permanent plantings or decorations affixed to monuments, shall be removed by the lot owner prior to the clean-up. A failure to remove shall result in the disposal of the decoration. Subsequent to the clean-up, the lot owner may place new decorations on the burial lot. Shepherd hooks must be removed from the burial lot from November 1 to May 1 of each respective year. 
(f)  Shepard hooks will no longer be stored at the cemetery maintenance facility. It shall be the owner's responsibility to store their own hook(s). Any hook left at the grave site after the removal date will become property of the city and will be disposed of. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93; Ord. No. 1032, § 1, 11-24-98) 
Sec. 7-17. - Visitors hours. 
    Visitors shall be allowed access to the city cemeteries during daylight hours. The cemetery office will be open from 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. on Monday through Friday, and Saturday and evenings by arrangement. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93) 
Sec. 7-18. - Injuring property. 
    No person shall injure, deface or destroy any grave, vault, building, fence or other property located in a city cemetery without the permission of the cemetery attendant. No person shall injure, destroy or steal any tree, shrub, flower or plant in any city cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93) 
Sec. 7-19. - Prohibited travel. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or drive any vehicle, bicycle or animal in the city cemetery except on designated roads, walks and paths, or to park on the grass. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93) 
Sec. 7-20. - Errors and liability. 
    The city reserves and shall have the right to correct any errors that may be made in making either interments, disinterments, or removals, or in the description, transfer or conveyance of any interment property, either by cancelling such conveyance and substituting and conveying in lieu thereof other interment property of equal value and similar location as far as possible, or as may be selected by the city or in the sole discretion of the city, by refunding the amount of money paid on account of such purchase. In the event such error shall involve the interment of the remains of any person in such property, the city reserves the right to remove and transfer such remains to such other property of equal value and similar location as far as reasonably possible, which may be substituted and conveyed in lieu thereof. 
    The city shall take reasonable precautions to protect lot owners and the property rights of lot owners within the cemetery from loss or damage including, but not limited to, loss or damage to a monument, headstone, statuary or other memorial, but it expressly shall not be liable for loss or damage beyond its control, and, particularly, from damage caused by the elements, an act of God, common enemy, thieves, vandals, strikers, malicious mischief makers, explosions, or unavoidable civil disorder, whether the damage be direct or consequential. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 6-23-93) 
Chapter 7.1 - CURFEW FOR MINORS 

Sec. 7.1-1. - Purpose. 
    A curfew for minors is necessary to promote the public health, safety, morals and general welfare of the residents of the city, and is enacted specifically to achieve the following purposes: 
(1)  Reinforce the primary authority and responsibility of adults responsible for minors; 
(2)  Protect the public from illegal acts committed by minors and; 
(3)  Protect minors from improper influences and criminal activity during certain hours. 
(Ord. No. 925, § 1, 2-22-95) 
Sec. 7.1-2. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall mean as indicated below: 
    Emergency errand means, but is not limited to, an errand relating to a fire, a natural disaster, an automobile accident, or any other situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious illness, bodily injury or loss of life. 
    Knowingly means knowledge which a responsible adult should reasonably be expected to have concerning the whereabouts of a minor in that responsible adult's custody. It is intended to continue to hold the neglectful or careless adult responsible for a minor to a reasonable community standard of adult responsibility through an objective test. It shall, therefore, be no defense that an adult responsible for a minor was completely indifferent to the activities or conduct or whereabouts of the minor. 
    Minor means any unemancipated person under the age of eighteen (18) years. 
    Nonsecured custody means custody in an unlocked area, such as a lobby, office or interrogation room which is not designed, set aside or used as a secured detention area, and the person arrested is not physically secured during the period of custody in the area; the person is physically accompanied by a peace officer or person employed by the facility where the person arrested is being held; and the use of the area is limited to providing nonsecure custody only while awaiting transfer to an appropriate juvenile facility or to court, for contacting of and release of the person's parents, or other responsible adult, or for other administrative purposes; but not for longer than six (6) hours without the oral or written order of a judge or magistrate authorizing the detention. 
    Public place shall include the city square, shopping centers, parking lots, parks, playgrounds, streets, alleys, sidewalks, dedicated to public use; and shall also include such parts of buildings and other premises whether publicly or privately owned which are used by the general public or to which the general public is permitted without specific invitation, or to which the general public has access. 
    Responsible adult means a parent, guardian or other adult specifically authorized by law, or authorized by a parent or guardian to have custody or control of a minor. 
    Unemancipated means unmarried and still under custody or control of a responsible adult. 
(Ord. No. 925, § 1, 2-22-95) 
Sec. 7.1-3. - Curfew established. 
    (a) No minor fifteen (15) years of age of younger shall be in any public place during the following time: 
(1)  Sunday-Thursday 
10:00 p.m.-5:00 a.m. each day 
(2)  Friday-Saturday 
11:00 p.m.-5:00 a.m. each day 
    (b) No minor sixteen (16) through seventeen (17) years of age shall be in any public place during the following times: 
(1)  Sunday-Thursday 
11:00 p.m.-5:00 a.m. each day 
(2)  Friday-Saturday 
Midnight-5:00 a. m. each day 
(Ord. No. 925, § 1, 2-22-95) 
Sec. 7.1-4. - Exceptions. 
    The following are exceptions to the curfew: 
(1)  The minor is accompanied by a responsible adult. 
(2)  When the minor is on the sidewalk or property where the minor resides, or on either side of the place where the minor resides and the adult responsible for the minor has given permission for the minor to be there. 
(3)  The minor is present or is travelling between home and one of the following: 
a.  Minor's place of employment, trade or occupation, in which the minor is permitted by law to be engaged; or, if traveling, within one (1) hour after the end of work. 
b.  Minor's place of religious activity; or, if traveling, within one (1) hour after the end of the religious activity. 
c.  Governmental or political activity; or, if traveling, within one (1) hour after the end of the activity. 
d.  School activity; or, if traveling, within one (1) hour after the activity. 
e.  Assembly such as a march, protest, demonstration, sit-in; or meeting of an association for advancement of economic, political, religious or cultural matters; or for any other activity protected by the First Amendment of the U. S. Constitution guarantees of free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, freedom of assembly. If traveling, within one (1) hour of after the end of the activity. 
f.  The minor is on an emergency errand for a responsible adult. 
(Ord. No. 925, § 1, 2-22-95) 
Sec. 7.1-5. - Responsibility of adults. 
    It is unlawful for an responsible adult knowingly to permit or allow a minor to be in any public place in the city within the time periods prohibited by this chapter, unless the minor's presence falls within one of the exceptions set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 925, § 1, 2-22-95) 
Sec. 7.1-6. - Enforcement procedures. 
    (a)  Determination of age. In determining the age of the juvenile and in the absence of convincing evidence such as birth certificate or driver's license, a police officer shall, in the first instance, use his or her best judgement in determining age. 
    (b)  Grounds for arrest. The following shall constitute grounds for arrest: 
(1)  Refusal to sign the citation without qualification; 
(2)  Two (2) or more violations of the curfew ordinance; 
(3)  Refusal to provide proper identification; 
(4)  An individual engaged in action that constitutes an immediate threat to the person's own safety or the safety of the public. 
    (c)  Conditions of custody. A law enforcement officer who arrests a minor for a curfew violation may keep the minor in custody either in a shelter care facility or in any nonsecured setting. The officer shall not place bodily restraints, such as handcuffs, on the minor unless the minor physically resists or threatens physical violence when being taken into custody. A minor shall not be placed in detention following a curfew violation. 
    (d)  Notification of responsible adult. After a minor is taken into custody, the law enforcement officer shall notify the adult responsible for the minor as soon as possible. The minor shall be released to the adult responsible for the minor upon the promise of such persons to produce the child in court at such time as the court may direct. 
    (e)  Minor without adult supervision. If a peace officer determines that a minor does not have adult supervision because the peace officer cannot locate the minor's parent, guardian or other person legally responsible for the care of the minor within a reasonable period of time, the peace officer shall attempt to place the minor with an adult relative of the minor, an adult person who cares for the child, or another adult person who is known to the child. 
(Ord. No. 925, § 1, 2-22-95) 
Sec. 7.1-7. - Penalties. 
    (a)  Responsible adult's first violation-warning. In the case of a first violation by a minor, the police department shall send the adult responsible for the minor a written notice of the violation by certified mail, with a warning that any subsequent violation will result in full enforcement of the curfew ordinance against both the responsible adult and minor. 
    (b)  Responsible adult's second violation-simple misdemeanor. Any responsible adult as defined in this chapter who, following receipt of a warning, knowingly allows the minor to violate any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a simple misdemeanor, and upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisonment not to exceed thirty (30) days. 
    (c)  Minor's first violation-warning. In the case of a first violation by a minor, the police shall give the minor a written warning, which states that any subsequent violation will result in full enforcement of the curfew ordinance against the responsible adult and the minor. 
    (d)  Minor's second violation-simple misdemeanor. For the minor's second and subsequent violations of any of the provisions of this chapter, the minor shall be guilty of simple misdemeanor. Upon conviction, the person shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) of to perform community service as ordered by the court. 
(Ord. No. 925, § 1, 2-22-95) 
Chapter 8 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; fire zones, § 6-1; permit fees under Uniform Fire Code, § 25-19; fire protection in mobile home parks, App. C, § 36. 
State Law reference- Municipal fire protection, I.C.A. § 364.16. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Former Art. I, §§ 8-1 and 8-2, pertained to bonfires and storage of flammable liquids, respectively, was repealed by § 1 of Ord. No. 778, adopted May 9, 1990, and originated from the 1969 Code, § 4.12.010; and Ord. No. 511, adopted Aug. 1, 1979; also, § 1, of Ord. No. 778 added a new Art. I, §§ 8-1-8-11, to read as herein set out. 
Cross reference- Building and zoning administrator, § 6-201; police department, Ch. 18; zoning, App. D; M-3 heavy industrial district regulations, App. D, Ch. 19.42. 

Sec. 8-1. - Adoption of the Uniform Fire Code. 
    There is hereby adopted by the city for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion that certain code known as the Uniform Fire Code, recommended by the Western Fire Chiefs Association and the International Conference of Building Officials, being particularly the 1988 Edition thereof, and the whole thereof, including Appendices I-A through VI-D inclusive, save and except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified or amended by section 8-7 herein. Henceforth, any modifications and future editions of the Uniform Fire Code shall be automatically adopted upon the publication of such by the International Conference of Building Officials and the Western Fire Chiefs Association. 
(Ord. No. 778, § 1, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 8-2. - Establishment and duties of bureau of fire prevention. 
(a)  The Uniform Fire Code shall be enforced by the Bureau of Fire Prevention in the Fire Department of the city which is hereby established and which shall be operated under the supervision of the chief of the fire department. 
(b)  The chief in charge of the bureau of fire prevention shall be appointed by the fire chief of the city on the basis of examination to determine his or her qualifications. 
(c)  The chief of the fire department may detail such members of the fire department as inspectors as shall from time to time be necessary. The chief of the fire department shall recommend to the city council the employment of technical inspectors who, when such authorization is made, shall be selected through an examination to determine their fitness for the position. The examination shall be open to members and nonmembers of the fire department, and appointments made after examination shall be for an indefinite term with removal only by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 778, § 1, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 8-3. - Definitions. 
(a)  Wherever the words chief of the bureau of fire prevention are used, they shall be held to include fire marshal. 
(b)  Wherever the term corporation counsel is used in the Uniform Fire Code, it shall be held to mean the city attorney. 
(c)  Wherever the word jurisdiction is used in the Uniform Fire Code, it shall be held to mean the city. 
(d)  Wherever the words false alarm appears, it means the activation of fire alarm system through technical failure, malfunction, improper installation, or the negligence of the owner or lessee of an alarm system or of his or her employees or agents. A false alarm under this division does not include alarm system failures caused by water, gas, electrical, telephone or other transmission lines or devices not under control of an alarm user or his or her agent; and does not include failures due to conditions clearly beyond the control of the alarm user or his or her agents, servants or employees. False fire alarm includes alarms which activate a signal to which the fire department responds with equipment and personnel without regard to whether the alarm is connected to any receiving alarm station. False alarm includes the willful use of an alarm system for purposes other than warning or notification of a fire. A false alarm does not include any activation of an alarm which is caused by storms, tornadoes or other violent weather conditions. 
(Ord. No. 778, § 1, 5-9-90; Ord. No. 1328, § 1(1), 5-10-2017) 
Sec. 8-4. - Establishment of limits of districts-For storage of flammable or combustible liquids in outside aboveground tanks. 
(a)  The limits referred to in Sections 79.401 and 79.501 of the Uniform Fire Code in which storage of flammable or combustible liquids in outside aboveground tanks is prohibited are hereby established as follows: Such storage shall be allowed only in areas zoned M-3, Heavy Industrial Districts, as provided by the city zoning ordinance and, then, only when such storage would pose no hazard to nearby persons and residential or business property and where topography and available water supply are conducive to adequate fire protection. 
(b)  The limits referred to in Section 79.601 of the Uniform Fire Code in which new bulk plants for flammable or combustible liquids are prohibited are hereby established as follows: Such bulk plans shall be allowed only in areas zoned M-3, Heavy Industrial Districts, as provided by the city zoning ordinance and, then, only when such establishment would pose no hazard to nearby persons and residential or business property and where topography and available water supply are conducive to adequate fire protection. 
(Ord. No. 778, § 1, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 8-5. - Same-For bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gases. 
    The limits referred to in Article 82 of the Uniform Fire Code in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted are hereby established as follows: Such storage shall be allowed only in areas zoned M-3, Heavy Industrial Districts, as provided by the city zoning ordinance and, then, only when such storage would pose no hazard to nearby persons and residential or business property and where topography and available water supply are conducive to adequate fire protection. 
(Ord. No. 778, § 1, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 8-6. - Same-For storage of explosives and blasting agents. 
    The limits referred to in Section 77.106(b) of the Uniform Fire Code in which storage of explosives and blasting agents is prohibited are hereby established as follows: Such storage shall be allowed only in areas zoned M-3, Heavy Industrial Districts, as provided by the city zoning ordinance and, then, only when such storage would pose no hazard to nearby persons and residential or business property and where topography and available water supply are conducive to adequate fire protection. 
(Ord. No. 778, § 1, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 8-7. - Amendments to the Uniform Fire Code. 
(a)  Sections 2.101 and 2.102 are amended to add the city administrator, fire chief and building and zoning administrator. 
(b)  Sections 4.108 and 11.101 are amended to specifically exclude the burning of leaves from the necessity for a permit. 
(c)  Fire lanes. 
(1)  The establishment of fire lanes on private property devoted to public use shall be the responsibility of the planning and zoning commission, the chief of the fire department and the chief of police, subject to the approval of the city council. 
(2)  No person shall park a vehicle or permit it to stand unattended in an official fire lane, either on public or private property, when the area has been designated as an official fire lane pursuant to this code. 
(3)  The chief of police and all city peace officers are authorized to enforce the no-parking regulations designated herein by the issuance [of] a citation to the operator or owner of said vehicle (which may be affixed to the vehicle) or, in the event the parked or stopped vehicle constitutes a fire hazard of an emergency nature, to provide for the removal of such vehicle; the chief of police, authorized members of the police department and the city shall not be liable for damages occasioned by reason of the removal or towing of the vehicle. 
(4)  Any person violating the no-parking regulations provided in subsection (3) of this section, shall upon conviction, be subject to a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. No. 778, § 1, 5-9-90; Ord. No. 1279, § 1, 3-26-2014) 
Sec. 8-8. - Permits issued. 
    Any permits required to be issued under the terms and conditions of this section shall be issued by the city clerk upon approval of the chief of the fire department. The fee for the issuance of any permit shall be in the amount established in Section 25-19. 
(Ord. No. 778, § 1, 5-9-90; Ord. No. 846, § 1, 11-11-92) 
Sec. 8-9. - Appeals. 
    Whenever the chief shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for or when it is claimed that the provisions of the fire code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the fire code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the chief to the city council within thirty (30) days of the date of the decision. Appeals shall be conducted in accordance with the procedure set forth in the Mt. Pleasant Administrative Code (chapter 2, article VIII). 
(Ord. No. 778, § 1, 5-9-90; Ord. No. 949, § 1, 1-10-96) 
Sec. 8-10. - New materials, processes or occupancies requiring permits. 
    The zoning board of adjustment, the chief of the fire department and the chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies which shall require permits, in addition to those enumerated in the fire code. The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall post such list in a conspicuous place in his office and distribute copies thereof to interested persons. 
(Ord. No. 778, § 1, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 8-11. - Violation; penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the fire code hereby adopted or fail to comply therewith or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder or any certificate or permit issued thereunder and from which no appeal has been taken or who shall fail to comply with such order as affirmed or modified by the city council or by a court of competent jurisdiction within the time fixed herein shall severally, for each and every violation and noncompliance respectively, be guilty of a simple misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or by imprisonment of not more than thirty (30) days. The imposition of one (1) penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time; and, when not otherwise specified, each day that a prohibited condition is maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited [materials.] 
(c)  Penalties for false fire alarms. 
(1)  The fire department is authorized to impose a municipal infraction upon fire alarm users who have two (2) or more false alarms per calendar year. The municipal [infraction] for each false fire alarm shall be as provided in the schedule of fines for municipal infractions, section 25-24(c). Notice of violation, with the applicable penalty for such violation noted thereon, shall be issued by the fire chief or the chief's authorized representative to the violator. Fines shall be paid in full within thirty (30) days of the issuance of the notice at the city clerk's office. 
(2)  The fine set out in the schedule for fines for municipal infractions in section 25-24(c) shall be charged in lieu of the fines and penalties provided for in section 1-8.1, unless the violator refuses to correct the violation and pay the scheduled fine, or the fire chief or the chief's authorized representative determines that immediate enforcement action by misdemeanor or municipal infraction prosecution pursuant to section 1-8.1 is, in view of the particular circumstances of the case, necessary to achieve compliance with the requirements of this article. The fire department shall maintain a record of all violations, administrative penalties charged or other enforcement actions taken. 
(Ord. No. 778, § 1, 5-9-90; Ord. No. 1328, § 1(2), 5-10-2017) 
Secs. 8-12-8-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Fire departments authorized, I.C.A. § 364.16; fire companies, I.C.A. § 102.1. 

Sec. 8-16. - Generally. 
    There is hereby established a fire department which shall have such size and composition as may be provided by the council. 
(Code 1969, § 2.40.010) 
Sec. 8-17. - Chief and other official positions. 
    The fire chief shall be the commanding officer of the fire department, and shall be in charge of the general affairs of the department. The other official positions of the fire department shall be the assistant fire chief, the deputy fire chief, the fire captain and the fire lieutenant. The duties of each official shall be defined in the policy manual of file in the city clerk's office. Wherever it is applicable, the ranking of the positions shall be determined by the order described in this section. 
(Code 1969, § 2.40.020;, Ord. No. 793, § 1, 2-13-91) 
Cross reference- Fire chief, § 2-18. 
Sec. 8-18. - Compensation. 
    The officers and members of the fire department shall be compensated for attending meetings, and for their service on fire calls in the city, in an amount to be determined by resolution of the council. 
(Code 1969, § 2.40.050) 
Sec. 8-19. - Budget and records. 
    The fire chief shall prepare an annual budget, and keep records for the maintenance of fire-fighting equipment in good condition, and other expenses incurred in operating the fire department, and he shall keep the council informed as to the conditions and needs of the fire department. 
(Code 1969, § 2.40.060) 
Sec. 8-20. - Equipment, personnel and housing agreement. 
    The fire chief may make recommendations as to the agreement existing between the city and the Mount Pleasant Benefited Fire District, for the sharing of equipment, personnel and housing of the department and as the chief administrative officer, he shall be responsible for executing the provisions of such agreement in a manner to insure the continuity of the department and to provide the best fire protection and fire-fighting service available in the city whenever the same is required. 
(Code 1969, § 2.40.070) 
Sec. 8-21. - Fires outside city. 
    The fire chief may authorize or dispatch fire equipment or personnel outside the corporate limits for the purpose of fighting fires and giving other emergency assistance when the chief determines that such action will save life or property and not be prejudicial to the safety and general welfare of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 2.40.110) 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate fire calls outside city limits, I.C.A. § 364.16. 
Secs. 8-22-8-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE FIGHTER RESERVE 

Sec. 8-31. - Establishment and purpose. 
    A fire fighter reserve is hereby established to assist the Mt. Pleasant, Iowa, Fire Department in all its activities and functions including the prevention and control of fires. The reserves shall be known as the Mt. Pleasant Fire Fighter Reserves. 
(Ord. No. 625, § 1, 9-5-84) 
Sec. 8-32. - Members of the fire fighter reserve. 
    Ten (10) residents of the City of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa, between the ages of eighteen (18) and sixty-five (65) shall be appointed to serve on the reserve by the fire chief of the City of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa, subject to the approval of the city council of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa. 
(Ord. No. 625, § 2, 9-5-84) 
Sec. 8-33. - Personal standards. 
    The members of the Mt. Pleasant Fire Fighter Reserve shall be subject to the minimum standards of physical, educational, mental and moral fitness and shall be established by the City of Mt. Pleasant. Additionally, the members of the Mt. Pleasant Fire Fighter Reserve shall be subject to the rules and regulations as set forth by the fire chief with the approval of the Mt. Pleasant City Council. 
(Ord. No. 625, § 3, 9-5-84) 
Sec. 8-34. - Standards and training. 
    All members of the Mt. Pleasant Fire Fighter Reserve shall meet minimum standards as required by state law and as implemented by the fire chief for the City of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa. Further, all members of the Mt. Pleasant Fire Fighter Reserve shall have received the minimum training and instruction as required by state law and as implemented by the fire chief for the City of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa. 
(Ord. No. 625, § 4, 9-5-84) 
Sec. 8-35. - Status of reserve officers. 
    Members of the Mt. Pleasant Fire Fighters Reserve shall serve as firemen on the orders and at the discretion of the fire chief of the City of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa. While in the actual performance of official duties, members of the Mt. Pleasant Fire Fighter Reserve shall be vested with the same rights, privileges, obligations and duties as any other firemen of the City of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa. 
(Ord. No. 625, § 5, 9-5-84) 
Sec. 8-36. - Supplementary capacity. 
    Members of the Mt. Pleasant Fire Fighter Reserve shall act only in a supplementary capacity to the regular fire department for the City of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa, and shall not assume full-time duties of a regular fireman without first complying with all requirements for full-time firemen. 
(Ord. No. 625, § 6, 9-5-84) 
Sec. 8-37. - No reduction of the fire department. 
    The City of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa, shall not reduce the authorized number of members of full-time firemen for the Mt. Pleasant Fire Department because of the establishment and utilization of the Mt. Pleasant Fire Fighter Reserve. 
(Ord. No. 625, § 7, 9-5-84) 
Sec. 8-38. - Fire fighter reserve compensation. 
    While performing official duties, each member of the Mt. Pleasant Fire Fighter Reserve shall be considered an employee of the City of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa, and shall be paid (a minimum of one dollar ($1.00) per year). 
(Ord. No. 625, § 8, 9-5-84) 
Sec. 8-39. - Removal and suspension. 
    A member of the Mt. Pleasant Fire Fighter Reserve may be removed or suspended by the fire chief or the mayor of the City of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa, for violation of departmental rules or regulations. Such member shall have a right to appeal such decision to the city council in accordance with the procedures set forth in the Mt. Pleasant Administrative Code (chapter 2, article VIII). 
(Ord. No. 625, § 8, 9-5-84; Ord. No. 949, § 1, 1-10-96) 
Sec. 8-40. - Workers' compensation. 
    The city council of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa, shall contract to insure the city against liability for the workers' compensation as required by the laws of the State of Iowa for members of the Mt. Pleasant Fire Fighter Reserve injured in the course of performing their official duties. 
(Ord. No. 625, § 10, 9-5-84) 
Sec. 8-41. - No participation in a pension fund or retirement system. 
    This article shall not be construed to authorize or permit a member of the Mt. Pleasant Fire Fighter Reserve to become eligible for participation in a pension fund or retirement system created by the laws of the State of Iowa wherein a regular fireman for the City of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa, may become a member. 
(Ord. No. 625, § 11, 9-5-84) 
Secs. 8-42-8-44. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SELF-INSPECTION PROGRAM[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Zoning, App. D 

Sec. 8-45. - Establishment. 
    The city hereby establishes a self-inspection program for the purpose of providing and maintaining functions necessary for the prevention of fire and for the protection of life and property from fire and panic. In order to ensure that certain occupancies within the city are inspected on an annual basis for fire and human safety, the following program set out in this article will be adopted. 
(Ord. No. 777, § 1, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 8-46. - Definition. 
    Occupancies, as used in this article, means those permitted uses or special uses allowed in the zoning districts as follows: B-2 (Central Business District Commercial District), B-3 (General Retial and Service Commercial District), B-4 (Highway Service Commercial District), M-1 (Limited Industrial Districts), M-2 (Light Industrial Districts), and M-3 (Heavy Industrial Districts). 
(Ord. No. 777, § 1, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 8-47. - Function. 
(a)  The city volunteer fire department shall annually deliver, by hand or by mail, its most current self-inspection worksheet and business and emergency record forms to each occupancy within city limits. 
(b)  The owner or manager or said occupancy or person in highest authority in the occupancy must return the self-inspection worksheet within thirty (30) days after the date of issuance. 
(Ord. No. 777, § 1, 5-9-90) 
Sec. 8-48. - Compliance. 
    The owner, manager, occupant or other duly authorized person in possession of the premises must answer the questions within the self-inspection worksheet honestly and correct the deficiency noted in the occupancies within the time limits granted. Any person who fails to comply with these requirements shall be guilty of a simple misdemeanor, and any peace officer may cause to be issued a citation for violation of the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 777, § 1, 5-9-90) 
Chapter 9 - HOUSING CODE[1]

(Code 1969, § 15.16.010) 
State Law reference- Power of city to adopt nationally recognized code by reference, I.C.A. § 380.10.

Sec. 9-3. - Violations.

Chapter 9.1 - HUMAN RESOURCES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 9.1-1-9.1-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION 

Sec. 9.1-16. - Appointment and terms. 
    The Mt. Pleasant Human Rights Commission shall consist of the following three (3) members appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. The members shall chose a chairperson. One (1) of the first members shall serve one (1) year; one of the first members shall serve two (2) years; and one of the first members shall serve three (3) years. Members therefor appointed or re-appointed shall serve for three (3) years, and thereafter until their successor has been appointed and qualified. 
(Ord. No. 510, § 1, 8-1-79; Ord. No. 942, § 1, 9-27-95) 
Sec. 9.1-17. - Compensation and expenses. 
    The members of the human rights commission shall serve without compensation. The commission members may, however, receive actual and necessary expenses incurred which are within limits established in the city budget. 
(Ord. No. 510, § 2, 8-1-79) 
Sec. 9.1-18. - Duties and functions. 
    The human rights commission has the following duties and functions: 
(1)  To research, investigate and study the existence, character, causes and the extent of discrimination in public accommodations, employment, apprenticeships, on-the-job training programs, vocational schools and housing in this city and to attempt the elimination of such discrimination by education and conciliation. 
(2)  To issue such publications and reports of investigations and research as in the judgment of the commission tends to promote good will among the various racial, religious and ethnic groups of the city and which tends to minimize or eliminate discrimination in public accommodations, employment apprenticeship and on-the-job training programs, vocational schools or housing because of race, creed, color, national origin, sex, religion or ancestry. 
(3)  To prepare and transmit to the mayor and council from time to time, but not less than once each year, reports describing its proceedings, investigations, hearings conducted and the outcome thereof, decisions rendered and other work performed by the Commission. 
(4)  To make such recommendations to the mayor and council for such further ordinances concerning discrimination because of race, creed, color, sex, national origin, religion or ancestry as it deems necessary and advisable. 
(5)  To cooperate with other agencies or organizations, both public and private, whose purposes are not inconsistent with those of this Chapter, and in the planning and conducting of programs designed to eliminate racial, religious, cultural and intergroup tensions. 
(6)  To conduct its duties and functions in the spirit of, and in accord with, all Federal and State Legislation pertaining to the elimination of discrimination in public accommodations, employment, apprenticeship and on-the-job training programs, vocational schools and housing because of race, creed, color, sex, national origin, religion or ancestry. 
(Ord. No. 510, § 3, 8-1-79) 
Sec. 9.1-19. - Cooperation with other agencies. 
    The human rights commission shall cooperate with the Iowa State Civil Rights Commission, the United States Civil Rights Commission, the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and all other agencies with purposes consistent with the objectives of this commission. 
(Ord. No. 510, § 4, 8-1-79) 
Chapter 10 - LICENSES, PERMITS AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1]

Chapter 11 - LITTER[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Solid waste, Ch. 21. 
State Law reference- Municipal home rule powers, I.C.A. § 361.1 et seq. 

Sec. 11-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Aircraft: Any contrivance now known or hereafter invented, used or designed for navigation or for flight in the air, including helicopters and lighter-than-air dirigibles and balloons. 
    Authorized private receptacles: A litter storage and collection receptacle installed and placed by the authority of the director of public works and bearing a label indicating its authorization and control by the city. 
    Commercial handbill: Any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature: 
(a)  Which advertises for sale any merchandise, product, commodity or thing. 
(b)  Which directs attention to any business or mercantile or commercial establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or indirectly promoting the interest thereof by sales. 
(c)  Which directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition or event of any kind, for which an admission fee is charged for the purpose of private gain or profit; this shall not apply where an admission fee is charged or a collection is taken up for the purpose of defraying the expenses incident to such meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition or event of any kind, when either of the same is held, given or takes place in connection with the dissemination of information which is not restricted under the ordinary rules of decency, good morals, public peace, safety and good order; provided, that nothing contained in this clause shall be deemed to authorize the holding, giving or taking place of any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition or event of any kind, without a license, where such license is or may be required by law. 
(d)  Which, while containing reading matter other than advertising matter, is predominantly and essentially an advertisement, and is distributed or circulated for advertising purposes, or for the private benefit and gain of any person so engaged as advertiser or distributor. 
    Garbage: Putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Litter: Garbage, refuse, rubbish, cigarette and cigar butts, and all other waste material which, if thrown or deposited as prohibited in this chapter, tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare. 
    Newspaper: Any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law, any newspaper duly entered with the Post Office Department of the United States, in accordance with federal statute or regulation, and any newspaper filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law; and, in addition thereto, shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four (4) issues per year, and sold to the public. 
    Noncommercial handbill: Any printed or written matter, any sample, or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper, booklet or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature not included in the definitions of a commercial handbill or newspaper. 
    Park: A park, reservation, playground, recreation center or any other public area owned or used by the city and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
    Private premises: Any dwelling, house, building or other structure designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building or other structure. 
    Public place: Any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways; and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds and buildings; and any and all public school buildings and grounds. 
    Refuse: All putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except body wastes), including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles and solid market and industrial wastes. 
    Rubbish: Nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials. 
    Vehicle: Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Ord. No. 1197, § 1, 12-29-2008) 
Sec. 11-2. - Littering public places. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place, drain, sewer or receiving basin except in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or in any drain, sewer or receiving basin. 
Sec. 11-3. - Sweeping into public places; duty to keep sidewalk clean. 
    No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk in front of their premises free of litter. 
Sec. 11-4. - Merchants to keep sidewalks, public places free of litter. 
    No person owning or occupying a place of business shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying places of business shall keep the sidewalk in front of their business premises free of litter. 
Sec. 11-5. - Throwing litter from vehicles. 
    No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit litter upon any street or other public place. 
Sec. 11-6. - Vehicles causing litter. 
    No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any load or contents of litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley or other public place. Nor shall any person drive or move any vehicle or truck the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any street, alley or other public place, mud, dirt, sticky substances or foreign matter of any kind. 
Sec. 11-7. - Litter in parks. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any park except in public receptacles and in such manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the park or upon any street or other public place. Where public receptacles are not provided all such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere. 
Sec. 11-8. - Littering fountains, bodies of water. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any fountain, pond or any other body of water in a park or elsewhere in the city. 
Sec. 11-9. - Throwing, distributing commercial handbills in public places. 
    No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any sidewalk, street or other public place. Nor shall any person hand out or distribute or sell any commercial handbill in any public place; provided, however, that it shall not be unlawful on any sidewalk, street or other public place for any person to hand out or distribute, without charge to the receiver thereof, any noncommercial handbill to any person willing to accept it. 
Sec. 11-10. - Placing handbills on or in vehicles. 
    No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any vehicle; provided, however, that it shall not be unlawful for any person to hand out or distribute in any public place, without charge to the receiver thereof, a noncommercial handbill to any occupant of a vehicle who is willing to accept it. 
Sec. 11-11. - Depositing handbills on uninhabited premises. 
    No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any private premises which are temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant. 
Sec. 11-12. - Distributing handbills where prohibited. 
    No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any commercial or noncommercial handbill upon any private premises, if requested by anyone thereon not to do so, or if there is placed on said premises in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof, a sign bearing the words: "No Peddlers, Agents or Advertisements Allowed," or any similar notice, indicating that the occupants of said premises desire not to have any such handbills left upon such premises. 
Sec. 11-13. - Distributing handbills at inhabited private residences. 
(a)  No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon private premises which are inhabited, except by handing or transmitting any such handbill directly to the owner, occupant or other person when present in or upon such private premises; provided, however, that in case of inhabited private premises which are posted, as provided in this chapter, such person, unless requested by anyone upon such premises not to do so, shall have the authority to place or deposit any such handbill in or upon inhabited private premises, if such handbill is so placed or deposited as to secure or prevent such handbill from being blown or drifted about such premises or sidewalks, streets or other public places, and except that mailboxes may not be used when so prohibited by law. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the distribution of mail by the United States nor to newspapers. 
Sec. 11-14. - Dropping litter from aircraft. 
    No person in an aircraft shall throw out, drop or deposit any litter, handbill or any other object. 
Sec. 11-15. - Posting notices. 
    No person shall post or affix any notice, poster or other paper or device, calculated to attract the attention of the public, to any lamppost, public utility pole or shade tree, or upon any public structure or building, except as may be authorized or required by law. 
Sec. 11-16. - Litter on occupied private property. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any occupied private property whether owned by such person or not, except that the owner or person in control of private property may maintain authorized private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon any private property. 
Sec. 11-17. - Duty to maintain premises free of litter. 
    The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter; provided, however, this section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for collection. 
Sec. 11-18. - Litter on vacant lots. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private property whether owned by such person or not. 
Sec. 11-19. - Mowing adjacent to public streets. 
    No person shall operate mowing equipment adjacent to a public street, in such a manner as to cause the discharge of grass clippings, vegetative material or other litter, to be disbursed or remain in the public street. 
(Ord. No. 968, § 1, 1-8-97) 
Chapter 12 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Transportation of alcoholic beverages in vehicles, § 3-5; vehicles and bicycles only in designated areas in the city cemetery, § 7-9; vehicles in parks, § 15-3; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 22; blocking railroad crossings, § 22-4; parades, § 22-59 et seq.; visual obstructions, § 22-83 et seq. 
State Law reference- Traffic generally, I.C.A. Ch. 321. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Business district. 
    The Business district of the city shall be as follows: 
    Beginning at the northeast corner of the intersection of Maddison and Harrison Streets, thence southerly along the east side of Harrison Street to the southeast corner of the intersection of Harrison and Clay Streets, thence westerly along the south side of Clay Street to the southeast corner of the intersection of Clay and Adams Streets, thence southerly along the east side of Adams Street to the southeast corner of the intersection of Adams and Warren Streets, thence westerly along the south side of Warren Street to the southwest corner of the intersection of Warren and Jackson Streets, thence northerly along the west side of Jackson Street to the southwest corner of the intersection of Jackson and Clay Streets, thence westerly along the south side of Clay Street to the southwest corner of the intersection of Clay and White Streets, thence northerly along the west side of White Street to the northwest corner of the intersection of White and Madison Streets, thence easterly along the north line of Madison Street to the northwest corner of the intersection of Madison and Jackson Streets, thence northerly along the west line of Jackson Street, to the northwest corner of the intersection of Jackson and Henry Streets, thence easterly along the north line of Henry Street to the northeast corner of the intersection of Henry and Adams Streets, thence southerly along the east side of Adams Street to the northeast corner of the intersection of Adams and Madison Streets, thence easterly along the north side of Madison Street to the place of beginning, and all included streets, highways, alleys and intersections. 
(Code 1969, § 8.04.030) 
Sec. 12-1.1. - U-turns and other similar traffic maneuvers, prohibited in the business district. 
    Within the business district described in section 12-1 herein, no person shall drive in such a manner as to cause their vehicle to cross the opposing lane of traffic while pulling into or out of a parking space, nor shall any person execute a turn within the roadway which results in the vehicle reversing directions, the same being more commonly referred to as a U-turn. 
(Ord. No. 869, § 1, 5-26-93) 
Sec. 12-2. - Statutes adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted by reference the provisions of Chapter 321 and 321L of the Iowa Code as amended. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of said chapters. 
    For the purpose of prosecuting these violations, a violation of the chapter shall be cited by Chapter 12-2 followed by the specific subsection number of the state code Chapter 321 or 321L. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1, 11-26-2002) 
Sec. 12-3. - Arterial road designated. 
    Washington Street is designated as a four-lane arterial highway from the intersection with U.S. Highway No. 218, thence west through the city to the western city limits in the vicinity of the Iris Motel. 
(Code 1969, § 8.12.100; Ord. No. 971, § 1, 1-8-97) 
Sec. 12-4. - Speed limits. 
    No person shall operate a motor vehicle in any of the following areas in excess of the speed indicated below: 
Ten (10) miles per hour: 
In any alley; an "alley" is hereby defined as a public way within a block generally giving access to the rear of lots or buildings, and not used for general traffic circulation. 
Twenty (20) miles per hour: 
    South Locust Street from Warren Street to Garfield Street. 
    East Webster Street from Harrison Street to Walnut Street. 
    East Green Street from Harrison Street to Walnut Street. 
    Corkhill Street from Webster Street to Green Street 
    Orange Street from North Broadway Street to College Street. 
    Mill Street from North Broadway Street to College Street. 
    North Lucas Street from Exchange Street to Harlan Street. 
    North Main Street from Exchange Street to Harlan Street. 
    North Adams Street from Henry Street to Taft Street. 
    North Lincoln Street from Henry Street to Taft Street. 
    East Saunders Street from Adams Street to Lincoln Street. 
    Pine Street from Madison Street to Henry Street. 
    East Henry Street from Walnut Street to Wilson Street. 
    North Cherry Street from Madison Street to Oak Street. 
Twenty-five (25) miles per hour: 
    Main Street from Clay Street to South Street. 
    South Locust Street from Harvest Drive to East South Street. 
    U.S. 34 from White Street to Harrison Street. 
    Golden Eagle Drive from 235th Street to Maple Leaf Drive. 
    Commerce Drive from Iris Street to Golden Eagle Drive. 
    Maple Leaf Drive from Iris Street to Golden Eagle Drive. 
    235th Street from Iris Street to Golden Eagle Drive. 
    East Monroe Street from Adams Street to Hamlin Street. 
    East Madison Street from Adams Street to Hamlin Street. 
    Jay Street from Washington Street to Henry Street. 
    Harrison Street from Washington Street to Henry Street. 
Thirty-five (35) miles per hour: 
    Iris Road from the intersection of U.S. 34 to Winfield Avenue. 
    Maple Leaf Drive from U.S. 218 to Iris Road. 
    North Grand Avenue from East Washington Street to Winfield Avenue. 
    South Grand Avenue from East Washington to 1,000 feet south of the intersection. 
    U.S. 34 from Harrison Street to 900 feet west of Iris Road. 
    U.S. 34 from west city limits to White Street. 
    Winfield Avenue for Lincoln Street intersection east to U.S. 218. 
Forty-five (45) miles per hour: 
    South Grand Avenue from 1,000 feet south of the intersection to the south city limits. 
    South Grand Avenue from 1,000 [feet] south of East Washington Street to the south city limits. 
    East Washington Street from 900 feet west of Iris Road to 1,000 feet east of Iris Road. 
    West Washington Street from 1,120 feet east of the intersection at JW & J Lane to Goodyear Road. 
Fifty-five (55) miles per hour: 
    U.S. 34 from 1,000 feet east of Iris Road to the east city limits. 
    U.S. 218 from 1,000 feet north of Maple Leaf Drive to the north city limits.

The driver, having so yielded to any person or other vehicle approaching and passing through the intersection, may then proceed into the intersection with caution.
