Sec. 12-7.1. - One-way streets. 
(a)  Whenever a traffic ordinance designates a street to be a one-way street, then the city administrator shall place and maintain official traffic control devices to notify the public of such designation, all as provided in section 12-19. 
(b)  The following streets shall be designated to be one-way streets, with vehicular traffic to move in the indicated directions: 
Pearl Street, from White Street to Broadway, with eastbound travel only. 
East Webster Street , from South Locust to Corkhill, with westbound travel only, between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 8:30 a.m. and 2:40 p.m. and 3:40 p.m. on days Lincoln Elementary School is in session. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle in violation of such markings, signs, barriers or other devices so placed in accordance with this section. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 1, 5-26-93; Ord. No. 1286, § 1(Amd. 1), 9-10-2014) 
Sec. 12-8. - One-way alleys. 
(a)  Whenever any traffic ordinance of this city designates any one-way alley, the chief of police shall place and maintain signs giving notice thereof; and no such regulation shall be effective unless such signs are in place. Signs indicating the direction of traffic movement shall be placed at every alley entrance where movement of traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any reason to operate any vehicle in violation of such markings, signs, barriers or other devices so placed in accordance with this section. 
(b)  Upon the following alleys vehicular traffic shall move only in the indicated direction: 
(1)  The alley running south to north in Block 7 of the Original Plat of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa. 
(2)  The alley running north to south in Block 10 of the Original Plat of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa. 
(3)  The alley running east to west and north to south in Block 36 of the Original Plat and Part of Block 1, Commissioner's Second Addition and Block 1 in Lathrop's First Addition, all in the City of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa. 
(4)  The alley running south to north in Block 8 of the Original Plat of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa. 
(5)  The alley running north to south in Blocks 4 and 5 in the Original Plat of the City of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa. 
(6)  The alley running south to north in Block 19 of the Original Plat of the city. 
(7)  The alley running south to north in Block 37 of the Original Plat of the city. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle in violation of such markings, signs, barriers or other devices so placed in accordance with this section. 
(Code 1969, 8.52.050; Ord. No. 428, §§ 2-4, 3-6-74; Ord. No. 442, § 1, 4-16-75; Ord. No. 469, § 1, 9-15-76; Ord. No. 516, § 1, 10-3-79; Ord. No. 1235, § 1, 3-22-2011) 
State Law reference- Authority to designate one-way streets, I.C.A. § 321.236(4). 
Sec. 12-9. - Load limits. 
    It is unlawful for the owner or operator of any vehicle having a gross vehicle weight of more than six (6) tons to travel upon any of the following streets: 
Courtland St., between west city limits and west line of White St. 
(Code 1969, § 8.64.010) 
Sec. 12-10. - School traffic-control signals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any vehicle to park same upon the streets within fifty (50) feet of the approach of any electrical school traffic-control signal. 
(b)  When roll-out stop signs have been placed in the streets at the places designated as school zones, all motor vehicles approaching the zones shall come to a full stop at the limits of the zones and shall give way to pedestrian traffic using the areas so designated as school zones. 
(Code 1969, §§ 8.52.020, 8.52-040; Ord. No. 530, § 1, 4-2-80; Ord. No. 694, § 1, 10-28-87) 
State Law reference- School traffic-control signals, I.C.A. §§ 321.249, 321.358(6).

Sec. 12-11.1. - School traffic-Closed streets. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a motor vehicle, with the exception of school buses, on the following streets: 
(1)  East Green Street from South Locust to Corkhill Street, between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 8:30 a.m. and 2:40 p.m. and 3:40 p.m. on days the Mount Pleasant Community Schools are in session. School buses shall travel only eastbound on East Green Street. 
(2)  East Saunders Street from North Lincoln Street to North Adams Street, between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 8:30 a.m. and 2:40 p.m. and 3:40 p.m. on days the Mount Pleasant Community Schools are in session. 
(Ord. No. 915, § 1, 12-14-94; Ord. No. 1124, § 1, 12-18-2002; Ord. No. 1286, § 1(Amd. 2), 9-10-2014) 
Sec. 12-12. - Squealing tires. 
(a)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle, and no owner of a motor vehicle shall permit or allow the operation of a motor vehicle in such a manner or by such a method as to cause the tires on such motor vehicle to make any loud, raucous, squealing, screeching noise or other sounds caused by excessive acceleration from a stopped position or while a vehicle is in motion. This section shall not apply to any noises or sounds caused by the tires of motor vehicles when the vehicle is engaged in any emergency situation where it is necessary to accelerate or stop the vehicle immediately or suddenly in order to avoid contact with another motor vehicle or with a pedestrian as long as the emergency situation is not that of the owner's making. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to authorized police, fire and emergency vehicles and special mobile equipment licensed and authorized by the state as such special mobile equipment. 
(Ord. No. 775, § 1, 3-28-90) 
Sec. 12-13. - Vehicles entering street. 
    The driver of a vehicle about to enter or cross a street from a private road, driveway or building shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on the street. 
(Code 1969, § 8.28.030) 
Sec. 12-14. - Driving through funeral procession or parade. 
    No motor vehicle or other vehicle shall be driven through a funeral procession or a parade without the permission of a police officer. 
(Code 1969, § 8.20.080) 
Sec. 12-15. - Vehicles on sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle on a sidewalk. 
(Code 1969, § 7.40.210) 
Sec. 12-16. - Accident reports. 
    The driver of a vehicle involved in an accident in the corporate limits which results in injury or death to any person, or damage to a vehicle to the apparent extent of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or more, shall report such accident to the city police department within seventy-two (72) hours after said accident occurs. 
(Code 1969, § 8.36.030; Ord. No. 488, § 2, 11-2-77; Ord. No. 558, 7-1-81) 
Sec. 12-17. - Condition of vehicle; required equipment. 
    It is unlawful for any person to drive or move or for the owner to cause or knowingly permit to be driven or moved on any highway any vehicle or combination of vehicles which is in such unsafe condition as to endanger any person, or which does not contain those parts or is not at all times equipped with such lamps and other equipment in proper condition and adjustment as required by Chapter 321 of the Code of Iowa, or which is equipped with one or more unsafe tires or which is equipped in any manner in violation of Chapter 321 of the Code of Iowa. 
(Ord. No. 577, § 1, 5-9-82) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 577, § 1 adopted May 9, 1982, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as § 8.60.090. Such provisions have been codified herein as § 12-17, for purposes of classification. 
Sec. 12-18. - Tires not making contact with roadway surface. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of any two-or three-wheel motor vehicle to operate the same upon any public street or highway with any of the operational tires not making contact with the roadway surface, or to indulge or engage in any kind of trick or unsafe driving. Nothing in this section shall apply to any vehicle being legally parked or towed. 
(Ord. No. 618, § 1, 4-4-84) 
Sec. 12-19. - Traffic-control devices-Authority to install and maintain. 
(a)  The director of public works or the city administrator shall place and maintain official traffic-control devices when and as required under the traffic ordinances of this city to make effective the provisions of such ordinances and may place and maintain such additional signs or devices as he/she may deem necessary to regulate, warrant or guide traffic under the traffic ordinances of this city or the state vehicle code. 
(b)  The director of public works or the city administrator shall notify the city council in writing of the placement and location of such designation and installation of signs. Upon such notification, the city council shall confirm the action taken by passage of a resolution authorizing the signage. The resolution confirming the action shall be adopted by the council on or before its second regular meeting following the notification. Should the council fail to adopt an authorizing resolution, the sign shall immediately be removed. 
(Ord. No. 761, § 1, 1-10-90) 
Sec. 12-20. - Same-Traffic lanes. 
    The director of public works or the city administrator is hereby authorized to mark traffic lanes upon the roadway of any street or highway where a regular alignment of traffic is necessary. 
(Ord. No. 761, § 1, 1-10-90) 
Sec. 12-21. - Same-Manual and specifications. 
    All traffic-control signs, signals and devices shall conform to the manual and specifications approved by the state highway commission. All signs and signals required hereunder for a particular purpose shall so far as practicable be uniform as to type and location throughout the city. All traffic-control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law and this chapter shall be official traffic-control devices. 
(Ord. No. 761, § 1, 1-10-90) 
Sec. 12-22. - Same-Presumption of legality. 
(a)  Whenever official traffic-control devices are placed in a position approximately conforming to the requirements of the Code of Iowa and this chapter, such devices shall be presumed to have been so placed by the official act or direction of lawful authority unless the contrary shall be established by competent evidence. 
(b)  Any official traffic-control device placed pursuant to the provisions of this chapter and purporting to conform to the law requirements pertaining to such devices shall be presumed to comply with the requirements of the Code of Iowa and this chapter unless the contrary shall be established by competent evidence. 
(Ord. No. 761, § 1, 1-10-80) 
Secs. 12-23-12-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2]

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-31. - Presumption. 
    In any prosecution for a violation of any of the provisions of this article, there shall be a rebuttable presumption that the registered owner of a vehicle was its operator.

Sec. 12-32.1. - Parking lots. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in a parking lot or portion of a parking lot owned by the city that has been designated to be one of the following: 
(1)  A prohibited parking lot. 
(2)  A reserved parking lot. 
(3)  A partially prohibited parking lot. 
(4)  A partially reserved parking lot. 
(5)  A combination of the above. 
    Such designation shall be determined by resolution of the city council pursuant to section 12-19 of the Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 828, § 1, 11-11-92; Ord. No. 867, § 1, 4-4-93) 
Sec. 12-32.2. - Parking in cul-de-sacs. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a motor vehicle within the circular turnaround of any cul-de-sac. 
(Ord. No. 932, § 1, 5-10-95) 
Sec. 12-33. - Parking during cleanup hours. 
(a)  It is unlawful for the driver or owner of any motor vehicle to park or leave standing any such vehicle between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m., designated as cleanup hours, in the following locations: 
(1)  Main St., between Washington St. and Monroe St. (east side of street) 
(2)  Main St., between Monroe St. and Madison St. (both sides of street) 
(3)  Monroe St., between Main St. and Jefferson St. (north side of street) 
(4)  Jefferson St., between Washington St. and Monroe Street (west side of street) 
(5)  Jefferson St., between Monroe St. and Madison St. (both sides of street) 
(6)  Monroe St., between Jefferson St. and Jackson St. (both sides of street) 
(b)  Any vehicles parked in violation of this section may be subject to impoundment by the police department, in addition to any other remedies allowed by law. 
(Code 1969, § 8.12.050; Ord. No. 569, § 1, 2-3-82; Ord. No. 796, § 1, 3-13-91; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 3-22-2011) 
Sec. 12-34. - Parking during school term. 
(a)  The parking of motor vehicles is expressly prohibited from the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on school days during the regular school term, in the following places: 
Saunders Street, north side, from Adams Street to Lincoln Street. 
Saunders Street, south side, from Adams Street to Lincoln Street. 
Mill Street, south side, from Main Street to Lucas Street. 
Orange Street, north side, from 100 feet west of the intersection of Main and Orange to Orange Street. 
Poplar St., west side, from East Henry St. to the railroad tracks. 
Corkhill Street, the North 126 feet of the east side. 
(b)  The parking of motor vehicles is expressly prohibited from the hours of 7:30 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. and from 3:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. on school days during the regular school term, that is, from the last Monday of August to June 1 of each respective year, on the north side of the 800 Block of East Henry Street, in the area designated to be the curb loading zone which is directly in front of Van Allen Elementary School. 
(Code 1969, § 8.12.140; Ord. No. 584, 9-15-82; Ord. No. 684, § 1, 2-25-87; Ord. No. 789, § 1, 11-14-90; Ord. No. 916, § 1, 12-14-94; Ord. No. 974, § 1, 1-8-97; Ord. No. 1015, § 1, 8-12-98; Ord. No. 1043, § 1, 3-10-99; Ord. No. 1066, § 1, 1-12-2000; Ord. No. 1130A, § 1, 12-10-2003; Ord. No. 1150, § 2, 6-22-2005; Ord. No. 1327, § 1, 4-26-2017; Ord. No. 1329, § 1, 5-24-2017) 
Sec. 12-34.1. - Parking in designated loading zone. 
    It is unlawful for the driver or owner of any motor vehicle to leave standing or park such vehicle for a period of time in excess of twelve (12) minutes at the following designated loading areas: 
Main St., east side, from a point beginning 120 feet south of the intersection of Pearl St. and Main St., then continuing in a southerly direction for 170 feet. 
Main St., west side, in the paved portion of the public right-of-way, adjacent to the Iowa Wesleyan Chapel. 
North Marion St., west side, from a point beginning 105 feet south of West Monroe St., and continuing in a northerly direction for 30 feet. 
(Ord. No. 901, § 1, 4-27-94; Ord. No. 907, § 1, 7-13-94; Ord. No. 1253, § 1, 9-12-2012) 
Sec. 12-34.2. - Parking in designated tow away zone prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for the driver or owner of any motor vehicle to leave standing or park such vehicle at the following designated tow away zones: 
Pearl St., both sides, between White St. and the east line of Jackson St. extended into the street. 
    Any motor vehicle left standing or parked in the above designated tow away zone shall be towed as prescribed in section 12-60 and impounded. 
(Ord. No. 994, § 1, 9-24-97)

Jefferson St., both sides, between north line of Monroe St. and south line of Madison St.

Sec. 12-36. - Parking on private property. 
(a)  Parking spaces shall be used only for parking of vehicles for property owners, guests, renters, patrons or employees of the site. Required parking spaces shall not be used for sale, display, rental or repair of other motor vehicles. 
(b)  All parking of vehicles on private property, including automobiles, vans, campers, trucks, trailers, tractors, recreational vehicles, boats, construction equipment and any other mobile vehicle equipped for street and highway travel shall occur on paved areas and on private property only. The term "paved areas" shall include gravel surfaces. 
(c)  City right-of-way shall not be used for parking of vehicles, including paved portions of the right-of-way. The term "paved areas" shall include gravel surfaces. 
(d)  No person shall park, place, keep or store, or permit the parking or storage of a stock car, racing car, inoperable vehicle, vehicular component parts, unless it shall be in a completely enclosed building. This regulation shall not apply to legitimate businesses operating in a lawful place and manner provided, however, that such outside areas are screened from public view. 
(e)  For the purpose of this section, the city right-of-way shall be defined as that area between the curb line of a street and the adjacent sidewalk or property line, whichever is the greater distance; or if there is no sidewalk, then the area within six (6) feet of the curb line of the street or adjacent property line, whichever is the greater distance. 
(f)  Violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine, as prescribed in section 12-59. 
    Exception: Subparagraphs (a), (b), and (d) of this section shall not be enforced during the week before, during or the week following the Midwest Old Settlers and Threshers Reunion. 
(Ord. No. 1332, § 1, 6-28-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 975, adopted Jan. 8, 1997, amended this Code by repealing § 12-36, which pertained to four-hour standing or parking and was derived from Ord. No. 471, § 1, adopted Oct. 20, 1976 and Ord. No. 473, § 1, adopted Oct. 20, 1976.  
 Subsequently, Ord. No. 1332, § 1, adopted June 28, 2017, enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 12-37. - Standing or parking prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver or owner of a motor vehicle to park or leave such vehicle standing in any of the following locations: 
Walnut St., west side, between north line of McMillan Park as extended into the street and south line of McMillan Park as extended into the street. 
Locust St., east side, between north line of McMillan Park as extended into the street and south line of McMillan Park as extended into the street. 
Washington St., both sides, except where parking spaces or improved shoulders have been provided for such purpose. 
(Code 1969, §§ 8.12.100-8.12.130; Ord. No. 439, §§ 1, 2, 2-9-75; Ord. No. 633, § 2, 12-5-84) 
Sec. 12-38. - Truck parking. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a person to park or leave any semi-trailer tractor and/or trailer: 
(1)  In any municipal parking lot. 
(2)  Along the north side of East Monroe Street from Cherry Street to a point one hundred thirty (130) feet east. 
(3)  Along the west side of North Adams Street between Broad Street and Pearl Street. 
(b)  In addition to the above, the following parking restrictions shall apply in residential areas: 
(1)  Motor vehicles of any type that exceed seven (7) feet in height or eight (8) feet in width or twenty (20) feet in length, including but not limited to recreational vehicles (self-contained or towed) and commercial delivery vehicles shall not be parked on any street in a residential district except as herein provided. Such vehicles may park for the purpose of loading or unloading or making deliveries, but parking for such activity shall not exceed a period of one (1) hour. Moving vans are exempt from this one (1) hour restriction. Semi-trailer tractors may park on a city street where not prohibited in residential districts only by and adjacent to the driver or owner's residence for a period not to exceed 24 hours. These provisions shall be suspended and not enforced for recreational vehicles only from five days prior to the annual Midwest Old Thresher Reunion until four days following said reunion in each calendar year. 
(2)  Commercial vehicles which transport detonable materials or flammable solids, liquids and/or gases, radioactive materials, or hazardous materials as defined by the National Traffic and Safety Board (NTSB) shall not be parked on any street in a residential district except for the purpose of making local deliveries. 
(3)  Commercial vehicles or trailers with operating refrigeration units shall not be parked in such proximity to any residence as to constitute a nuisance as defined by the Municipal Code. 
(Code 1969, § 8.12.160; Ord. No. 752, § 1, 8-23-89; Ord. No. 756, § 1, 10-11-89; Ord. No. 821, § 1, 5-13-92; Ord. No. 1039, § 1, 2-24-99) 
Sec. 12-39. - Parking in center of street. 
    No person shall park a motor vehicle in the center of any street. 
(Code 1969, § 8.12.090) 
Sec. 12-40. - Parking in alleys. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle in the traveled portion of an alley for purposes of loading or unloading for longer than fifteen (15) consecutive minutes. 
(b)  Except as provided in subsection (a), no person shall park a motor vehicle in the traveled portion of an alley. 
(Code 1969, § 8-12.090) 
Sec. 12-41. - Parking for sale or show. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave standing or cause to be parked or left standing any motor vehicle for sale, barter, exchange or for show on any street, alley or municipally owned parking lot or in the space between the property line and the curb of the street. 
(Code 1969, § 8.12.150) 
Sec. 12-42. - Parking over twenty-four hours. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the driver or owner of any motor vehicle to park or leave standing any such vehicle upon any street, alley, highway of the city, or in a municipal parking lot owned and controlled by the city, for a period of more than twenty-four (24) hours. Such restrictions shall not apply to any reserved parking lots or spaces as described in section 12-32.1 of the Municipal Code. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(Code 1969, § 8-12.040; Ord. No. 802, § 1, 7-10-91; Ord. No. 868, § 1, 4-14-93; Ord. No. 1212, § 2, 10-28-2009) 
Sec. 12-43. - Parking spaces for the handicapped. 
(a)  Parking spaces designated. It is unlawful for any person except a handicapped person or driver for a handicapped person to park a vehicle in any of the following parking spaces: 
(1)  One (1) parking space located in the 100 block of West Monroe Street which is identified by the handicapped parking designation. 
(2)  One (1) parking space located in the 100 block of East Monroe Street which is identified by the handicapped parking designation. 
(3)  Two (2) parking spaces located in the parking lot on the south side of the county courthouse which is identified by the handicapped parking designation. 
(4)  Two (2) parking spaces located on the west side of Jackson Street between Monroe and Washington Streets which is identified by the handicapped parking designation. 
(5)  One (1) space in the 100 block of North Jefferson Street, which is identified by the handicapped parking designation. 
(6)  One (1) space in the 100 block of South Main Street, which is identified by the handicapped parking designation. 
(7)  One (1) space in the 100 block of North Main Street, which is identified by the handicapped parking designation. 
(8)  One (1) space each in the city municipal parking lots located at the 200 block of South Main Street and the 200 block of North Main Street; and four (4) spaces in the city municipal parking lot located at the 200 block of North Jefferson Street, identified by the handicapped parking designation. 
(9)  One (1) parking space located in the 200 block of North Main Street, which is identified by the handicapped parking designation. 
(10)  One (1) parking located in the 200 block of West Monroe Street, south side, identified by the handicapped parking designation. 
(11)  One (1) parking space in the 200 block of North Jefferson Street, which is identified by the handicapped parking designation. 
(12)  One (1) parking space in the 100 block of East Madison Street, which is identified by the handicapped parking designation. 
(13)  One (1) parking space in the 200 block of West Pearl Street, which is identified by the handicapped parking designation. 
(14)  One (1) parking space located in the 100 block of East Monroe Street, south side, furthest east space, identified by the handicapped parking designation. 
(b)  Handicapped vehicle stickers. The handicapped person's vehicle shall be appropriately designated as such by a sticker displayed on the vehicle's windshield, which can be obtained from the Iowa Department of Transportation Office of Vehicle Registration, Special Services Section. 
(c)  Other provisions applicable. The provisions contained herein will not exempt said vehicle or the operator from all other provisions of this Code. 
(d)  Prima facie proof. The fact that a motor vehicle is illegally parked or parked overtime and is registered in the name of a person shall be considered prima facie proof that such person was in control of the motor vehicle at the time of such parking. 
(e)  Penalties. The penalty for violating the provisions contained herein shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 535, §§ 1-3, 6-18-80; Ord. No. 595, § 1, 2-16-83; Ord. No. 643, § 1, 3-20-85; Ord. No. 644, § 1, 3-20-85; Ord. No. 719, § 1, 7-27-88; Ord. No. 742, § 1, 6-19-89; Ord. No. 764, § 1, 2-14-90; Ord. No. 786, § 1, 7-11-90; Ord. No. 831, § 1, 11-11-92; Ord. No. 1005, § 1, 1-28-98; Ord. No. 1100, § 1, 9-12-2001; Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 11-26-2002; Ord. No. 1223, § 1, 5-26-2010) 
Sec. 12-44. - Parking near school traffic control signal. 
    It is unlawful for the owner or operator of any truck to park same upon the streets of this city within fifty (50) feet of the approach of any electrical school traffic-control signal. 
(Code 1969, § 8.52.040) 
Sec. 12-45. - Angle parking. 
(a)  Generally. No part of any vehicle or the load thereon, when parked within a diagonal parking district, shall extend within the roadway more than a distance of sixteen (16) feet when measured at right angles to the adjoining curb. This requirement shall not apply to angle parking on E. Saunders St. described in subparagraph (b): deleting said subparagraph. 
(b)  Specified parking. Motor vehicles may be parked in the following specified parking areas, within the marked parking lines, at an angle of approximately sixty (60) degrees with the curbline in the direction of travel on the following streets: 
Adams St., west side, between Washington St. and Clay St. 
E. Saunders St., north side, where so marked, between N. Lincoln St. and N. Adams St. 
Jackson St., west side, between Madison St. and Washington St. 
Jefferson St., west side, between Madison St. and Monroe St. 
Jefferson St., both sides, where so marked, between Monroe St. and Clay St. 
Main St., both sides, between Washington St. and Madison St. 
Monroe St., north side, between Adams St. and Main St. 
Monroe St., both sides, where so marked between Main St. and White St., but excluding the angle parking reserved to the police department described in paragraph (c). 
Washington St., north side, between Main St. and Jefferson St. 
(c)  Police department. No more than three (3) angle parking spaces, the same to be designated by reserved parking signs, shall be reserved at all times for visitors of the city police department, the same to be located on the south side of Monroe Street in the area that is north of the police station, the point of beginning commencing approximately ten (10) feet west of the currently located stop sign. 
(d)  Fire department. Angle parking spaces, the same to be designated by reserved parking signs, shall be reserved at all times for the fire department along the south property line of the municipal parking lot lying north of the fire station, the point of beginning commencing in front of the north fire entrance and continuing west for the remainder of the lot. 
(e)  Marked areas; violation. Whenever motor vehicles are required to park at an angle of approximately sixty (60) degrees to the curb, the city council shall indicate places or stalls in those areas by marking or painting lines on the pavement in those areas. Whenever the city has marked those parking areas or stalls, it shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle in those areas or stalls except within the lines. 
(Code 1969, §§ 8.12.060, 8.12.070, 8.12.180; Ord. No. 791, § 1, 11-28-90, Ord. No. 824, § 1, 8-26-92; Ord. No. 1021, § 1, 8-26-98; Ord. No. 1118, § 2, 8-14-2002; Ord. No. 1124, § 1, 12-18-2002) 
State Law reference- Authority to permit angle parking, I.C.A. § 321.361. 
Sec. 12-45.1. - Reserved parallel parking. 
(a)  No more than two (2) parallel parking spaces, the same to be designated by reserved parking signs, shall be reserved at all times for the fire department on the east side of Jackson Street in the area that is west of the fire station and the municipal parking lot, the point of beginning commencing south of the west municipal parking lot entrance and moving southerly along the 200 Block of South Jackson Street to a point north of the fire department driveway in accordance with Section 321.358(9) of the Code of Iowa. 
(Ord. No. 790, § 1, 11-28-90; Ord. No. 922, § 1, 1-11-95; Ord. No. 1092, § 1, 5-9-2001) 
Sec. 12-46. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1018, § 1, adopted Aug. 26, 1998, repealed § 12-46 in its entirety. Formerly, § 12-46 pertained to parking spaces for driver's license examination. 
Sec. 12-47. - Emergency regulation of parking. 
    The mayor, subject to review of the city council, may make temporary rules regulating parking on city streets. No such rules regulating parking may remain in effect for more than thirty (30) days. The rules and regulations may include the following: 
(1)  To erect signs indicating no parking on public streets when such parking would interfere with traffic or create a hazardous situation. 
(2)  To determine and designate by proper signs where the stopping or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic. 
(Ord. No. 667, § 1, 3-12-86) 
Sec. 12-48. - Three-hour parking or standing. 
    It is unlawful for the driver or owner of any vehicle to leave standing or park such vehicle for a period of time in excess of three (3) hours between 6:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. at the following locations: 
Those diagonal parking spaces located on Washington St., Jefferson St., Monroe St. and Main St. directly adjacent to and abutting Central Park. 
(Ord. No. 770, § 1, 3-14-90; Ord. No. 921, § 1, 1-11-95) 
Sec. 12-49. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 816, § 1, adopted January 8, 1992, repealed § 12-49 in its entirety. Formerly, § 12-49 pertained to a bus loading and unloading zone and derived from § 1 of Ord. No. 767, adopted February 28, 1990. 
Sec. 12-50. - Prohibitions on public property. 
(a)  It is unlawful for the owner of any property to place said property upon any street, alley, sidewalk, right-of-way or public parking lot of the city, except as otherwise described in section 12-42. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, the city right-of-way shall be defined as that area between the curbline of a street and the adjacent sidewalk or property line, whichever is the greater distance; or if there is no sidewalk, then the area within six (6) feet of the curbline of the street or adjacent property line, whichever is the greater distance. 
(Ord. No. 780, § 1, 5-23-90; Ord. No. 803, § 1, 7-10-91) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 780, § 1, adopted May 23, 1990 amended the Code by adding § 12-48. Such provisions were redesignated as § 12-50, at the editor's discretion, in order to avoid a duplication of section numbers. 
Secs. 12-51-12-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESTRICTED PARKING AREA 

Sec. 12-56. - Designated. 
    The following described streets in the city are hereby designated and established as a parking area: 
(1)  Main Street from Clay Street to Madison Street; 
(2)  Jefferson Street from Clay Street to Madison Street; 
(3)  Six (6) parking spaces immediately in front of post office on North Jefferson Street; 
(4)  Washington Street from Jackson Street to Adams Street. 
(5)  Monroe Street from Jackson Street to Adams Street; 
(6)  Madison Street, north side, from Harrison Street to Jay Street, designated for "Resident Parking Only" from 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. Monday through Friday. 
(Ord. No. 527, § 3, 3-19-80; Ord. No. 585, § 1, 9-15-82) 
Sec. 12-57. - Hours effective. 
    Parking regulations shall be enforced in said parking area from 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday of each week, except for all legal holidays excluding Labor Day. The enforcement of section 12-42 for parking over twenty-four (24) hours, shall continue to apply and shall not be limited in anyway by this section. 
(Ord. No. 527, § 4, 3-19-80; Ord. No. 977, § 1, 1-8-97) 
Sec. 12-58. - Parking limits. 
(a)  There shall be a maximum of twelve (12) minutes of parking time in the following parking spaces in the parking areas described as follows: 
(1)  Two (2) in front of the building at 102 S. Main Street. 
(2)  Two (2) on the 200 Block of South Main Street, west side, between the city parking lot and the intersection with Washington Street. 
All other parking spaces within the parking area shall have a maximum parking time of one hundred twenty (120) minutes. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any vehicle so parked to allow said vehicle to remain parked in said parking area beyond the time limit hereinbefore provided. 
(Ord. No. 527, §§ 5, 6, 3-19-80; Ord. No. 563, § 1, 11-18-81; Ord. No. 599, § 1, 4-20-83; Ord. No. 978, § 1, 1-8-97; Ord. No. 1321, § 1, 11-9-2016) 
Sec. 12-59. - Violations. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of traffic officers so instructed to take the state vehicle tag number of all persons violating the provisions of this article and make complaint therefor. Any person who parks within the parking area in violation of this article and receives a ticket for violation of this article shall be subject to the following penalty: 
(1)  A ten-dollar fine, and said fine shall be deposited in the box located at the Mount Pleasant Police Department in Mount Pleasant, Iowa. 
(2)  A ticket for any violation of this article shall be paid within forty-eight (48) hours after the ticket has been placed on said vehicle. If not paid within forty-eight (48) hours, the fine will increase to fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(b)  Whenever the fine and costs imposed for the violation of this article are not paid, the person convicted may be subject to imprisonment not to exceed thirty (30) days, or to a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 527, §§ 7-9, 3-19-80; Ord. No. 710, § 1, 3-23-88; Ord. No. 1116, § 1, 7-10-2002; Ord. No. 1278, § 1, 3-26-2014) 
Sec. 12-60. - Impoundment. 
(a)  The police department or any officer of the city designated to enforce the parking ordinances of the city, on finding a vehicle unattended at a designated tow away zone or on finding a vehicle unattended where the vehicle constitutes an obstruction to vehicular traffic, may remove or cause the removal of such vehicle to a place designated by the officer for the storage of impounded vehicles. Upon impoundment of such vehicle, the city shall notify the last known registered owner of such impoundment by certified mail if the name and address of the owner can be ascertained with reasonable diligence. The registered owner or operator may reclaim such vehicle by payment of any charges incurred for towing and storage. 
(b)  No vehicle shall be impounded by towing unless such vehicle is on a public street or in a public lot and appears to be in violation of this section or section 12-34.2. 
(c)  If it is necessary to enter a locked or unlocked vehicle in order to impound such vehicle, such entrance must be made in the presence of a police officer. The police officer shall conduct a search of such vehicle as he/she deems necessary to protect the contents therein, however, such search need not be a complete inventory. 
(d)  The registered owner or operator may reclaim any vehicle impounded pursuant to the provisions herein by appearing before the city administrator or his/her representative. At such time, the owner or the operator shall sign a certificate that he/she is the registered owner or operator of the impounded vehicle, pay for all charges and costs incurred in impounding the vehicle and accept service of a citation filed against him/her for any outstanding tickets. In lieu of said citation, the owner or operator may at that time pay for any outstanding tickets. 
(Ord. No. 996, § 1, 9-24-97) 
Secs. 12-61-12-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONTROLLED ACCESS FACILITIES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Controlled access facilities, I.C.A. Ch. 306A. 

Sec. 12-76. - Definition. 
    For the purpose of this article, a "controlled access facility" means a highway or street especially designed for through traffic, and over, from or to which owners or occupants of abutting land or other persons have only a controlled right of easement of access, light, air or view by reason of the fact that their property abuts upon such controlled access facility or for any other reason. 
(Code 1969, § 8.76.020) 
Sec. 12-77. - Establishment. 
    There are hereby fixed and established controlled access facilities on the primary road system extension improvement, Project No. F-56(9) Primary Road No. U.S. 218 within the city, described as follows: 
(1)  Sta. 0+00 (NCL) southerly to near the north line of Orange Street (Sta. -10+39.5) regulating access to and from Sta. 0+00 to Sta. -10+39.5 and to abutting properties along the highway, all in accordance with the plans for such improvement identified as Project No. F-56(9) on file in the office of the city clerk; 
(2)  From Sta. 530+10 (SCL) to Winfield Avenue (NCL) regulating access to and from Sta. 530+10 to Winfield Avenue and to and from abutting properties along the highway all in accordance with the plans for such improvement identified as Project No. F-219 on file in the office of the city clerk; 
(3)  Controlled access facilities are further fixed and established regulating access on U.S. No. 34 (Washington Street) on both sides of the street for a distance of one city block where the highways intersect, being all of that area along Washington Street from Sta. 534+50 (Wilson Street) to Sta. 541+00 (Porter Street), and to and from abutting properties along Highway U.S. No. 34 in the one block area, all in accordance with the plans for such improvement, identified and approved as Project No. F-219 on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 8.76.050)

    The compiled list furnished by the Iowa State Highway Commission of entrances provided for access under the above improvement in section 12-77 specified as Project No. F-56(9) are recorded as follows:

Sec. 12-79. - General restrictions. 
    It is unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Drive a vehicle over, upon or across any curb, central dividing section or other separation or dividing line on controlled access facilities; 
(2)  Make a left turn or a semicircular or U-turn except through an opening provided for that purpose in the dividing curb section, separation or line; 
(3)  Drive any vehicle except in the proper lane provided for that purpose and in the proper direction and to the right of the central dividing curb, separation section or line; 
(4)  Drive any vehicle into the controlled access facility from a local service road except through an opening provided for that purpose in the dividing curb or dividing section or dividing line which separates such service road from the controlled access facility property. 
(Code 1969, § 8.76.030) 
Sec. 12-80. - Parking. 
    Parking is prohibited as follows on controlled access facilities: 
(1)  From Sta. -10+39.5 to Sta 0+00. Parking is prohibited on the minor street approach for a distance of thirty-five (35) feet in advance of the stop sign. Parking is prohibited on the exit side of the minor street for a distance of thirty-five (35) feet. 
(Code 1969, § 8.76.080) 
Sec. 12-81. - Speed limits. 
    Speed limits are established as follows: 
(1)  Thirty (30) miles per hour from Sta. -10+39.5 to Sta. 0+00. 
(Code 1969, § 8.76.080)

ARTICLE IV. - PRIMARY ROADS 

Sec. 12-91. - Parking. 
    Parking is hereby prohibited in the following areas: 
(a)  Parking of any nature is prohibited from Sta. 530+(SCL) to Sta. 561+10(U.S. No. 34) Parking is prohibited on the minor street approach for a distance of thirty-five (35) feet in advance of the stop sign. Where diagonal parking is permitted, on the minor street approach, parking shall be restricted so that a fifty-five foot stop sign distance is maintained. 
(b)  Parking is prohibited on the exit side of the minor street for a distance of thirty-five (35) feet where one (1) through lane is provided for exit traffic. Limits of parking restriction on U.S. No. 34 approaches will be determined by intersection capacity analysis and by the limits of construction and will be specifically described in the final project resolution. 
(c)  No parking shall be permitted on U.S. No. 34 from Sta 534+50 (Wilson Street) to Sta. 541+00 (Porter Street). 
(d)  Parking of any nature is prohibited from Sta 561+10.0 (Washington Street and Primary No. U.S. 34) to Sta. 597+67.0 (Maple Leaf Drive) and from Sta. 622+20.0 to Sta 625+23.7 (Winfield Avenue). Parking is prohibited on the minor street approaches for a distance of thirty-five (35) feet in advance of the stop signs and on the exit sides of the minor streets for a distance of thirty-five (35) feet beyond the right-of-way line. 
(Code 1969, §§ 8.80.10-8.80.30) 
Sec. 12-92. - Speed limits. 
    Speed limits shall be as follows: 
(1)  Fifty-five (55) miles per hour daytime from Sta. 531 - 15 (SCL) to Sta. 547 - 00; 
(2)  Fifty-five (55) miles per hour nighttime from Sta. 531 - 15 (SCL) to Sta. 547 - 00; 
(3)  Fifty-five (55) miles per hour from Sta. 547 - 00 to Sta. 554 - 00; 
(4)  Thirty-five (35) miles per hour from Sta. 554 - 00 to Sta. 560 - 90; 
(Code 1969, § 8.80.040; Ord. No. 979, § 1, 1-8-97) 
Secs. 12-93-12-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BICYCLES AND SKATEBOARDS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Bicycles generally, Ch. 5. 

Sec. 12-101. - Seats and passengers. 
(a)  No person shall ride on a bicycle other than upon or astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto. 
(b)  No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one (1) time than the number for which it is designed and equipped. 
(Code 1969, § 8.68.020) 
Sec. 12-102. - Riding abreast. 
    No person using or operating bicycles upon the streets shall ride more than two (2) abreast. 
(Code 1969, § 8.68.070) 
Sec. 12-103. - Riding on sidewalk. 
(a)  No person shall operate a bicycle or a skateboard on a sidewalk located in the central business district. For the purpose of this section, the perimeters of the central business district shall include the east side of Jackson Street from the north side of Clay Street to the south side of Madison Street; and the south side of Madison Street from the east side of Jackson Street to the west side of Adams Street; and the west side of Adams Street from the south side of Madison Street to the north side of Clay Street; and the north side of Clay Street from the west side of Adams Street to the east side of Jackson Street. 
(b)  Any person in violation of any provision of this section shall have committed a municipal infraction, and shall be assessed a civil penalty in the manner described in section 1-8.1, and in such amount as is established in section 25-24(a). 
(Code 1969, § 8.68.010; Ord. No. 741, § 1, 5-24-89; Ord. No. 800, § 1, 5-22-91; Ord. No. 835, § 1, 11-11-92) 
Sec. 12-104. - Pedestrian right-of-way. 
    Pedestrians upon sidewalks shall have the right-of-way at all times over persons riding bicycles upon any sidewalk. 
(Code 1969, § 8.68.030) 
Chapter 13 - NUISANCES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Dangerous buildings, § 6-167 et seq.; removal of snow and ice from sidewalks, § 22-30. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Public nuisances prohibited; authority to abate. 
    The creation or maintenance of a nuisance is unlawful and is prohibited. The mayor or the mayor's designee is authorized to abate nuisances either by issuance of a municipal infraction punishable as provided in section 1-8.1 of this Code, or by administrative abatement procedures set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1263, § 1(1), 1-23-2013) 
Editor's note- Section 1(1) of Ord. No. 1263, adopted Jan. 23, 2013, repealed the former § 13-1, and enacted a new § 13-1 as set out herein. The former § 13-1 pertained to definitions, and derived from the original codification. 
State Law reference- Power of city to define and abate nuisances, I.C.A. § 364.12. 
Sec. 13-2. - Nuisance defined; enumeration of nuisances. 
    Whatever is injurious to the senses or an obstruction to the free use of public and private property so as essentially to interfere with the comfortable enjoyment of life or property by the public or community shall be deemed a nuisance. Nuisances shall include, but shall not be limited to, the following: 
(a)  Noxious weeds and other rank vegetation. Dense growth of all weeds, vines, brush or other vegetation in the city so as to constitute a health, safety or fire hazard. 
(b)  Accumulation of rubbish, trash, refuse, junk and other abandoned materials, metals, lumber or other things. 
(c)  Creating, maintaining, causing or allowing to exist, conditions which are conducive to the harborage or breeding of vermin; or allowing to exist infestations of vermin, such as rats, mice, skunks, snakes, bats, starlings, pigeons, wasps, cockroaches or flies. 
(d)  Any real property which is in such a dilapidated condition that it is unfit for human habitation, kept in such an unsanitary condition that it is a menace to the health of people residing in the vicinity thereof, presents a more than ordinarily dangerous fire hazard in the vicinity where it is located, or becomes so defective, unsightly, or in such condition of deterioration or disrepair that the same causes substantial depreciation of the property values of the surrounding properties or is materially detrimental to properties and improvements. 
(e)  All unnecessary or unauthorized noises and annoying vibration, including animal noises. 
(f)  The erecting, continuing or using of any building or other place for the exercise of any trade, employment or manufacture which, by occasioning noxious exhalations, offensive smells or other annoyances, becomes injurious and dangerous to the health, comfort or property of individuals or the public. 
(g)  The causing, preventing or allowing any refuse, solid waste, garbage, noxious substances, hazardous wastes, junk or salvage materials to be collected or to remain in any place. The term "noxious substances" shall include, but not be limited to, substances, solid or fluid, which are offensive, detrimental to health, hurtful or dangerous, including any dead animal or portion thereof, together with human or animal excrement. 
(h)  The corrupting or rendering unwholesome or impure of the water of any river, stream or pond, or unlawfully diverting the river, stream or pond from its natural course or state, to the injury or prejudice of others. 
(i)  Any building, structure or other place or location where any activity which is violation of local, state or federal law is conducted, performed or maintained. 
(j)  Creating, maintaining, causing or allowing to exist any stagnant water standing on any property, including any container or material kept in such a condition that water can accumulate and stagnate therein. 
(k)  Dense smoke, noxious fumes, gas, soot or cinders, in unreasonable quantities. 
(l)  The causing or suffering of any offal, filth or noisome substance to be collected or remain in any place to the prejudice of others. 
(m)  The obstructing or encumbering by fences, buildings, or otherwise, of the public roads, private ways, streets, alleys, commons or burying grounds. 
(n)  Houses of ill fame, kept for the purpose of prostitution and lewdness. 
(o)  Gambling houses or houses resorted to for the use of drugs, or houses where drunkenness, quarreling, fighting or breaches of the peace are carried on or permitted, to the disturbance of others. 
(p)  Any object or structure hereafter erected within one thousand (1,000) feet of the limits of any municipal or regularly established airport or aerial place which may endanger or obstruct aerial navigation, unless such object or structure constitutes a proper use or enjoyment of the land on which it is located. 
(q)  Any accumulation of snow and/or ice upon the sidewalks or that portion of the sidewalk extended across a driveway which has not been removed within a reasonable time after a snowfall or storm. 
(r)  The obstructing or impeding, without legal authority, of the passage of any navigable river, harbor or collection of water. 
(s)  Creating, maintaining, causing or allowing to exist any ditch, drain or water course which is now or hereafter may be constructed so as to prevent or unduly interfere with the surface and overflow water drainage from adjacent lands, or any storm water detention basin not properly maintained. 
(t)  Facilities for the storage or processing of sewage, such as septic tanks, cesspools and drain fields, which have failed or do not function properly, or which are overflowing, leaking or emanating odors; or septic tanks, cisterns and cesspools which are abandoned or no longer in use, unless properly emptied and filled with clean fill; or any cesspool or septic tank which does not comply with the county department of health regulations. 
(u)  Any gathering of persons or vehicles upon a public street or sidewalk or any use of property abutting a public street or sidewalk which obstructs pedestrian or vehicular traffic or other lawful use of streets or sidewalks, except as permitted by permit or ordinance. 
(v)  Unoccupied buildings or unoccupied portions of buildings which are unsecured or abandoned. 
(w)  Billboards, signboards and advertising signs, whether erected and constructed on public or private property, which so obstruct and impair the view of any portion or part of a public street, avenue, highway, boulevard or alley or of a railroad or street railway track as to render dangerous the use thereof. 
(x)  The depositing of inflammable junk, such as old rags, rope, cordage, rubber, bones and paper, by dealers in such articles, within the corporate limits of the city, unless it is in a building of fireproof construction. 
(y)  The depositing or allowing the depositing of any mud, dirt, gravel, grass or other debris on any public street, alley, sidewalk, or other public property. 
(z)  Trees infected with infectious disease as identified by the city public works director; or any dead, diseased or damaged trees or plant materials which may harbor serious insect or disease pests or disease injurious to other trees or plant materials, or any healthy tree in such a state of deterioration that any part of such tree is likely to fall and damage property or cause injury to persons. 
(aa)  The following items, when stored continuously in excess of 48 hours, on any portion of any property outside of a totally enclosed structure located on the property, in outdoor areas or in partially enclosed sheds, lean-tos or other structures not totally enclosed by structural walls, roof and properly functioning doors: building materials not part of an active building project authorized by a current city building permit; auto parts; miscellaneous steel, plastic, rubber or metal parts or junk; tires, packing boxes, wooden pallets, tree limbs, brush piles, discarded lumber, not including neatly stacked and cut fire wood; broken or unused furniture and appliances, any upholstered or finished furniture intended for indoor usage such as couches, beds, mattresses, desks, chairs, shelving or wooden tables, other broken or unused household furnishings or equipment including carpeting, appliances and other typical household items intended for indoor usage; plastic tarps, trash bags containing leaves, debris, garbage or other items, trash and garbage not properly contained within a trash disposal container; or any other discarded or miscellaneous item or items not normally required in the day to day use of the exterior area of the property. 
(bb)  Any attractive nuisance dangerous to children in the form of abandoned vehicles, abandoned or broken equipment, including abandoned refrigerators, hazardous pools, ponds, excavations, materials, including building material, debris, or neglected machinery. 
(cc)  Any wall, fence or hedge in such condition as to constitute a hazard to persons or property or to cause depreciation in the value of any adjacent or nearby property. 
(dd)  Any discarded or unused material on real property that is not consistent with the condition and visual appearance of surrounding adjacent real properties. Types of unacceptable materials include those items enumerated in subsection (w) and also include dirt and gravel piles, rock piles, incomplete landscaping projects, eroded soil areas, pits, holes and excavations. 
(ee)  The causing of the accumulation of building debris and/or construction materials, tools, equipment or machinery on any property within the city limits of the city after the expiration of a building permit, the occasioning of which becomes injurious and dangerous to the health, comfort, or property of individuals or the public. 
(ff)  Creating, maintaining, causing or allowing to exist for a continuous period of more than thirty (30) days, any man-made excavation, hole, or other depression in the ground in or on any lot or parcel of land in the city of a depth of more than three (3) feet below the surrounding grade, other than as part of the active construction of a building or other structure on the lot which will ultimately close in and completely cover such excavation, hole or depression. Upon a finding by the court that the owner of the lot or parcel of land has violated the provisions of the subsection, the lot owner shall be required to fill in any such excavation, hole or depression and grade the same to a topographic elevation equal to or level with the surrounding adjacent grade, and seed the site with grass or similar vegetative ground cover, and take reasonable measures to ensure the proper germination of the planted vegetation. 
(gg)  On properties being used by an allowable commercial use, any items stored on the property that are not normally utilized in the daily operation of the commercial use must be stored in structures totally enclosed by structural walls, roof and properly functioning doors. 
(hh)  All real property defaced by graffiti vandalism which is visible to the public view. 
(ii)  Any hazardous thing or condition on property which may contribute to injury of any person present on the property, including, but not limited to, open holes, open foundation, open wells or cisterns, or dangerous trees or limbs. 
(jj)  Any thing or condition on property creating an imminent threat to human health or in violation of any health or sanitation law. 
(kk)  Any violation of junk vehicles set forth in Article II of Chapter 13 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1263, § 1(2), 1-23-2013) 
Editor's note- Section 1(2) of Ord. No. 1263, adopted Jan. 23, 2013, repealed the former § 13-2, and enacted a new § 13-2 as set out herein. The former § 13-2 pertained to illustrative enumeration, and derived from the Code of 1969, §§ 5.08.010, 5.16.010; Ord. No. 872, § 1, adopted May 26, 1993; Ord. No. 1019, § 1, adopted Aug. 26, 1998; and Ord. No. 1088, § 1, adopted Dec. 31, 2000. 
Sec. 13-2.1. - Notice to abate preceding issuance of civil citation. 
(a)  Whenever a nuisance is found to exist within the city, notice to abate the same shall be given to the owner of the property as shown by the records of the county auditor, upon which such nuisance is located. 
(b)  The notice shall contain: 
(1)  A description of what constitutes the nuisance. 
(2)  The location of the nuisance, if the same is stationary. 
(3)  A statement of the steps necessary to abate the nuisance. 
(4)  A statement that if the nuisance is not abated within a specified time, the same to be reasonable under the circumstances, a civil citation shall be issued charging the owner with a municipal infraction. 
(5)  An explanation that upon being found guilty of a municipal infraction, the court is authorized to order abatement, assess the costs of abatement against the property and/or enter them as a judgment against the owner, and/or assess a civil penalty against the owner, or any combination of the above. 
    The notice to abate shall be served by U.S. certified mail or personal delivery. If the certified letter is returned to the city as undeliverable or personal delivery cannot reasonably be made then, service may be made by posting the notice in a conspicuous place upon the premises where the nuisance exists. 
(Ord. No. 1017, § 1, 8-26-98) 
Sec. 13-2.2. - Issuance of a civil citation. 
    In the event that the nuisance is not abated pursuant to the notice described in section 13-2.1, then the city may issue a civil citation as prescribed by law, charging the owner with a municipal infraction. The city may, but shall not be required, to give notice to abate prior to issuance of a civil citation for a repeat offense involving the same property and occurring within one (1) year of a prior violation. 
(Ord. No. 1017, § 1, 8-26-98) 
Sec. 13-2.3. - Abatement remedies and penalties in municipal infraction proceeding. 
    In a municipal infraction proceeding for the abatement of a nuisance, the court may order any one (1) or more of the following: 
(1)  Place a judgment against the owner and/or property for the costs of the abatement. 
(2)  Levy a civil penalty (fine) against the owner up to one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day for the first offense, and up to two hundred dollars ($200.00) per day for the second offense. 
(3)  Order abatement for the nuisance by the landowner. 
(4)  Assess costs of abatement against the property for collection in the same manner as property taxes. 
(Ord. No. 1017, § 1, 8-26-98) 
Sec. 13-3. - Prohibited. 
    It shall be a municipal infraction for any person or persons to cause, create, maintain or permit a nuisance to exist. 
(Code 1969, § 10.20.070; Ord. No. 814, § 1, 12-11-91) 
Sec. 13-4. - Notice to abate preceding abatement by the city. 
(a)  Whenever a nuisance is found to exist within the city, notice to abate the same shall be given to the owner of the property as shown by the records of the county auditor upon which such nuisance is located. 
(b)  The notice shall contain: 
(1)  An order to abate the nuisance or to request a hearing within a stated time, which shall be reasonable under the circumstances. 
(2)  A description of what constitutes the nuisance. 
(3)  The location of the nuisance, if the same is stationary. 
(4)  A statement of the acts necessary to abate the nuisance. 
(5)  A statement that if the nuisance is not abated as directed and no request for hearing is made within the prescribed time, the city will abate such nuisance and assess the costs thereof against such person. 
(c)  The notice to abate shall be served by U.S. certified mail or personal delivery. If the certified letter is returned to the city as undeliverable or personal delivery cannot reasonably be made then, service may be made by posting the notice in a conspicuous place upon the premises where the nuisance exists. 
(d)  All abatement hearings shall be held before the city council and shall be conducted in accordance with the Mt. Pleasant Administrative Code (Chapter 2, Article VIII), except as otherwise provided for in this article. 
(Code 1969, § 5.08.020; Ord. No. 951, § 1, 1-10-96; Ord. No. 1017, § 1, 8-26-98) 
State Law reference- Abatement notice, I.C.A. § 364.12(3)(h). 
Sec. 13-5. - Abatement by city. 
    Upon the failure of the person upon whom notice to abate a nuisance was served pursuant to the provisions of this article to abate the same, a duly designated officer of the city shall proceed to abate such nuisance and shall prepare a statement of costs incurred in the abatement thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 5.08.020) 
State Law reference- Power of city to abate nuisance, I.C.A. § 364.12(3)(h). 
Sec. 13-6. - Collection of city's costs. 
    Any and all costs incurred by the city in the abatement of a nuisance under the provisions of this article shall be certified to the county auditor as a special tax against such lot or parcel of ground or the person causing or maintaining the nuisance, and shall be collected the same as other property taxes. 
(Code 1969, § 5.08.020) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, I.C.A. § 364.12(3)(h). 
Sec. 13-7. - Emergency actions. 
    In an emergency the city may perform any action which may be required by this article without prior notice and assess the costs thereof, as provided herein, after notice to the property owner and hearing. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, I.C.A. § 364.12(3)(h). 
Sec. 13-8. - Article to be supplemental. 
    The provisions of this article shall be supplemental to all other ordinances. 
Secs. 13-9-13-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - INOPERABLE VEHICLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 1267, adopted March 27, 2013, repealed the former Art. II, §§ 13-20, 13-28, 13-29, 13-37-13-40, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to abandoned and junk vehicles, and derived from Ord. No. 449, §§ 2, 9-12, adopted Aug. 20, 1975; Ord. No. 765, § 1, adopted Feb. 14, 1990; Ord. No. 1035, § 1, adopted Jan. 27, 1998; Ord. No. 1037, § 1, adopted Jan. 27, 1998; Ord. No. 1107, § 1, adopted Jan. 23, 2002; and Ord. No. 1148, § 1, adopted May 11, 2005. 

Sec. 13-20. - Purpose. 
    It is hereby declared that the parking, dismantling, or storage of inoperable vehicles or vehicle parts upon public or private property within the corporate limits of the city is a threat to the public health, welfare and safety and constitutes a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 1267, § 1, 3-27-2013) 
Sec. 13-21. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall govern the interpretation of this chapter: 
    City means the City of Mount Pleasant, Iowa. 
    Dismantle means to take apart; disassemble; tear down. 
    Inoperable vehicle means any vehicle that has any one (1) of the following characteristics: 
(1)  Any vehicle that does not display current state registration. 
(2)  Any vehicle that lacks an engine, one (1) or more wheels, or other parts that render the vehicle unable to move under its own power in both a forward and reverse gear, and make a left and right turn of at minimum ninety (90) degrees. 
(3)  Any vehicle that does not have all tires inflated. 
    Parking means the placement on public or private property of any vehicle or vehicle part for any period of time not exceeding seventy-two (72) hours. 
    Permit means to allow or fail to prevent. 
    Person means any firm, person, partnership or corporation. 
    Storage means the placement on public or private property of any vehicle or vehicle part for any consecutive period of time exceeding seventy-two (72) hours. 
    Vehicle means any implement of conveyance designed or used for the transportation of people or materials on land, water, or air, including, but not limited to, automobiles, trucks, motorcycles, snowmobiles, boats, airplanes, helicopters, tractors, trailers, campers, motor homes, wagons, etc. 
    Vehicle part means an individual component or subassembly of a vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 1267, § 1, 3-27-2013) 
Sec. 13-22. - Violation declared. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park, dismantle, or store any inoperable vehicle or vehicle part or to permit the parking, dismantling, or storage of any inoperable vehicle or vehicle part, for more than seventy-two (72) hours, other than as herein provided by section 13-30. 
(Ord. No. 1267, § 1, 3-27-2013) 
Sec. 13-23. - Owner of motor vehicle or vehicle parts prima facie responsible. 
    The owner of any inoperable vehicle or vehicle part is prima facie responsible for the parking, dismantling, or storing of such vehicle or vehicle part upon public or private property in violation of this chapter. Any owner, occupant or person in possession of real property within the city upon which one (1) or more inoperable vehicles or vehicle parts are found is prima facie responsible for permitting such parking, dismantling, or storage of any inoperable vehicle or vehicle part upon such property in violation of this chapter. No person shall be charged with more than one (1) violation of this chapter for any one (1) vehicle. The owner of an inoperable vehicle or vehicle part and the owner of real estate upon which such inoperable vehicle or vehicle part are found may both be charged. 
    Each day the owner of an inoperable vehicle or vehicle part and the owner, occupant or person in possession of real property within the city is found in violation of this chapter and permits the violation to continue after the notice period provided in section 13-24 of this chapter shall be a new violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1267, § 1, 3-27-2013) 
Sec. 13-24. - Notice. 
    Upon discovery of any inoperable motor vehicle or vehicle part stored upon private property within the corporate limits of this city, any police officer, or other city officer, official or employee having authority or responsibility for enforcement of any provisions of this Code, may notify in writing the owner of said motor vehicle or vehicle part, and the owner of the property upon which it is parked, dismantled, or stored that: 
(1)  The motor vehicle or vehicle part constitutes a violation under the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  The owner must abate the violation by removing or repairing same in accordance with the terms of section 13-25 of this chapter. 
(3)  Failure to remove or repair same shall be sufficient cause for removal and disposal by the city and assessment of costs. 
    In the alternative, the city may cause to be issued to the owner of the vehicle or vehicle part, or to the owner of the property on which the vehicle or vehicle part is found, a citation for a municipal infraction setting forth the violation of this chapter and seeking an order of removal on conviction. 
    The notice provided by this section relates only to the abatement of a violation of this chapter and is not an element of a violation, provided, however, that a second and/or any subsequent citation shall not be issued until after the notice provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 1267, § 1, 3-27-2013) 
Sec. 13-25. - Duty of owner to remove or repair. 
    The owner of the inoperable vehicle or vehicle part which violates the provisions of this chapter, or the owner of the property upon which it is parked, dismantled, or stored, shall within ten (10) days after service of a written notice from any police officer, or other city officer, official or employee having authority or responsibility for enforcement of any provisions of this Code, remove or repair same. 
(Ord. No. 1267, § 1, 3-27-2013) 
Sec. 13-26. - Abatement. 
    If the owner of an inoperable vehicle or vehicle part or the owner of the property upon which it is parked, dismantled, or stored, shall fail to remove or repair same in accordance with the requirements of section 13-25 of this chapter, any police officer, or other city officer, official or employee having authority or responsibility for enforcement of any provisions of this Code, may abate such violation by causing same to be towed to a place of safekeeping and the cost of the towing and storage shall be charged to the owner of the vehicle or vehicle part, or to the owner of the property upon which it was parked, dismantled, or stored. 
(Ord. No. 1267, § 1, 3-27-2013) 
Sec. 13-27. - Auction sale. 
    Inoperable vehicles or vehicle parts impounded by the city may be sold at auction as provided in I.C.A. § 321.89, for motor vehicles otherwise impounded. All revenues derived from the sale of inoperable vehicles or vehicle parts, however, shall accrue to the city. 
(Ord. No. 1267, § 1, 3-27-2013) 
Sec. 13-28. - Interpretation. 
    Where any other ordinance of the city is more stringent or more restrictive than the requirements set forth herein, or any ordinance of the city affords any other remedy, nothing herein shall be construed to waive or limit the use of and/or compliance with the provisions of such other ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1267, § 1, 3-27-2013) 
Sec. 13-29. - Violation. 
    A violation of any of the provisions of this chapter may be charged as a municipal infraction or a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 1267, § 1, 3-27-2013) 
Sec. 13-30. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to inoperable vehicles or vehicle parts parked, stored, or dismantled: 
(1)  Within a garage or other fully enclosed building. 
(2)  Within a fully enclosed vehicle. 
(3)  On the premises of a business operating in a properly zoned area, when necessary to the operation of said business, as authorized under the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1267, § 1, 3-27-2013) 
Secs. 13-31-13-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GRASS AND WEEDS 

Sec. 13-41. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to beautify and preserve the appearance of the city by requiring property owners and occupants to maintain grass lawns at a uniform height within the boundaries of their property and on abutting street right-of-way in order to prevent unsightly, offensive or nuisance conditions. 
(Ord. No. 1283, § 1, 6-11-2014) 
Sec. 13-42. - Definitions. 
    For use in this article, the following terms are defined: 
    Curb , curb line , or curbing means the outer boundaries of a street at the edge of that portion of the street usually traveled by vehicular traffic. 
    Cut or mow means to mechanically maintain the growth of grass, weeds or brush at a uniform height. 
    Owner means a person owning private property in the city and any person occupying private property in the city. 
    Parking means that part of a street, avenue or highway in the city not covered by a sidewalk and lying between the lot line or property line and the curb line; or on unpaved streets, that part of the street lying between the lot line or property line and that portion of the street usually traveled by vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. No. 1283, § 1, 6-11-2014) 
Sec. 13-43. - Cutting specifications and standards of practice. 
(a)  Every property owner shall cut, mow, and maintain all grass, weeds, and brush upon the owner's property and adjacent to the curb line or outer boundary of any street, which shall include the parking area abutting the owner's property, to a uniform height as defined in section 13-44. 
(b)  Every property owner shall cut, mow, and maintain grass, weeds, and brush adjacent to the curb line, including the parking area abutting the owner's property in such a manner so as to be in conformity with and at an even height with all other grass, weeds, or brush growing on the remainder of the owner's property. 
(c)  Vacant and undeveloped property are exempted from subsections (a) and (b), except for the area within one hundred (100) feet of the property line where adjoining an improved street, alley, or developed property including all areas between the property line and the centerline of a street, alley, or easement. 
(Ord. No. 1283, § 1, 6-11-2014) 
Sec. 13-44. - Uniform height specifications. 
    Grass, weeds, or brush shall be cut, mowed, and maintained so as not to exceed the following height specifications: 
(1)  Developed residential areas - not to exceed six (6) inches. 
(2)  Undeveloped residential areas - not to exceed six (6) inches. 
(3)  Business and industrial areas - not to exceed six (6) inches. 
(4)  Agriculture areas not exempted by subsection 13-43(c) - not to exceed fifteen (15) inches. 
    Grass, weeds, and brush which are allowed to grow in excess of the above specified limitations shall be deemed to be a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1283, § 1, 6-11-2014) 
Sec. 13-45. - Noxious weeds. 
(a)  Every property owner shall cut and control noxious weeds upon the owner's property and adjacent to the curb line or outer boundary of any street, which shall include the parking area abutting the owner's property, by cutting noxious weeds to ground level or use of herbicides to eliminate or eradicate such weeds. 
(b)  Noxious weeds include any weed growth or plant designated as noxious by the State Department of Natural Resources rules or regulations or by the Code of Iowa. 
(Ord. No. 1283, § 1, 6-11-2014) 
Sec. 13-46. - Abatement procedure. 
    Upon discovery of any violation of this chapter by the mayor, community service officer, or other authorized municipal officer, such officer shall cause to be served upon the property owner a written notice to abate the nuisance within seven days. The city shall abate the nuisance, if the nuisance is not abated within seven days of the notice being served, the city shall abate the nuisance and assess the cost of abatement to the property owner. The cost of abatement shall be the actual cost to abate the nuisance and an administrative fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. No. 1283, § 1, 6-11-2014; Ord. No. 1314, § 1, 4-27-2016) 
Sec. 13-47. - Notification. 
    Notification may be in the form of an ordinance or sent by regular mail to the recorded property owner as listed in the records of the Henry County Assessor, Mount Pleasant, Iowa. Notification in the form of an ordinance means formal notice will be given to all residents, by publication in the city's official newspaper that if a violation of chapter 13, article III exists on their property the city will proceed with abatement procedures immediately upon discovery of such violation. When the nuisance exists on a property occupied by a structure the city will attempt to post a notice to abate on or near the front entrance of the residence or business, prior to the city abating it and assessing the costs against the property owner. If the nuisance exists on an empty lot notice to abate will be issued only in the form of a certified letter to the property owner as listed in the records of the Henry County Assessor. 
(Ord. No. 1283, § 1, 6-11-2014) 
Sec. 13-48. - Notice to abate: Contents. 
    The notice to abate shall contain: 
(1)  A description of what constitutes the nuisance. 
(2)  The location of the nuisance. 
(3)  A statement of the act or acts necessary to abate the nuisance. 
(4)  A statement that the nuisance is to be abated within seven (7) days. 
(5)  A statement that if the nuisance or condition is not abated as directed and no request for hearing is made within seven (7) days of the notice, the city will abate it and assess the costs against such person. 
(Ord. No. 1283, § 1, 6-11-2014) 
Sec. 13-49. - Request for hearing. 
    Any person ordered to abate a nuisance may have a hearing with the city administrator as to whether a nuisance exists. A request for a hearing must be made in writing and delivered to the city clerk within the time stated in the notice, or it will be conclusively presumed that a nuisance exists and it must be abated as ordered. 
(Ord. No. 1283, § 1, 6-11-2014) 
Sec. 13-50. - Abatement in emergency. 
    If it is determined that an emergency exists by reason of the continuing the nuisance or condition, the city may perform any action which may be required under this article without prior notice. 
(Ord. No. 1283, § 1, 6-11-2014) 
Sec. 13-51. - Collection of city's costs. 
    Any and all costs incurred by the city in the abatement of a nuisance under the provisions of this article shall be certified to the county auditor as a special tax against such lot or parcel of ground or the person causing or maintaining the nuisance, and shall be collected the same as other property taxes. 
(Ord. No. 1283, § 1, 6-11-2014) 
Chapter 14 - OFFENSES-MISCELLANEOUS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Public consumption of alcoholic beverages, § 3-2. 
State Law reference- Municipal home rule powers, I.C.A. § 364.1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Failure to appear in court or answer summons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to appear in the district court when properly summoned or to fail to appear at the date and time specified in any traffic citation or other citation for the violation of any law or ordinance. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, I.C.A. §§ 804.1, 805.5. 
Secs. 14-2-14-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PERSONS 

Sec. 14-16. - Assault. 
(a)  A person commits an assault when, without justification, the person does any of the following: 
(1)  Any act which is intended to cause pain or injury to, or which is intended to result in physical contact which will be insulting or offensive to, another, coupled with the apparent ability to execute the act. 
(2)  Any act which is intended to place another in fear of immediate physical contact which will be painful, injurious, insulting or offensive, coupled with the apparent ability to execute the act. 
(3)  Intentionally points any firearm toward another, or displays in a threatening manner any dangerous weapon toward another. 
    Provided, that where the person doing any of the above enumerated acts, and such other person, are voluntary participants in a sport, social or other activity, not in itself criminal, and such act is a reasonably foreseeable incident of such sport or activity, and does not create an unreasonable risk of serious injury or breach of the peace, the act shall not be an assault. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to commit an assault. 
(Code 1969, §§ 7.12.010, 7.12.020, 7.16.020) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, I.C.A. § 708.1. 
Secs. 14-17-14-27. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 

Sec. 14-28. - Reserved. 
Sec. 14-29. - Trespass. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term "property" shall include any land, dwelling, building, conveyance, vehicle or other temporary or permanent structure whether publicly or privately owned. 
(b)  As used herein the term "trespass" shall mean one or more of the following acts: 
(1)  Entering upon or in property without justification or without the implied or actual permission of the owner, lessee or person in lawful possession with the intent to commit a public offense or to use, remove therefrom, alter, damage, harass or place thereon or therein anything, animate or inanimate, without justification, or without the implied or actual permission of the owner, lessee or person in lawful possession. 
(2)  Entering or remaining upon or in property without justification after being notified or requested to abstain from entering or to remove or vacate therefrom by the owner, lessee or person in lawful possession, or the agent or employee of the owner, lessee or person in lawful possession, or by any peace officer, magistrate or public employee whose duty it is to supervise the use or maintenance of the property. 
(3)  Entering upon or in property for the purpose or with the effect of unduly interfering with the lawful use of the property by others.
