(4)  Being upon or in property and wrongfully using, removing therefrom, altering, damaging, harassing or placing thereon or therein anything, animate or inanimate, without the implied or actual permission of the owner, lessee or person in lawful possession. 
    The term "trespass" shall not mean entering upon the property of another for the sole purpose of retrieving personal property which has accidentally or inadvertently been thrown, fallen, strayed or blown onto the property of another; provided that the person retrieving the property takes the most direct and accessible route to and from the property to be retrieved, quits the property as quickly as is possible, and does not unduly interfere with the lawful use of the property. 
(c)  Any person who knowingly trespasses upon the property of another commits a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, §§ 7.36.030, 7.36.040) 
State Law reference- Trespass, I.C.A., §§ 716.7, 716.8. 
Sec. 14-30. - Criminal mischief. 
(a)  Any damage, defacing, alteration or destruction of tangible property is criminal mischief when done intentionally by one who has no right to so act. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to commit an act of criminal mischief if the cost of repairing, replacing or restoring the property which has been damaged, defaced, altered or destroyed is one hundred dollars ($100.00) or less. 
(Code 1969, §§ 7.08.090, 7.36.030, 7.36.050, 7.36.070, 7.36.130) 
State Law reference- Criminal mischief, Iowa Criminal Code, Ch. 1, § 1601 et seq. 
Sec. 14-31. - Peeping Toms. 
    No person shall perform such acts as will make him a Peeping Tom on or about the premises of another, or go upon the premises of another for the purpose of becoming a Peeping Tom. 
    Peeping Tom, as used in this section, means one who peeps through windows or doors, or other like places, situated on or about the premises of another for the purposes of spying upon or invading the privacy of persons spied upon without the consent of the person spied upon. It is not a necessary element of this offense that the Peeping Tom be upon the premises of the person being spied upon. 
(Code 1969, § 7.08.170) 
Sec. 14-32. - Posting bills on property. 
    Any person who defaces any private or public property within the city by posting, pasting, tacking, sticking or nailing thereon any advertising bills, posters or any other written or printed matter, except legal notices provided by law, or in any manner defaces same, without first having obtained the written consent of the owner or agent of such property, is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 7.36.080) 
Sec. 14-33. - Driving over public property. 
    No person shall run or drive any vehicle over or across any wire, rope, chain, cable or device used by any public employee in the performance of his official duty without the permission of the person in lawful charge of same. 
(Code 1969, § 7.36.140) 
Sec. 14-34. - Interfering with motor vehicles. 
    No person shall willfully remove, injure, destroy, meddle or interfere with, or put out of adjustment, any apparatus or equipment attached to any motor vehicle, or injure, deface, meddle or interfere with any motor vehicle in any other manner without the consent of the owner or the person in lawful charge thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 7.36.160) 
Sec. 14-35. - Hazardous substances. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  Hazardous waste means those wastes which are included in section 455B.411(3)(a) of the Code of Iowa, and the rules of the Department of Natural Resources. 
(2)  Hazardous substance means any substance as defined in section 455B.381(5) of the Code of Iowa. 
(3)  Hazardous condition means the same as set out in section 455B.381(4) of the Code of Iowa. 
(4)  Person having control over a hazardous substance means the same as set out in section 455B.381(7) of the Code of Iowa. 
(5)  Clean up means the same as set out in section 455B.381(1) of the Code of Iowa. 
(6)  Treatment means a method, technique, or process, including neutralization, designed to change the physical, chemical or biological character or composition of a hazardous substance so as to neutralize it or to render the substance nonhazardous, safe for transport, amenable for recovery, amenable for storage, or to reduce it in volume. Treatment includes any activity or processing designed to change the physical form or chemical composition of hazardous substance to render it nonhazardous. 
(b)  Clean up required. Whenever a hazardous condition is created by the deposit, injection, dumping, spilling, leaking or placing of a hazardous waste or substance so that the hazardous waste or substance or a constituent of the hazardous water or substance may enter the environment or be emitted into the air or discharged into any waters, including groundwaters, the person having control over the hazardous waste or substance shall cause the condition to be remedied by a clean up, as defined in the preceding section, as rapidly as feasible to an acceptable, safe condition. The costs of clean up shall be borne by the person having control over the hazardous waste or substance. If the person having control over the hazardous waste or substance does not cause the clean up to begin in a reasonable time in relation to the hazard and circumstances of the incident the city may, by an authorized officer, give to the person having control over the hazardous waste or substance, reasonable notice, based on the character of the hazardous condition, said notice setting deadlines for commencing and completing the clean up and stating that in the event the person having control over the hazardous waste or substance fails to comply with said deadlines, the city may proceed to procure cleanup services and bill the responsible person for all reasonable expenses associated with the clean up. If the bill for services is not paid within thirty (30) days, the city attorney shall proceed to obtain payment by all legal means. If the type or cost of the clean up is beyond the capacity of the city to remedy, the authorized officer shall report to the city council and immediately seek any state or federal assistance or funds for said clean up. 
(c)  Notification. The first city officer or employee who arrives at the scene of an incident involving hazardous wastes or substances, if not a peace officer, shall notify the police department which shall notify the proper state office as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 905, § 7-13-94) 
Secs. 14-36-14-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST MORALS 

Sec. 14-46. - Gambling prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to participate in any game for any sum of money or other property of any value or make any bet or wager for money or other property of value or engage in bookmaking. 
(Code 1969, § 7.28.010) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, I.C.A. § 725.7. 
Sec. 14-47. - Keeping gambling house. 
    Any person who keeps a house, shop or place resorted to for the purpose of gambling, or permits or suffers any person in any house, shop or other place under his control or care to conduct bookmaking or to play at cards, dice, faro, roulette, equality, punchboard, slot machine or other game for money or other things is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 7.28.020) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, I.C.A. § 725.5. 
Sec. 14-48. - Prostitution. 
    A person who sells or offers for sale his or her services as a partner in a sex act, or who purchases or offers to purchase such services, commits a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 7.20.020) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, I.C.A., § 725.1. 
Sec. 14-49. - Leasing premises for prostitution. 
    A person who has rented or let any building, structure or part thereof, boat, trailer or other place offering shelter or seclusion, and who knows, or has reason to know, that the lessee or tenant is using such for the purposes of prostitution, and who does not, immediately upon acquiring such knowledge, terminate the tenancy or effectively put an end to such practice of prostitution in such place, commits a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 7.02.010) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, I.C.A., § 725.4. 
Sec. 14-50. - Urinating or defecating in public. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to urinate or defecate in or upon any street, alley, public place or in any place open to public view, provided that this section shall not apply to restrooms or public facilities designated for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 519, § 1, 12-19-79) 
Secs. 14-51-14-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OTHER OFFENSES 

Sec. 14-61. - Riots. 
    A riot is three (3) or more persons assembled together in a violent manner, to the disturbance of others, and with any use of unlawful force or violence by them or any of them against another person, or causing property damage. A person who willingly joins in or remains a part of a riot, knowing or having reasonable grounds to believe that it is such, commits a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 7.16.050) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, I.C.A., § 723.1. 
Sec. 14-62. - Unlawful assembly. 
    An unlawful assembly is three (3) or more persons assembled together, with them or any of them acting in a violent manner, and with intent that they or any of them will commit a public offense. A person who willingly joins in or remains a part of an unlawful assembly, knowing or having reasonable grounds to believe that it is such, commits a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 7.16.040) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, I.C.A., § 723.2. 
Sec. 14-63. - Failure to disperse. 
    A peace officer may order the participants in a riot or unlawful assembly or persons in the immediate vicinity of a riot or unlawful assembly to disperse. Any person within hearing distance of such command, who refuses to obey, commits a misdemeanor. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, I.C.A., § 723.3. 
Sec. 14-64. - Discharging firearms. 
    No person, except in proper defense of himself or property, or a peace officer in the performance of his duties, shall discharge any cannon, gun, rifle or other firearm. 
(Code 1969, § 7.52.010) 
Sec. 14-65. - Carrying weapons. 
    A person who goes armed with a dangerous weapon concealed on or about his person, or who, within the limits of any city, goes armed with a pistol or revolver, or any loaded firearm of any kind, whether concealed or not, or who knowingly carries or transports in a vehicle a pistol or revolver, commits a misdemeanor, provided that this section shall not apply to any of the following: 
(1)  A person who goes armed with a dangerous weapon in his or her own dwelling or place of business, or on land owned or possessed by the person. 
(2)  Any peace officer, when his or her duties require the person to carry such weapons. 
(3)  Any member of the armed forces of the United States or of the national guard or person in the service of the United States, when the weapons are carried in connection with his or her duties as such. 
(4)  Any person who for any lawful purpose carries an unloaded pistol, revolver or other dangerous weapon inside a closed and fastened container or securely wrapped package which is too large to be concealed on the person. 
(5)  Any person who for any lawful purpose carries or transports an unloaded pistol or revolver in any vehicle inside a cargo or luggage compartment where the pistol or revolver will not be readily accessible to any person riding in the vehicle or common carrier. 
(6)  Any person while he or she is lawfully engaged in target practice on a range designed for that purpose or while engaged in lawful hunting for game in any place designated by local law as a hunting area. 
(7)  Any person who has in his or her possession and who displays to any peace officer on demand a valid permit to carry weapons which has been issued to the person, and whose conduct is within the limits of that permit. No person shall be convicted of a violation of this section if the person produces at his or her trial a permit to carry weapons which was valid at the time of the alleged offense and which would have brought the person's conduct within this exception if the permit had been produced at the time of the alleged offense. 
(8)  Any correctional officer, when his or her duties require, serving under the authority of the division of adult corrections. 
(Code 1969, § 7.52.020) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, I.C.A., § 724.4. 
Sec. 14-66. - Air guns, bows, sticks and similar projectiles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot or discharge any bow, air gun, pellet gun, slingshot, wrist rocket or similar device. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to throw any stone or stick with the intent of damaging or defacing any private or public property or with the intent to cause injury to any person or animal. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, the parks and recreation director, with prior approval of the city council, may establish locations within the city where the use of the above devices may be permitted. The parks and recreation director shall promulgate appropriate rules and regulations governing the use of these facilities, which rules and regulations shall receive prior approval of the city council. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to utilize any such facility established by the city contrary to the rules and regulations as posted at the facility site or as available from the parks and recreation department. 
(Code 1969, §§ 7.08.130, 7.08.140; Ord. No. 781, § 1, 6-27-90) 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, Ch. 15. 
Sec. 14-67. - Disorderly conduct. 
    A person commits a misdemeanor when the person does any of the following: 
(1)  Engages in fighting or violent behavior in any public place or in or near any lawful assembly of persons, provided, that participants in athletic contests may engage in such conduct which is reasonably related to that sport. 
(2)  Makes loud and raucous noise in the vicinity of any residence or hospital which causes unreasonable distress to the occupants thereof. 
(3)  Directs abusive epithets or makes any threatening gesture which the person knows or reasonably should know is likely to provoke a violent reaction by another. 
(4)  Without lawful authority or color of authority, the person disturbs any lawful assembly or meeting of persons by conduct intended to disrupt the meeting or assembly. 
(5)  By words or action, initiates or circulates a report or warning of fire, epidemic or other catastrophe, knowing such report to be false or such warning to be baseless. 
(6)  Knowingly and publicly uses the flag of the United States in such a manner as to show disrespect for the flag as a symbol of the United States, with the intent or reasonable expectation that such use will provoke or encourage another to commit a public offense. 
(7)  Without authority or justification, the person obstructs any street, sidewalk, highway or other public way, with the intent to prevent or hinder its lawful use by others. 
(Code 1969, §§ 17.12.030, 17.16.030; Ord. No. 427, § 2, 2-20-74) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, I.C.A., § 723.3. 
Sec. 14-68. - Spitting. 
    No person shall expectorate or spit upon any sidewalk or upon the floor of any public building, hallway, steps, cellarway, stairway, window, public motor bus or depot platform. 
(Code 1969, § 7.40.220) 
Sec. 14-69. - Regulation of amplified sound sources. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section "plainly audible" means any sound that can be detected by any person using his or her unaided hearing facilities. If the sound source under investigation is a portable or vehicular sound amplification or reproduction device, the enforcement officer need not determine the title of a song, specific words, or the artist performing the song. The detection of the rhythmic bass component of the music is sufficient to constitute a plainly audible sound. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to operate personal or commercial music amplification or reproduction equipment in such a manner that is plainly audible at a distance of one hundred (100) feet in any direction from the source. 
(c)  Self-contained, portable, hand-held music or sound amplification or reproductive equipment shall not be operated on a public space or public right-of-way in such a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of one hundred (100) feet in any direction from the source. 
(d)  The following amplified sound sources are exempt from the provisions of this section: 
(1)  The Mount Pleasant Aquatic Center public announcement and sound system. 
(2)  An amplified sound systems operated by persons or organizations who have obtained prior approval of the city council for its use during an approved event. 
(3)  Emergency short-term operations that are necessary to protect the health and welfare of the citizens. 
(4)  Bells, chimes and similar devices that signal the time of day and operate during the daytime hours for a duration of no longer than five (5) minutes in any given one-hour period. 
(Ord. No. 1152, § 1, 8-11-2005) 
Editor's note- Formerly, Ord. No. 970, § 1, adopted Jan. 8, 1997, amended this Code by repealing § 14-69, which pertained to curfew for minors and was derived from Code 1969, §§ 7.64.010-7.64.060. 
Sec. 14-70. - Interference with city officers or employees. 
    No person shall willfully prevent or attempt to prevent any city officer or employee from performing the officer's or employee's duty. 
(Code 1969, § 7.08.080) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, I.C.A., § 718.4. 
Sec. 14-71. - Fortune-tellers, palmists and clairvoyants prohibited. 
    The following businesses and vocations are hereby prohibited: 
(1)  Fortune-tellers; 
(2)  Palmist; 
(3)  Clairvoyant. 
(Code 1969, § 4.16.010) 
Sec. 14-72. - Outdoor use of indoor furnishings. 
    It shall be a violation of this section for any landowner or person leasing, occupying or having control of any real property used for residential purposes, to keep, store, maintain, deposit or perform or permit on such property, the outdoor use, outdoor storage or outdoor placement of household appliances, household furniture, or household furnishings, unless such items are designed for outdoor use and are used on the premises for purposes of the household. The term "outdoor" includes a porch. However, the use, storage or placement of household appliances, household furniture or household furnishings on a porch is not prohibited, if the porch is completely enclosed by fully intact glass or fully intact screens. 
    The following shall constitute an affirmative defense to any alleged violation of this provision: a) that the furniture of appliance was temporarily placed outside during the move of a resident; or b) that the furniture was temporarily placed outside during the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. in order that it be offered for sale at a yard or garage sale and that a sign visible from the right-of-way is placed on or near the furniture indicating that it is for sale. The second defense is not available if the furniture is located outside for more than two (2) days in any six-month period. 
(Ord. No. 1225, § 1, 8-11-2010) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 970, § 1, adopted Jan. 8, 1997, amended this Code by repealing § 14-72, which pertained to loitering and was derived from Ord. No. 489, §§ 1-3, adopted Nov. 16, 1977. 
 Subsequently, section 1 of Ord. No. 1225, adopted Aug. 11, 2010, added new provisions as set out herein. 
Sec. 14-73. - No hunting within city. 
    It shall be a violation of this section for any person to pursue, hunt, kill, snare, net, search for, shoot at, stalk, or lie in wait for any game, animal, or bird with an air gun, BB gun, firearm, bow and arrow, or any other thrown or propelled device within the city limits. 
    Exception. Nothing herein shall prohibit the hunting with bow and arrow of deer during those periods designated annually by the Iowa Department of Natural Resources for such hunting by persons issued licenses by the Iowa Department of Natural Resources and issued permits by the city, provided that such hunting is in done in compliance with the regulations established by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1233, § 1, 1-26-2011; Ord. No. 1266, § 1, 3-27-2013) 
Sec. 14-74. - Fireworks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, or entity, to possess, store, offer for sale, sell or explode any fireworks, except as allowed by state law. It shall be unlawful for any person, or entity, to possess or explode any fireworks on any city-owned or leased property, including, but not limited to, city parks and trails, without a permit approved by city council. 
(Ord. No. 1330, § 1, 5-31-2017) 
Chapter 15 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Public library, Ch. 19; parks and recreation fees, § 25-14. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 661, § 1, adopted Dec. 4, 1985, amended Art. I, §§ 15-1-15-7, contained similar subject matter and derived from Code 1969, §§ 7.63.100, 8.60.080, 17.36.170-17.36.200; Ord. No. 483, § 3, adopted July 20, 1977; Ord. No. 537, §§ 3-6, adopted June 25, 1980; and Ord. No. 555, § 1, adopted June 3, 1981. 

Sec. 15-1. - Injury or destruction of vegetation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully cut, break, injure, destroy or interfere with any tree, shrub, flower, bush or any other planting in any public park. 
(Ord. No. 661, § 1, 12-4-85) 
Sec. 15-2. - Closing hours. 
    All city parks, except United Through Play Park, will be closed to the public from the hours of 10:30 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. daily, except as hereinafter provided. United Through Play Park shall be closed daily from sunset to sunrise. All persons in a public park shall leave promptly at closing time. No persons shall remain in a park or use the park facilities during the hours of closing. This section shall not apply to city employees working in parks, or to scheduled public activities or events which have been submitted to and approved by the city council or the director of the recreation department, or persons in the authorized camping area of McMillan Park which is designated to be that area immediately to the north of the east gate entrance. It shall be unlawful for any person to be in any city park after closing. 
(Ord. No. 661, § 1, 12-4-85; Ord. No. 1348, § 1(Amd. 1), 4-11-2018) 
Sec. 15-3. - Vehicles and animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle or drive or ride a horse on the pedestrian walkways, or over the grass lawns, or cultivated areas in any city park, except for the use of parking or crossing areas authorized and designated by the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle, motorcycle, go-karts and all-terrain vehicles on the dirt race track at McMillan Park, except for special public events by prior written authorization of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 661, § 1, 12-4-85) 
Sec. 15-4. - Alcoholic beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use or consume beer or any alcoholic beverages in any city park, except where a special public activity or event has been submitted to and approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 661, § 1, 12-4-85) 
Sec. 15-5. - Swimming. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to swim, bathe or wade in any city park with the exception of the city pool, located in Saunders Park, and only then while the pool is officially open. 
(Ord. No. 661, § 1, 12-4-85) 
Sec. 15-6. - Boating. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a boat, raft or canoe in any city park without prior written authorization of the city council, the director of parks and recreation, or a city police officer. 
(Ord. No. 661, § 1, 12-4-85; Ord. No. 969, § 1, 1-8-97) 
Sec. 15-7. - Camping in parks. 
    Camping is unlawful in any city park except that area designated in McMillan Park as stated in section 15-2, or as designated in East Park or Saunders Park when approved by the city council or the director of parks and recreation. A camping permit for McMillan Park must be obtained from the police department after a payment of a daily fee in the amount established in section 25-14(c)(4). 
(Ord. No. 661, § 1, 12-4-85; Ord. No. 856, § 1, 11-11-92; Ord. No. 969, § 1, 1-8-97) 
Sec. 15-8. - Fires. 
    Fires are unlawful in any city park, unless they are contained in a fire ring, fireplace, barbecue grill or other device provided by the city parks department. A privately owned barbecue grill may be used for a charcoal fire only. 
(Ord. No. 661, § 1, 12-4-85) 
Sec. 15-9. - Hunting or trapping. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to hunt, shoot, trap, chase, pursue, catch or disturb any animal in any city park unless there is prior written authorization by the city council or the city police department. 
(b)  No firearms, traps of any kind, air rifles, slingshots, bows or crossbows, blowguns or explosive material shall be used or kept or permitted in any city park, unless they are broken down or taken apart and secured within a carrying case or in a trunk of a car, and unless there is prior written authorization by the city council or city police department. 
(Ord. No. 661, § 1, 12-4-85) 
Sec. 15-10. - Peddling and advertising. 
    It shall be unlawful to peddle, hawk, solicit, beg, advertise, or carry on business or other commercial enterprises within a city park, unless there is prior written authorization by the city council or director of parks and recreation. 
(Ord. No. 661, § 1, 12-4-85; Ord. No. 969, § 1, 1-8-97) 
Sec. 15-11. - Animals on leash. 
    It shall be unlawful for any privately owned animal to run at large in a city park. Every such animal shall be deemed as running at large, unless the owner carries such animal or leads it by a leash or chain not exceeding six (6) feet in length or keeps it confined or attached to a vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 661, § 1, 12-4-85) 
Sec. 15-12. - Ice skating. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ice skate on any city lake, pond or pool, with the exception of Crane's Pond, and only on Crane's Pond when the director of parks and recreation or his designee permits ice skating by posting a sign stating "Skating Allowed." 
(Ord. No. 730, § 1, 2-8-89) 
Secs. 15-13-15-19. - Reserved. 
Sec. 15-20. - Definitions. 
    "City park" is any city-owned property that is designated as a city park or recreation area. This includes McMillan Park, Saunders Park, East Park, Cranes Pond, Greensquare Park, Shaeffer Park, Central Park, United Through Play Park, and any other properties that may be designated as a city park or recreation area in the future. 
(Ord. No. 661, § 1, 12-4-85; Ord. No. 1348, § 1(Amd. 2), 4-11-2018) 
Sec. 15-20.1. - Fees. 
    All fees required for the use of the city park shelters, park buildings, park open areas, or municipal pool shall be in the amounts established in section 25-14(a) through (d). 
(Ord. No. 857, § 1, 11-11-92) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 857, § 1, adopted November 11, 1992, amended the Code by adding a new § 15-21. Inasmuch as such section already existed, such new provisions were codified as § 15-20.1 at the discretion of the editor. 
ARTICLE II. - PARK AND RECREATION BOARD[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 11 of Ord. No. 713, adopted May 11, 1988, repealed Art. II, §§ 15-21-15-24, pertaining to the recreation program and originating from Ord. No. 493, §§ I-IV, adopted Mar. 15, 1978. Provisions of §§ 1-10 of Ord. No. 713, dealing with the park and recreation board, have been codified by the editor as a new Art. II to read as herein set out in §§ 15-21-15-30. 
Cross reference- Appointive position of building and zoning administrator, § 2-18(a)(6); planning and zoning commission, § 17-16 et seq.; community development committee, § 17-41 et seq.; zoning, App. D. 

Sec. 15-21. - Created. 
    A park and recreation board is hereby created to advise the council on the needed facilities to provide open space, such as parks, playgrounds and community facilities for other forms of recreation. It shall also plan and monitor city programs and encourage other programs for the leisure time of the city's residents of all ages. 
(Ord. No. 713, § 1, 5-11-88) 
Sec. 15-22. - Organization; membership; appointment; terms. 
    The board shall consist of seven (7) members. At least six (6) of the members shall be residents of the City of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa, and one (1) member may be a nonresident of the City of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa, provided such nonresident resides in Henry County, Iowa. Each member shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the council, for overlapping three-year terms. The mayor shall designate the terms of the first appointed members, and the first chairperson and vice chairperson; and the board shall choose its chairperson and vice chairperson annually thereafter. Members shall serve without compensation but may receive their actual expenses. The first board to be appointed shall have its initial terms designated by the mayor so that three (3) members will serve one (1) year; three (3) shall serve two (2) years; and one (1) shall serve (3) years. Thereafter, terms shall be for three (3) years, and vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as original appointments. 
(Ord. No. 713, § 2, 5-11-88; Ord. No. 898, § 1, 3-9-94) 
Sec. 15-23. - Duties generally. 
    In addition to its duty to make a plan for recreation and for the facilities for recreation, and to update and revise these plans as required, the board shall have advisory authority over the properties and personnel devoted to parks and recreation, subject to the limitation of expenditures for salaries and supplies, contracts and capital outlays set forth in the annual budget provided by the council for park and recreation operations; and it shall cooperate with the director of public works and/or the director of parks and recreation in the allotment of time of city employees for park and recreation purposes. 
(1)  The board shall adopt rules and regulations to govern procedure and shall, by vote, set a time for regular meetings, which would be held at least monthly, and shall determine the manner in which special meetings may be held and the notice given. A majority of the regular members constitute a quorum. Absence from three (3) consecutive regular meetings without formal consent of the chairperson shall be deemed to constitute the retirement of such member, and the position shall be declared vacant. Minutes of the board meeting shall be filed with the city clerk and the mayor. 
(2)  The board shall act in an advisory capacity to the council and the director of parks and recreation in all matters pertaining to public recreation and to cooperate with other government agencies and civic groups in the advancement of sound park and recreation planning and programming. 
(3)  The board shall formulate policy on park and recreation services for approval by the council. 
(4)  The board shall advise the city council as to the minimum qualifications for the position of director of parks and recreation and assist the personnel committee of the council in selecting a qualified candidate for appointment to the position by the council as provided hereafter. 
(5)  The board shall advise the council after consultation with the director of parks and recreation on problems of administration, development of recreation areas, facilities, programs and improved recreation services. 
(6)  The board shall recommend the adoption of standards on organization, personnel, areas and facilities, program and financial support. 
(7)  The board shall make periodic inventories of recreation services that exist, or may be needed, and interpret the needs of the public to the council and to the director of parks and recreation. 
(8)  The board shall make periodic appraisals of the effectiveness of the director and staff in administering the program. 
(9)  The board shall interpret the policies and functions of the department to the public. The board shall advise the director of parks and recreation in the preparation of the annual budget and a long-range recreation and parks capital improvement program. 
(Ord. No. 713, § 3, 5-11-88) 
Sec. 15-24. - Director of parks and recreation; appointment; duties generally. 
(a)  The mayor shall appoint, with the consent of the council and upon recommendations of the board, a director to administer the parks and recreation program. 
(b)  The director shall attend meetings of the board; shall serve as secretary to the board; and shall make such reports to the board or to the council as shall be required. In addition to the foregoing, the director shall: 
(1)  Employ required personnel, such as assistants, supervisors, leaders and clerical and maintenance employees, and supervise them in the performance of their various duties; 
(2)  Administer, operate and maintain existing recreation areas and facilities and plan for the acquisition, development and operation of those facilities in accordance with the policies approved by the board and the council; 
(3)  Conduct and supervise any form of recreational, cultural or social activity that will employ the leisure time of the citizens in a wholesome and constructive manner; 
(4)  Inform the general public of the services and facilities being provided by the department; 
(5)  Solicit suggestions from the general public to improve or increase the effectiveness of the service; 
(6)  Cooperate with governmental and voluntary organizations and agencies in the furtherance of recreation opportunities; 
(7)  Prepare manuals, bulletins and reviews on recreation problems; 
(8)  Provide, upon request, assistance of a technical nature to community agencies and organizations having problems relating to recreation and park areas, and facilities and programs; 
(9)  Counsel with officials of public and private organizations and interested groups concerning community recreation and park services; 
(10)  Conduct studies of local conditions and needs for recreation and park services and assist with recruitment and training of recreation and park personnel; and 
(11)  Prepare a budget for approval of the board and present the budget to the council. 
(Ord. No. 713, § 4, 5-11-88) 
Sec. 15-25. - Recreation fund. 
    There is hereby established a park and recreation fund. The director of parks and recreation, after consultation with the park and recreation board, shall annually submit a budget to the council for its approval in whole or in part. Said budget should provide not only for recreation services, park maintenance and operating costs for the ensuing year, but should also contain estimates and recommendations for such long-term capital outlay as may be necessary to provide for orderly and coordinated development of the park and recreation program. 
(Ord. No. 713, § 5, 5-11-88) 
Sec. 15-26. - Limitations of the board. 
    The park and recreation board shall not pledge the credit of or the taxing power of the city this being specifically reserved unto the council. 
(Ord. No. 713, § 6, 5-11-88) 
Sec. 15-27. - Contracts. 
    The park and recreation board shall not contract or enter into agreements, payment of which is in excess of any amount budgeted therefor. All other contracts or agreements shall be recommended to and approved by the council. 
(Ord. No. 713, § 7, 5-11-88) 
Sec. 15-28. - Reports. 
    The board shall make written reports to the council of its activities from time to time, as it deems advisable or upon council request. Its revenues and expenditures shall be reported monthly by the clerk in the manner of other departmental revenues and expenditures, and a copy shall be provided to each member of the board and in the clerk's report to the council. 
(Ord. No. 713, § 8, 5-11-88) 
Sec. 15-29. - Rules. 
    The board shall have the power to make rules and regulations for the use of parks or other recreational facilities or for the conduct of recreational programs, subject to the approval of the rules by the council. Such rules shall be either posted on the facility or otherwise publicized in a manner to provide adequate notice to the using public. 
(Ord. No. 713, § 9, 5-11-88) 
Sec. 15-30. - Violation; penalty; appeal. 
    The violation of a board rule, which has been approved by the city council and adopted by ordinance, may be cause for the denial of the use of a facility or participation in a program; but such denial, which extends to more than one (1) day, may be appealed to the board or to the city council, whichever is applicable, for a hearing. The appeal hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures set forth in the Mt. Pleasant Administrative Code (chapter 2, article VIII). 
(Ord. No. 713, § 10, 5-11-88; Ord. No. 952, § 1, 1-10-96) 
Chapter 16 - PEDDLERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Application fee for peddlers, § 25-21. 
State Law reference- Municipal home rule powers, I.C.A. § 364.1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Definition. 
    For use in this article the following terms are defined: 
    Peddler means any person carrying or transporting goods or merchandise who sells or offers for sale for immediate delivery such goods or merchandise from house to house or upon the public street. 
    Solicitor means any person who solicits or attempts to solicit from house to house or upon public streets, orders for commercial goods, wares, subscriptions, publications, periodicals, merchandise or services to be delivered or fulfilled at a future date. For the purposes of this article, "solicitor" does not include a person who contacts another person at his or her residence without prior invitation to enlist support for or against or solicit funds for patriotic, philanthropic, charitable, political or religious purposes, whether or not there is an incidental purpose involving the sale of some goods or services. 
    Transient merchant includes every merchant, whether an individual person, a firm, corporation, partnership or association, and whether owner, agent, bailee, consignee or employee, who brings or causes to be brought within the city any goods, wares or merchandise of any kind, nature or description, with the intention of temporarily or intermittently selling or offering to sell at retail such goods, wares or merchandise. A merchant engaging in business shall be presumed to be temporarily or intermittently in business unless it is the intention of such merchant to remain continuously in business within the city as a merchant for a period of more than sixty (60) days. 
(Code 1969, §§ 4.08.040, 4.08.050, 4.32.010; Ord. No. 1149, § 1, 6-22-2005) 
Sec. 16-2. - Exceptions to chapter. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the following: 
(a)  Sales made to dealers or permanent merchants by commercial travelers selling in the usual course of business. 
(b)  Sheriffs, constables, bona fide assignees, receivers or trustees in bankruptcy or other public officers selling goods, wares and merchandise according to law. 
(c)  Bona fide residents of the state selling fruits, vegetables, dressed meats, fowl or farm products which were produced on land within the state, owned or controlled by such vendor. 
(d)  Solicitations, sales or distributions made by nonprofit charitable, educational or religious organizations which have their principal place of activity within this city. 
(e)  Persons selling or distributing newspapers or similar tabloids. 
(f)  Persons who operate a business or sell a product from their place of residence, even if the product is not produced at that location, so long as the activity is not in conflict with the Mount Pleasant Zoning Ordinance. 
(g)  Persons licensed by the State of Iowa to sell real estate or insurance or licensed as transient vendors of drugs. 
(h)  Person selling or delivering tangible personal property or services through a permanent business located in the city, or sold to regular customers on established routes. (i.e. Schwans, Avon) 
(i)  Farmers who offer for sale products of their own raising. 
(j)  Candidates (or their duly authorized representatives) for local, county, state, or national office soliciting donations and/or support. 
(k)  Persons selling tangible property at a garage, basement or yard sale held at one of the person's residences, a shelter house, or similar type location. 
(l)  Members of local Cub Scouts, Girl Scouts, Camp Fire Girls, Blue Birds, 4-H, Future Farmers of America, students representing a school organization or activity approved by the Mount Pleasant Community School District or Mount Pleasant Christian School, and similar organizations, provided that the organization consists in part of members who reside in Henry County, Iowa. 
(m)  Persons licensed as auctioneers by the laws of the state. 
(Code 1969, § 4.08.060; Ord. No. 1149, § 1, 6-22-2005; Ord. No. 1156, § 1, 9-13-2005) 
Sec. 16-3. - Entrance to premises restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler solicitor or transient merchant to enter upon any private premises when such premises are posted with a sign stating "No Peddlers Allowed" or "No Solicitations Allowed" or other words to such effect. 
(Ord. No. 1149, § 1, 6-22-2005) 
Sec. 16-4. - Refusing to leave. 
    Any peddler solicitor or transient merchant who enters upon premises owned, leased or rented by another and refuses to leave such premises after having been notified by the owner or occupant of such premises, or his agent, to leave the same and not return to such premises, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 1149, § 1, 6-22-2005) 
Sec. 16-5. - Misrepresentation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler solicitor or transient merchant to make false or fraudulent statements concerning the quality of his goods, wares, merchandise or services for the purpose of inducing another to purchase the same. 
(Code 1969, § 7.08.050; Ord. No. 1149, § 1, 6-22-2005) 
Sec. 16-6. - Hours of operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler to engage in the business of peddling within the city between the hours of one-half hour before sunset and 9:00 a.m. the following morning. 
(Ord. No. 1149, § 1, 6-22-2005) 
Secs. 16-7-16-17. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMIT 

Sec. 16-18. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business as a peddler solicitor or transient merchant within this city without first obtaining a permit to do so. 
(Code 1969, §§ 4.08.010, 4.32.030; Ord. No. 1149, § 1, 6-22-2005) 
Sec. 16-19. - Application. 
    Applicants for a permit under this article shall file with the clerk a sworn application in writing, in duplicate, on a form to be furnished by the clerk, which shall give the following information: 
(a)  The name and a description of the applicant; 
(b)  The permanent home address and full local address of the applicant; 
(c)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold; 
(d)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; 
(e)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
(f)  The place where goods or property proposed to be sold, or orders taken for the sale thereof, are manufactured or produced, where such goods or products are located at the time the application is filed and the proposed method of delivery; 
(g)  A photograph of the applicant, taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of filing of the application, which picture shall be two (2) inches by two (2) inches showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(h)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor; 
(i)  Whether the applicant, upon any sale or order, shall demand, accept or receive payment or deposit of money in advance of final delivery; 
(j)  The last five (5) municipalities wherein the applicant has worked before coming to this city; and 
(k)  Such other relevant information as may be required by the investigation of the applicant. 
(Code 1969, §§ 4.08.020, 4.32.020) 
Sec. 16-20. - Driver's license or identification and sales tax permit. 
    At the time of filing, the application for a permit required by this article, the applicant shall present his or her driver's license or state or federal identification card, to the clerk and a current and valid State of Iowa sales tax permit or proof that the applicant is exempt from State of Iowa sales tax. 
(Ord. No. 1156, § 1, 9-13-2005) 
Sec. 16-21. - Application fee. 
    At the time of filing the application, a fee shall be paid to the clerk to cover the cost of investigation of the facts listed in the application, such fee being in the amount established in section 25-21. 
(Ord. No. 847, § 1, 11-11-92) 
Sec. 16-22. - False information. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to give any false or misleading information in connection with his application for a permit required by this article. 
Secs. 16-23, 16-24. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1149, § 1, adopted June 22, 2005, repealed §§ 16-23, 16-24, which pertained to fingerprints and bond, respectively. These sections bore no history note. 
Sec. 16-25. - Service of process. 
    Before any permit shall be issued under this article, there shall also be filed with the clerk an instrument in writing, signed by the applicant under oath, nominating and appointing the clerk his true and lawful agent, with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process for and on the behalf of such applicant; and service of summons in any action brought upon the applicant's bond shall be deemed made when served on the clerk. 
Sec. 16-26. - Investigation. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a permit required by this article, the original shall be referred to the chief of police, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good. The chief of police shall complete his investigation within one (1) week of receiving the application. 
(Code 1969, § 4.08.030) 
Sec. 16-27. - Denial. 
    If, as a result of investigation, the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on the application his disapproval and his reasons for the same, and return the application to the clerk, who shall notify the applicant that his application is disapproved and that no permit shall be issued. 
Sec. 16-28. - Issuance. 
(a)  If, as a result of investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on the application his approval, execute a permit addressed to the applicant for the carrying on of the business applied for and return the permit along with the application to the clerk, who shall, upon payment of the required fee, deliver the permit to the applicant. 
(b)  In determining whether any license under this article should be granted or denied the following standards shall be taken into consideration: 
(1)  If the proposed activity is likely to cause undue congestion of a public area. 
(2)  If the proposed activity is likely to create a safety hazard. 
(3)  If the applicant has had complaints for misrepresentation, fraud, or selling defective merchandise. 
(4)  If the applicant or any of its agents or representatives has been convicted within the last five (5) years of any public offense relating to fraud, misrepresentation, or moral turpitude. 
(5)  If the proposed activity is likely to cause excessive or unusual noise. 
(Ord. No. 1149, § 1, 6-22-2005; Ord. No. 1156, § 1, 9-13-2005) 
Sec. 16-29. - Contents. 
    Each permit issued under this article shall contain the signature and seal of the issuing officer and shall show the name, address and photograph of the permittee, the class of permit issued and the kind of goods to be sold thereunder, the date of issuance and the length of time the same shall be operative, as well as the permit number and other identifying description of any vehicle used in such business. 
Sec. 16-30. - Record. 
    The clerk shall keep a permanent record of all permits issued under this article. 
Sec. 16-31. - Display. 
    Every peddler having a permit issued under the provisions of this article and doing business within the city shall display his permit upon the request of any person, and failure to do so shall be a misdemeanor. 
Sec. 16-32. - Duration. 
    Every permit issued under the provisions of this article shall be valid for the period of thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No. 1156, § 1, 9-13-2005; Ord. No. 1191, § 1, 6-11-2008) 
Sec. 16-33. - Revocation. 
    Any permit issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked by the council after a hearing, for the violation by the permittee of any applicable provisions of the city ordinance or state law. Any such hearing shall be conducted pursuant to the procedures set forth in the Mt. Pleasant Administrative Code (chapter 2, article VIII). 
(Code 1969, § 4.08.090; Ord. No. 953, § 1, 1-10-96) 
Sec. 16-34. - Penalty. 
    Any peddler, solicitor or transient merchant, whether an individual person, a firm, corporation, partnership or association, violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a municipal infraction, and shall bar the licensee from being eligible for any license under this article for a period of one (1) year from the date of the revocation. Each sale made in violation of the provisions hereof shall be considered a separate offense. 
    Any person, whether an individual person, a firm, corporation, partnership or association, who allows a peddler, solicitor or transient merchant as defined by this section, to conduct business on real estate owned or leased by them, shall be guilty of a municipal infraction. 
(Ord. No. 1149, § 1, 6-22-2005) 
Chapter 17 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 403A of the Code of Iowa, a low rent housing agency was created when the city passed resolution number one on May 6, 1970. 
Cross reference- Historic preservation commission, § 2-70 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; construction board of appeals, § G-200 et seq.; park and recreation board, § 15-21 et seq.; house addressing, § 22-42 et seq.; subdivisions, Ch. 23; planning and zoning commission fees, § 25-9; mobile homes and mobile home parks, App. C; zoning, App. D. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 17-1-17-15. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Provisions derived from Ord. No. 523, § 1, adopted Mar. 19, 1980, and formerly codified as § 17-1, have been redesignated by the editors as § 17-51 for purposes of classification. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Planning and zoning commission fees, § 25-9. 
State Law reference- Administrative agencies, I.C.A. § 392.1 et seq. 

Sec. 17-16. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a city planning and zoning commission. 
(Code 1969, § 2.44.010) 
Sec. 17-17. - Members. 
(a)  The city planning and zoning commission shall consist of seven (7) members, who shall be citizens of the city, and qualified by experience or knowledge to act in matters pertaining to the development and implementation of a city plan, and who shall not hold any elective office in the city government. The members shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to approval by the council. 
(b)  The term of office of the members of the commission shall be five (5) years. If any vacancies exist on the commission caused by resignation or otherwise, the mayor shall appoint a successor for the residue of the term, subject to the approval of the council. 
(c)  All members of the commission shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1969, §§ 2.44.020-2.44.050) 
Sec. 17-18. - Chairman. 
    At its first regular meeting of each year the city planning and zoning commission shall choose one (1) of its members to act as chairman. 
(Code 1969, § 2.44.060(a)) 
Sec. 17-19. - Organization and procedure. 
    The city planning and zoning commission shall adopt such rules and regulations governing its organization and procedure as it may deem necessary. 
(Code 1969, § 2.44.060(b)) 
Sec. 17-20. - Report. 
    The city planning and zoning commission shall make a report to the mayor and the council each month of its proceedings, with a full statement of its receipts and disbursements and the progress of its work during the preceding month. 
(Code 1969, § 2.44.060(c)) 
Sec. 17-21. - Appropriations. 
    The city planning and zoning commission shall have full, complete and exclusive authority to expend for and on behalf of the city all sums of money appropriated as hereinafter provided, and to use and expend all gifts, donations or payments whatsoever which are received by the city for city plan purposes. 
(Code 1969, § 2.44.060(i)) 
Sec. 17-22. - Limitations on contracts. 
    The city planning and zoning commission shall have no power to contract debts beyond the amount of its income for the present year. 
(Code 1969, § 2.44.060(j)) 
Sec. 17-23. - Assistants. 
    Subject to the limitations contained in this article as to the expenditure of funds, the city planning and zoning commission may appoint such assistants as it may deem necessary and prescribe and define their respective duties and fix and regulate the compensation to be paid to such persons. 
(Code 1969, § 2.44.060(d)) 
Sec. 17-24. - Surveys, studies, etc. 
    The city planning and zoning commission, with permission of the city council, shall have full power and authority to make or cause to be made such surveys, studies, maps, plans or charts of the whole or any portion of the city or any land outside thereof, which in the opinion of the commission bears relation to a comprehensive plan and shall bring same to the attention of the council, and may publish its studies and recommendations subject to provisions of section 17-22. 
(Code 1969, § 2.44.060(e)) 
Sec. 17-25. - Powers over public buildings or construction. 
    No statuary, memorial or work of art in a public place, and no public building, bridge, viaduct, street fixtures, public structure or appurtenances shall be located or erected, or site therefor obtained, nor shall any permit be issued by any department of the municipal government for the erection or location thereof, until and unless the design and proposed location of any such improvement shall have been submitted to the city plan commission and its recommendations thereon obtained. 
(Code 1969, § 2.44.060(f)) 
Sec. 17-26. - Consideration of plats of subdivisions. 
    All plans, plats or replats of subdivisions or resubdivisions of land embraced in the municipality or adjacent thereto, laid out in lots or plats with the streets, alleys, or other portions of same intended to be dedicated to the public in such municipality, shall first be submitted to the city planning and zoning commission and its recommendations obtained before approval by the council. 
(Code 1969, § 2.44.060(g)) 
Sec. 17-27. - Consideration of streets, parks, etc. 
    No plan for any street, park, parkway, boulevard, trafficway, or other public improvement affecting the city plan shall be finally approved by the municipality or the character or location thereof determined, unless such proposal has first been submitted to the city planning and zoning commission. 
(Code 1969, § 2.44.060(h)) 
Sec. 17-28. - Comprehensive plan. 
(a)  For the purpose of making a comprehensive plan for the physical development of the city, the city planning and zoning commission shall make careful and comprehensive studies of present conditions and future growth of the city and with due regard to its relations to neighboring territory. The plan shall be made with the general purpose of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated, adjusted and harmonious development of the city and its environs which will, in accordance with the present and future needs, best promote health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development. 
(b)  Before adopting a comprehensive plan as referred to in the preceding paragraph, or any part of it, or any substantial amendment thereof, the commission shall hold at least one public hearing thereon, notice of the time of which shall be given by one publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, not less than ten (10) nor more than twenty (20) days before the date of hearing. The adoption of the plan or part or amendment thereof shall be by resolution of the commission, carried by the affirmative vote of not less than two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the members of the commission. After adoption of the plan by the commission, an attested copy thereof shall be certified to the council, and the council may approve the same, and when the plan or any modification or amendment thereof shall receive the approval of the council, the plan, until subsequently modified or amended as hereinbefore authorized, shall constitute the official city plan. 
(c)  When such comprehensive plan has been adopted, no substantial amendment or modification thereof shall be made without such proposed change first being referred to the city planning and zoning commission, for its recommendation. If the commission disapproves the proposed change, it may be adopted by the city council only by the affirmative vote of at least three-fourths of the members of the council. 
(Code 1969, § 2.44.060(j-m)) 
Sec. 17-29. - Service as zoning commission. 
    The city planning and zoning commission is hereby appointed as the city's zoning commission. 
(Code 1969, § 2.44.080) 
State Law reference- Power of council to designate planning commission to be zoning commission, I.C.A., § 414.6. 
Secs. 17-30-17-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - REVITALIZATION AREAS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 560, §§ 1-10, adopted Sept. 2, 1981, did not specify manner of codification; hence, inclusion herein as Art. III, §§ 17-36, 17-37; 17-41-17-45; 17-52-17-57, has been at the discretion of the editors. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-36. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited and referred to as the "Mount Pleasant Revitalization District Development Regulation." 
(Ord. No. 560, § 1, 9-2-81) 
Sec. 17-37. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, certain terms and words are hereby defined. Words used in the present tense shall include the future, the singular number shall include the plural and the plural number includes the singular; the word "shall" is mandatory; the word "may" is permissive; the word "person" includes a firm, association, organization, partnership, trust, company or corporation as well as an individual; the word "used" or "occupied" include the words intended, designed, or arranged to be used or occupied. 
    Mount Pleasant Revitalization District: All areas which have been included in Revitalization Area No. 1 by Ordinance No. 523 of the city council of the City of Mount Pleasant, Iowa, dated the 19th day of March, 1980. 
    Committee: The "community development committee" as established by the Mount Pleasant City Council. 
    Building administrator: The City of Mount Pleasant Building Administrator. 
(Ord. No. 560, § 1, 9-2-81; Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 4-22-98) 
Sec. 17-38. - Designated areas. 
(a)  In accordance with Section 404.1 of the Code of Iowa, and in consideration of the recitations set out in the preamble hereof, the entire area within the corporate boundaries of the City of Mount Pleasant, Iowa, be and the same are hereby designated as a revitalization area, said area being described as follows: 
The entire area within the corporate boundaries of the City of Mount Pleasant, Henry County, Iowa, as established on October 14, 1988. 
(b)  All existing revitalization plans adopted or previously designated revitalization areas of the city shall continue to be in full force and effect, and in accordance with their particular terms, until such time as the city council hereafter shall adopt a revitalization plan for the city as a whole. 
(Ord. No. 726, §§ 1, 2, 10-12-88) 
Editor's note- Sections 1 and 2 of nonamendatory Ord. No. 726, adopted Oct. 12, 1988, have been codified as § 17-38(a) and (b) at the editor's discretion; §§ 3 and 4 of said ordinance, relating to severability clause and effective date, respectively, have not been included herein. 
Secs. 17-39-17-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT COMMITTEE 

Sec. 17-41. - Created; terms; compensation; meetings. 
    There is hereby created an advisory committee to be known as the community development committee which shall consist of seven (7) members, appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. Three (3) of the first appointees shall serve one (1) year, two (2) appointees shall serve two (2) years, and two (2) appointees shall serve three (3) years. Subsequent appointees shall serve for a term of three (3) years and thereafter until a successor has been appointed. Vacancies shall be filled for the remainder of the term. The appointees are eligible for reappointment for a consecutive two (2) terms. If a member misses three (3) consecutive monthly meetings without a reasonable excuse, a resignation from the committee will be required of that member. A new member shall be appointed by the mayor for the remainder of the term. The members of the committee shall choose from among themselves a person to act as a chairman who shall serve for a period of one (1) year unless reelected, provided, however, that no person shall serve as chairman for more than two (2) consecutive years. All members of the committee shall meet once a month or as deemed necessary by the chairman in order to carry out the intent of this article. 
(Ord. No. 560, § 5, 9-2-81; Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 4-22-98) 
Sec. 17-42. - Powers of the committee. 
    The committee shall act in an advisory capacity only, and shall have no power to bind the city by contract or otherwise. It shall be the function of the committee to advise the city council, the building administrator or such other appointee of the city, concerning all applications for building permits within the Mt. Pleasant Revitalization District, and to act in an advisory capacity to the mayor, and city council or it's appointee, in all matters pertaining to the development of the district and more particularly to the restrictions, regulations and controls as set out in this article. 
    The committee shall have the authority to inform the various departments of the city of violations of this article and recommend to such departments appropriate action, either under this article or under such ordinances that are in force and effect at the time of violation; subject to appeal procedures set out hereafter. 
    The committee shall have the authority to receive requests for the placement, repair, alterations, modification, painting or repainting of any sign, graphic, visual display, or outdoor furniture or fixtures; and to make recommendations to the various departments of the city concerning such requests. 
(Ord. No. 560, § 6, 9-2-81; Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 4-22-98) 
Sec. 17-43. - Building permits. 
    Whenever application is made for a building permit to construct, alter, modify or repair any building within the Mt. Pleasant Revitalization District, the building administrator shall refer said application, together with the plans and specifications for the proposed work to the committee for its recommendations. 
    The committee shall review the proposed plans and specifications, so far as they relate to the proposed appearance, colors, texture, materials and architectural design of the exterior, including the front, sides, rear and roof, of said building, and also including all parts of the building that are in a visual line from all areas or any alteration, modification, or repair, of any courtyard, fence, or dependency thereof. After due consideration, the committee shall promptly report to the building administrator it's recommendations, including such changes, if any, as in the judgement of the committee are reasonably necessary to comply with the requirements of this article. The building administrator shall take no action on the application for a permit until the expiration of thirty (30) days or until the building administrator has received the recommendation of the committee in writing, whichever occurs first. 
    The committee shall also review the proposed plans and specifications, so far as they relate to the placement, alteration, modifications, repair of any signs, graphic, visual display, outdoor furniture or fixture, including all parts of same that are visible from all areas. 
(Ord. No. 560, § 7, 9-2-81; Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 4-22-98) 
Sec. 17-44. - Denial of permit. 
    If the committee recommends denial of a building permit, said recommendation must be delivered to the city building administrator who shall notify the applicant that said building permit shall not be issued and the reasons therefor. The city building administrator may proceed with issuance of a building permit upon amendment of the application to conform with the recommendations of the committee pursuant to the powers and duties of the building administrator as set forth in the building code (see section 6-16 of the Mt. Pleasant Municipal Code). 
(Ord. No. 560, § 8, 9-2-81) 
Sec. 17-45. - Appeal from denial of permit. 
    Any person denied a building permit by the building administrator pursuant to the recommendation of the committee under the conditions of this article, may appeal said denial within thirty (30) days after the notification of the denial, to the board of adjustment. The appeal hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures set forth in the Mt. Pleasant Administrative Code (chapter 2, article VIII). 
(Ord. No. 560, § 9, 9-2-81; Ord. No. 954, § 1, 1-10-96) 
Secs. 17-46-17-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REVITALIZATION AREA NO. 1 

Sec. 17-51. - Description. 
    In accordance with the Act and in consideration of the recitations set out in the Preamble hereof, the area formed by contiguous real estate parcels with a legal description as follows: 
    Commencing at the centerline of Clay Street where it intersects with the centerline of Jackson Street; thence proceed in an easterly direction along the centerline of Clay Street to the centerline of Adams Street; thence proceed northerly along the centerline of Adams Street to the centerline of Madison Street; thence proceed westerly along the centerline of Madison Street to the centerline of Jackson Street; thence southerly along the centerline of Jackson Street to the point of beginning. 
Be and the same is hereby designated as a revitalization area under the Act, which shall be known as Revitalization Area No. 1. 
    In accordance with chapter 404 of the Code of Iowa, and as a result of the adoption of Resolution No. 2014-59 on November 12, 2014, the legal description of the Mount Pleasant Urban Revitalization Area now contains the following property: 
The Mount Pleasant Urban Revitalization Area (hereinafter referred to as "area") includes all real estate located within the Mount Pleasant corporate limits as of November 1, 2014. Any land annexed into the city in the future shall automatically be included in the plan area as of the effective date of the annexation. 
be and the same is hereby designated as a revitalization area under the Act, which shall be known as Amendment No. 1 to Mount Pleasant Urban Revitalization Area of the City of Mount Pleasant, Iowa. 
(Ord. No. 523, § 1, 3-19-80; Ord. No. 766, § 1, 3-5-90; Ord. No. 1184, § 1, 7-25-2007; Ord. No. 1288, § 1, 12-12-2014) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 523, § 1, adopted Mar. 19, 1980, and formerly codified as § 17-1, has been redesignated as § 17-51 for purposes of classification. 
Sec. 17-52. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this division is to preserve and promote the natural beauty, pride and dignified character, including the historical aspects of the Mt. Pleasant Revitalization District, which are all intimately connected with the history and life of Mt. Pleasant; to maintain atmosphere; and to promote an integrated shopping, living, entertainment, and recreation area for visitors and the people of this city, to the end that the public welfare will be promoted and advanced through the preservation of property values and the resulting benefits to the economy of the city flowing from the promotion and maintenance of Mt. Pleasant, and most importantly, to preserve and promote the quality of life for the citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 560, § 2, 9-2-81; Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 4-22-98) 
Sec. 17-53. - Interpretation of standards. 
    Interpretation and application of the provisions of this division shall be held to be minimum requirements. Where this division imposes greater restriction than is imposed or required by the provisions of law or by other rules or regulations or ordinances, the provisions of this division shall control. 
(Ord. No. 560, § 2, 9-2-81) 
Sec. 17-54. - Application of division. 
    The restrictions, regulations and controls on construction prescribed by this division shall be applicable to the construction, 
maintenance, repair, alterations, modifications and painting of all buildings, signs, graphics, visual displays, outdoor furniture and fixtures, in the Mt. Pleasant Revitalization District. 
    Whenever any building in the Mt. Pleasant Revitalization District is reconstructed, repaired, altered, modified, painted or repainted, such work shall be done in a manner conforming to and in sympathy with the building's original design, using such materials that are in keeping with the character and preservation of the district. New construction shall also conform to these standards. Nothing herein shall be construed as an attempt to regiment architecture to the extent of prohibiting modern technological styling or materials. 
    Whenever any sign, graphic, visual display, outdoor furniture and/or fixtures are to be placed, repaired, altered, modified, painted or repainted, such work shall be in such a manner as to conform to and be in sympathy with the general concept, using such materials as are in keeping with the theme in these areas. Nothing herein shall be construed as being an attempt to regiment design to the extent of prohibiting modern technological styling or materials which would be in sympathy with the purposes of this division. 
(Ord. No. 560, § 3, 9-2-81; Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 4-22-98) 
Sec. 17-55. - General regulations. 
    All activities, public or private, and all uses of property, public or private within the Mt. Pleasant Revitalization District shall be in furtherance of the prideful and dignified atmosphere of the area and shall conform to the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 560, § 4, 9-2-81) 
Sec. 17-56. - Conformity required within district. 
    All departments, officials and employees of the City of Mt. Pleasant, Iowa, who are vested with the duty or authority to issue permits or licenses, shall issue no such permit or license for any use, structure or purpose if the same would not conform to the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 560, § 10, 9-2-81) 
Sec. 17-57. - Violation and penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with or who resists enforcement of any of the provisions of this division, upon conviction, shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. Each day the violation is permitted to exist constitutes a separate offense. Proceeding with any construction work or repair work requiring a permit without applying for a permit shall be considered an offense and punishable by the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 560, § 10, 9-2-81) 
Secs. 17-58, 17-59. - Reserved. 
Chapter 18 - POLICE DEPARTMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Police department service charges, § 25-23. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Established. 
    A police department is hereby established to provide for preservation of the peace and enforcement of law within the city. 
(Ord. No. 448, § 1, 8-20-75) 
Sec. 18-2. - Composition and organization. 
(a)  The police department shall consist of all law enforcement officers performing duties authorized by law or ordinance. The authorized strength/size of the department shall be established by the city council. The members shall be designated by rank as follows: 
(1)  Police chief. 
(2)  Lieutenant. 
(3)  Sergeant. 
(4)  Police officer. 
(5)  In addition, police officer(s) of any rank may also be designated as a criminal investigator. 
(b)  Compensation of police officers shall be determined by the council with a salary schedule adopted by resolution. 
(c)  The department shall be headed by a police chief appointed by the mayor. 
(d)  A chart defining the structure of the department shall be established by the chief of police and maintained on file with the office of city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 448, § 2, 8-20-75; Ord. No. 763, § 1, 1-10-90) 
Sec. 18-3. - Duties of police chief. 
    The duties of the chief of police are as defined in the policy manual on file in the city clerk's office. 
Cross reference- Police chief, § 2-18. 
Sec. 18-4. - Standards and training. 
    All police officers shall meet minimum standards required by state law. Further, all police officers shall have received the minimum training required by state law at an approved law enforcement training school. The council shall provide financial assistance for such attendance. 
(Ord. No. 448, § 4, 8-20-75) 
Sec. 18-5. - Removal, demotion and suspension. 
(a)  A police officer may be removed, demoted or suspended by the police chief for violation of departmental rules or regulations, but such officer shall have the right to a hearing before the city council. Such hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures set forth in the Mt. Pleasant Administrative Code. 
(b)  The police chief shall by written rules specify whether suspension, pay penalties or reprimands are penalties for offenses. 
(Ord. No. 448, § 5, 8-20-75; Ord. No. 955, § 1, 1-10-96) 
Sec. 18-6. - State law exemption. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to comply with Chapter 23A, 1987 Code of Iowa, as amended, by authorizing, as an exempted activity, the unlocking of doors of motor vehicles. 
(b)  Facts found. The city council hereby makes the following findings: 
(1)  The city has a lengthy history of its police department unlocking doors of motor vehicles. 
(2)  Pursuant to Section 23A.2(1), Code of Iowa, a city may specifically authorize the exemption of an otherwise private enterprise. 
(3)  The policy of the gratuitous unlocking of doors of motor vehicles has been recognized as a voluntary public service offered by the city. 
(c)  Exemption authorized. The city council specifically authorizes its employees to unlock the doors of motor vehicles and exempts said activity from the provisions of Chapter 23A, 1987 Code of Iowa, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 718, §§ 1-3, 7-27-88) 
Sec. 18-7. - Enforcement regulations. 
    The chief of police may make and enforce regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of the chapters of this Code relating to the regulation of traffic and other provisions contained in this Code relating to public order and personal conduct, including such powers to establish regulations for specific areas as may be provided under Chapter 12 of this code, and to make and enforce temporary regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. 
(Ord. No. 762, § 1, 1-10-90) 
Sec. 18-8. - Temporary regulations. 
    Whenever the chief of police or persons authorized by him/her shall temporarily prohibit parking on a street or temporarily establish one-way traffic on a street or temporarily designate a stop intersection, they shall cause appropriate notice to be given with the means of notice reasonably calculated to give notice to operators of motor vehicles of the prohibited parking, one-way traffic movement or traffic sign. Such notice may be by special signs or by the temporary alteration of existing signs or a signing method which may be deemed appropriate or by direction by individuals authorized by the chief of police to direct such traffic and such parking. A sign intended for temporary use shall not remain in place for more than seven (7) consecutive days. 
(Ord. No. 762, § 1, 1-10-90) 
Sec. 18-9. - Community services unit. 
(a)  Positions created. Within the police department shall be established a community services unit. The size of the community services unit as well as compensation received by the community services officer(s) shall be as authorized by the city council. Community service officer(s) shall be appointed by the mayor subject to the approval of the city council. Community service officer(s) will be a civilian, nonsworn employee(s) of the city. Hereinafter in this section, the community services officer(s) shall be referred to as the officer. 
(b)  Duties-Generally. The officer shall be specifically responsible for the enforcement of the following sections of the Municipal Code: 
(1)  Sections 4-1 through 4-29, inclusive; 
(2)  Section 12-2 when enforcing provisions of Sections 321.358, 321.360 and 321.361 of the Code of Iowa; 
(3)  Sections 12-32 through 12-46, inclusive; 
(4)  Sections 12-48 and 12-49; 
(5)  Sections 12-56 through 12-59, inclusive; 
(6)  Sections 12-101 through 12-104, inclusive; and 
(7)  Section 22-13(c). 
(c)  Same-Additional. The officer shall also be responsible for the enforcement of all parking and bicycle ordinances and the enforcement of all other ordinances as directed by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 3-14-90) 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, Ch. 4; bicycles, Ch. 5; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 12; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 18-10. - Services charges. 
    The police department shall be authorized to collect service charges for fingerprinting, photographs, call and service printouts, storage of impounded vehicles, and such other administrative services, in amounts that are established in section 25-23. 
(Ord. No. 833, § 1, 11-11-92) 
Secs. 18-11-18-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE RESERVE 

Sec. 18-16. - Establishment and purpose. 
    A police reserve is hereby established to assist the police department in all its activities and functions, including the prevention and control of crime, preservation of the peace and the enforcement of the laws of the municipality, the State of Iowa, and the United States. The reserves shall be known as the "Mount Pleasant Police Reserve". 
(Ord. No. 534, § 1, 6-18-80; Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 8-26-98) 
Sec. 18-17. - Members. 
    Ten (10) residents of Henry County, Iowa, shall be appointed to serve on the police reserve by the chief of police subject to the approval of the city council.
