(Ord. No. 534, § 2, 6-18-80; Ord. No. 760, § 1, 11-22-89; Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 8-26-98) 
Sec. 18-18. - Personal standards. 
    The members of the police reserve shall be subject to the minimum standards of physical, educational, mental and moral fitness as shall be established by the director of the Iowa Law Enforcement Academy. Additionally, the members of the Mount Pleasant Police Reserve shall be subject to the rules and regulations as set forth by the chief of police with the approval of the city council. The chief of police shall made the bylaws and rules and regulations available to the members of the police reserve which shall govern the conduct of the members. 
(Ord. No. 534, § 3, 6-18-80; Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 8-26-98) 
Sec. 18-19. - Standards and training. 
    All members of the police reserve shall meet minimum standards as required by state law and as implemented by the chief of police. All members of the police reserve shall have received the minimum training and instruction as required by state law and as implemented by the chief of police. The initial training and instruction shall be completed within one (1) year from the date of the appointment of the member of the police reserve. 
(Ord. No. 534, § 4, 6-18-80) 
Sec. 18-20. - Status of reserve officers. 
    Members of the police reserve shall serve as peace officers on the orders and at the discretion of the chief of police. While in the actual performance of official duties, members of the police reserve shall be vested with the same rights, privileges, obligations and duties as any other peace officer of the city. 
(Ord. No. 534, § 5, 6-18-80; Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 8-26-98) 
Sec. 18-21. - Carrying weapons. 
    A member of the police reserve shall not carry a weapon in the performance of his duties until he has been approved to do so by the city and certified by the Iowa Law Enforcement Academy Council. After approval and certification, a member of the reserve may carry a weapon in the performance of his or her official duties only when authorized by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 534, § 6, 6-18-80; Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 8-26-98) 
Sec. 18-22. - Supplementary capacity. 
    Members of the police reserve shall act only in a supplementary capacity to the regular police department and shall not assume full-time duties of a regular peace officer without first complying with all requirements for full-time peace officers. 
(Ord. No. 534, § 7, 6-18-80; Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 8-26-98) 
Sec. 18-23. - Supervision of reserve peace officers. 
    Members of the police reserve shall be subordinate to full-time members of the police department such members shall not serve as peace officers unless under the direction of a full-time peace officer for the city and shall wear a uniform as prescribed by the chief of police unless authorized in compliance with state law. The police department shall appoint a full-time peace officer as the police reserve coordinating and supervising officer, and said officer may be the chief of police. The full-time peace officer acting as the coordinating and supervising officer shall report directly to the chief of police when said officer is not the chief of police. The members of the police reserve shall not wear an insignia of rank. 
(Ord. No. 534, § 8, 6-18-80; Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 8-26-98) 
Sec. 18-24. - No reduction of police department. 
    The city shall not reduce the authorized number of members of full-time peace officers for the police department because of the establishment and utilization of the police reserve. 
(Ord. No. 534, § 9, 6-18-80; Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 8-26-98) 
Sec. 18-25. - Compensation. 
    While performing official duties, each member of the police reserve shall be considered an employee of the city and shall be paid a minimum of one dollar ($1.00) per year. The city may provide additional monetary assistance for the purchase and maintenance of uniforms and equipment used by the police reserve, but said compensation shall not exceed the allowance provided in Section 337A.2 of the Code of Iowa. 
(Ord. No. 534, § 10, 6-18-80; Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 8-26-98) 
Sec. 18-26. - Removal and suspension. 
    A member of the police reserve may be removed or suspended by the chief of police for violation of departmental rules or regulations. Such member shall have a right to a hearing before the city council. The hearing shall be held in accordance with the procedures set forth in the Mt. Pleasant Administrative Code (chapter 2, article VIII). 
(Ord. No. 534, § 11, 6-18-80; Ord. No. 955, § 1, 1-10-96; Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 8-26-98) 
Sec. 18-27. - Workers' compensation. 
    The city council shall contract to insure the city against liability for worker's compensation and against statutory liability for the costs of hospitalization, nursing and medical attention for members of the police reserve injured in the course of performing their official duties. 
(Ord. No. 534, § 12, 6-18-80; Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 8-26-98) 
Sec. 18-28. - Liability insurance. 
    The city council shall contract to insure the city against liability of the city or members of the police reserve for injuries, death, property damage, or false arrests arising out of and while performing official duties. 
(Ord. No. 534, § 13, 6-18-80; Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 8-26-98) 
Sec. 18-29. - Participation in pension fund or retirement system. 
    This article shall not be construed to authorize or permit a member of the police reserve to become eligible for participation in a pension fund or retirement system created by the laws of the state wherein a regular peace officer for the city may become a member. 
(Ord. No. 534, § 14, 6-18-80; Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 8-26-98) 
Chapter 19 - PUBLIC LIBRARY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- There is in existence a G. Rhodes Memorial Fund established by a testamentary bequest from Eliza G. Rhodes. The fund is to be used by the library trustees for purchasing of library books, see Ord. No. 440, § 13, 3-19-75. 
By Ordinance Number 48 the city accepted a gift from the Ladies Library Association of Mount Pleasant, Iowa, see Ord. No. 440 § 12, 3-19-75. 
There is also in existence the Robbie McCoid Trust Fund, see Ord. No. 440, § 11, 3-19-75. 
There is also in existence a Charlotte Harding Kapp Fund, see Ord. No. 440, § 11, 3-19-75. Also there is in existence a Charlotte Harding Kapp and John Ruse Kapp Memorial Fund, see Ord. No. 440, § 11, 3-19-75. 
State Law reference- Library boards, I.C.A. § 392.5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - Violation of rules. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the rules promulgated by the city library trustees or the librarian. 
(Code 1969, § 7.08.060) 
Secs. 19-2-19-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF TRUSTEES 

Sec. 19-16. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a board of trustees of the Mount Pleasant Public Library, hereinafter referred to as the board. 
Sec. 19-17. - Members. 
(a)  The board shall consist of seven (7) members appointed by the mayor with the approval of the council. 
(b)  All of the members of the board shall be over the age of eighteen (18), and shall be bona fide citizens and residents of the city, except one (1) of the seven (7) members may be a nonresident of the city, provided such nonresident resides in the unincorporated boundaries of Henry County, Iowa, or within another city of Henry County, Iowa, which has contract services with the Mr. Pleasant Public Library. 
(c)  All appointments to the board shall be for six (6) years, except to fill vacancies. Each terns shall commence on July first. Appointments shall be made every two (2) years of one-third the total number as near as possible, to stagger the terms. 
(d)  The position of any board member shall be vacant if a member moves permanently from the city, or if a member is absent from three (3) consecutive regular meetings of the board, except in the case of sickness or temporary absence from the city. Vacancies in the board shall be filled by appointment of the mayor, with approval of the council, and the new member shall fill out the unexpired term for which the appointment is made. 
(e)  Members of the board shall receive no compensation for their services. 
(Ord. No. 440, §§ 2-4, 8-19-75; Ord. No. 904, § 1, 6-8-94; Ord. No. 1028, § 1, 10-14-98; Ord. No. 1255, § 1, 10-10-2012) 
Sec. 19-18. - Officers. 
    The board shall elect from among its membership a president, a secretary and such other officers as it deems necessary. The city treasurer shall serve as the board's treasurer. 
Sec. 19-19. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The board shall have the power and duty: 
(1)  To have charge, control and supervision of the public library, its appurtenances, fixtures and rooms containing the same. 
(2)  To direct and control all the affairs of the library. 
(3)  To employ a librarian, and authorize the librarian to employ such assistants and employees as may be necessary for the proper management of the library, and fix their compensation; provided, however, that prior to such employment, the compensation of the librarian, assistants and employees shall have been fixed and approved by a majority of the members of the board voting in favor thereof. 
(4)  To remove by a two-thirds vote of the board the librarian and provide procedures for the removal of assistants or employees for misdemeanor, incompetency or inattention to duty, subject, however, to the provisions of Chapter 70 of the Code of Iowa. 
(5)  To select, or authorize the librarian to select, and make purchases of books, pamphlets, magazines, periodicals, papers, maps, journals, other library materials, furniture, fixtures, stationery and supplies for the library within budgetary limits set by the board. 
(6)  To authorize the use of the library by nonresidents of the city and to fix charges therefor. 
(7)  To make and adopt, amend, modify or repeal rules and regulations, not inconsistent with ordinances and the law, for the care, use, government and management of the library and the business of the board, fixing and enforcing penalties for violations. 
(8)  To have exclusive control of the expenditure of all funds allocated for library purposes by the council, and of all moneys available by gift or otherwise for the erection of library buildings, and of all other moneys belonging to the library including fines and rentals collected, under the rules of the board. 
(9)  To accept gifts of real property, personal property or mixed property, and devises and bequests, including trust funds; to take the title to said property in the name of the library; to execute deeds and bills of sale for the conveyance of said property, and to expend the funds received by them from such gifts, for the improvement of the library. 
(10)  To keep a record of its proceedings. 
(11)  To enforce the performance of conditions on gifts, donations, devises and bequests accepted by the city by action against the city council. 
(12)  To have authority to make agreements with the local county historical associations, where such exists, and to set apart the necessary room and to care for such articles as may come into the possession of the association. The board is further authorized to purchase necessary receptacles and materials for the preservation and protection of such articles as are in their judgment of a historical and educational nature and pay for the same out of funds allocated for library purposes. 
(Ord. No. 440, § 5, 3-19-75) 
Sec. 19-20. - Power to contract with others for the use of library. 
(a)  The board may contract with any other boards of trustees of free public libraries, any other city, school corporation, private or semi-private organization, institution of higher learning, township or county, or with the trustees of any county library district for the use of the library by their respective residents. 
(b)  Such a contract may be terminated at any time by mutual consent of the contracting parties. It also may be terminated by a majority vote of the electors represented by either of the contracting parties. Such a termination proposition shall be submitted to the electors by the governing body of a contracting party on a written petition of not less than five (5) percent in number of the electors who voted for governor in the territory of the party at the last general election. The petition must be presented to the governing body not less than forty (40) days before the election. The proposition may be submitted at any election provided by law that is held in the territory of the party who is seeking to terminate the contract. 
(Ord. No. 440, § 6, 3-19-75) 
Sec. 19-21. - Nonresident use of the library. 
    The board may authorize the use of the library by nonresidents in any one or more of the following ways: 
(1)  By lending the books or other materials of the library to nonresidents on the same terms and conditions as to residents of the city, or upon payment of a special nonresident library fee. 
(2)  By establishing depositories of library books or other materials to be loaned to nonresidents. 
(3)  By establishing bookmobiles or a traveling library so that books or other library materials may be loaned to nonresidents. 
(4)  By establishing branch libraries for lending books or other library materials to nonresidents. 
(Ord. No. 440, § 7, 3-19-75) 
Sec. 19-22. - Library account. 
    All money appropriated by the council from the general fund for the operation and maintenance of the library shall be set aside in an account for the library. Expenditures shall be paid for only on orders of the board, signed by its president and secretary. The warrant writing officers are the president of board and the librarian. 
(Ord. No. 440, § 8, 3-19-75) 
Sec. 19-23. - Annual report. 
    The board shall make a report to the city council immediately after the close of the municipal fiscal year. This report shall contain statements of the condition of the library, the number of books added thereto, the number circulated, the amount of fines collected and the amount of money expended in the maintenance of the library during the year, together with such further information required by the council. 
(Ord. No. 440, § 9, 3-19-75) 
Chapter 20 - SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Drains on sidewalks, § 22-10; utilities, Ch. 24; municipal fees and charges, Ch. 25; sewers and sewage disposals in mobile home parks, App. C, § 28. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of the terms used in this chapter shall be as follows: 
    BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand): The quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Building drain: That part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five (5) feet (one and one-half (11/2) meters) outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    Building sewer: The extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    Combined sewer: A sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
    Garbage: Solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    Industrial wastes: The liquid wastes from industrial manufacturing processes, trade or business as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
    Natural outlet: Any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or groundwater. 
    pH: The logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution. 
    Properly shredded garbage: The wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (one and twenty-seven one-hundredths (1.27) centimeters) in any dimension. 
    Public sewer: A sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and is controlled by public authority. 
    Sanitary sewer: A sewer which carries sewage and to which storm, surface and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewage: A combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, together with such ground, surface and storm waters as may be present, but not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewage treatment plant: Any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage, under control of the city. 
    Sewage works: All facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage. 
    Sewer: A pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    Slug: Any discharge of water, sewage, or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent, or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes, more than five (5) times the average twenty-four-hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
    Storm drain (sometimes termed storm sewer): A sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes, other than unpolluted cooling water. 
    Superintendent: The director of public works. 
    Suspended solids: Solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, sewage or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Watercourse: A channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.010(1-22)) 
Sec. 20-2. - Control and management. 
    The wastewater treatment plant, lift stations and lagoon shall be under the control of the wastewater plant operator. The wastewater plant operator shall also be responsible for inspection and monitoring of third party wastewater treatment facilities, which use the city's wastewater treatment facilities. All other wastewater lines and related facilities and structures of the municipal sewer system of the city, shall be managed by the director of public works. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.010; Ord. No. 1062, § 1, 10-13-99; Ord. No. 1349, § 1(Amd. 1), 4-11-2018) 
Sec. 20-3. - Unsanitary discharges. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.030) 
Sec. 20-4. - Connection to system required and permits. 
(a)  The owner of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is a public sanitary or combined sewer of the city, is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, within ninety (90) days after date of official notice to do so, provided that the public sewer is within one hundred (100) feet of the property line. 
(b)  The city may issue a permit for an individual or business to discharge sewage into the city's municipal sewer system, upon the request of an individual or business to do so, provided that the applicant agrees to comply with the requirements set forth in chapter 20 of the Municipal Code, including inspections upon request by the city. The permit shall be issued by the director of public works for a period of three (3) years. The permit under this section is not intended to replace any permits which may be required by State of Iowa. The cost of the permit shall be as set forth in section 25-4(b). 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.060; Ord. No. 1326, § 1, 3-22-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1326, § 1, adopted March 22, 2017, changed the title of § 20-4 from "Connection to system required" to read as herein set out. 
State Law reference- Power of council to require connections to sewer systems, I.C.A. § 364.12(2)(f). 
Sec. 20-5. - Grease, oil and sand interceptors. 
    Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the director of public works, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the director of public works, and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.320; Ord. No. 1062, § 1, 10-13-99) 
Sec. 20-6. - Grease traps and catch basins. 
    All drains from public garages, public or private greasing and automobile washing stations, kitchens, sinks of hotels and public eating houses, meat markets and from laundries, and all other places where deemed necessary by the director of public works, shall be provided with grease traps or catch basins, or both, in order to prevent plugging of the sewer by waste materials discharged from the properties. The outlet for such catch basins is to be properly trapped so as to prevent air from the sewer entering the building, and is to be provided with a back water trap to prevent water from the sanitary sewer backing up into the catch basin. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.450; Ord. No. 1062, § 1, 10-13-99) 
Sec. 20-7. - Preliminary treatment and flow equalizing facilities. 
    Where preliminary treatment or flow equalizing facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.330) 
Sec. 20-8. - Control manhole. 
    When required by the director of public works, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessible and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the director of public works. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.340; Ord. No. 1062, § 1, 10-13-99) 
Sec. 20-9. - Measurements and tests. 
(a)  All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," published by the American Public Health Association, and shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples taken at the control manhole. 
(b)  In the event that no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. 
(c)  Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb and property. (The particular analyses involved will determine whether a twenty-four-hour composite of all outfalls of a premise is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses are obtained from twenty-four-hour composites of all outfalls, whereas pH's are determined from periodic grab samples.) 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.350) 
Sec. 20-10. - Inspections. 
(a)  The director of public works and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The director of public works or his representatives shall have no authority to inquire into any processes including metallurgical, chemical, oil, refining, ceramic, paper or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterways or facilities for waste treatment. 
(b)  While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in subsection (a), the director of public works or duly authorized employees of the city shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the owner. 
(c)  The director of public works and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the city holds an easement for a public sewer acquired by prescription, or by a duly negotiated easement, for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying within the easement. 
(Code 1969, §§ 11.08.380-11.08.400; Ord. No. 1062, § 1, 10-13-99) 
Sec. 20-11. - Damaging system. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the sewage works. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.370) 
Sec. 20-12. - Chapter not exclusive. 
    No statement contained in this chapter shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by any health authority or the state department of environmental quality. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.150) 
Sec. 20-13. - Violations. 
(a)  Any person found to be violating any provision of this chapter except section 20-11, shall be served by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. 
(b)  Any person who continues any violation beyond the time limit provided for in subsection (a) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(c)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage occasioned the city by reason of such violation. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.570) 
Secs. 20-14-20-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS 

Sec. 20-25. - Generally. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b), it shall be unlawful for any person to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage unless approved by the city council. 
(b)  If a person is not required by the provisions of this chapter to have his property connected to a public sanitary or combined sewer, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system which complies with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1969, §§ 11.08.050, 11.08.070) 
Sec. 20-26. - Permit generally. 
    Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system its owner shall obtain a written permit signed by the director of public works. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications and other information as are deemed necessary by the director of public works. A permit and inspection fee shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed, in such amounts as are established in section 25-4. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.080; Ord. No. 848, § 1, 11-11-92; Ord. No. 1062, § 1, 10-13-99) 
Sec. 20-27. - When permit effective; inspection of work. 
    A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the director of public works. The director of public works shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction. The applicant for the permit shall notify the director of public works when the work is ready for final inspection, and before any underground portions are covered, and an inspection shall be made within twenty-four (24) hours of the receipt of such notice by the director of public works. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.070; Ord. No. 1062, § 1, 10-13-99) 
Sec. 20-28. - Compliance with state law. 
    The type, capacities, location and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the department of public health of the state. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.100) 
Sec. 20-29. - Minimum lot size where subsurface soil absorption used. 
    No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system which will use subsurface soil absorption facilities if the area of the lot on which it is to be located is less than twenty thousand (20,000) square feet. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.100) 
Sec. 20-30. - Discharges into natural outlets. 
    No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge into any natural outlet. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.100) 
Sec. 20-31. - Sanitation. 
    The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.120) 
Sec. 20-32. - Connection to public sewer required when available. 
    At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, as provided in section 20-4, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this chapter, at the property owners expense, and any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.110) 
Secs. 20-33-20-43. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 20-44. - Permit required. 
    No unauthorized person shall uncover, remove or make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof, without first obtaining a written permit from the director of public works or his designee. The application fee for such permit shall be in the amount established in section 25-3. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.160; Ord. No. 795, § 1, 3-13-91; Ord. No. 852, § 1, 11-11-92; Ord. No. 1051, § 1, 10-13-99; Ord. No. 1062, § 1, 10-13-99) 
Sec. 20-45. - Permit application. 
    A person desiring a building sewer permit shall file an application on a form furnished by the city. The application shall be supplemented by such plans, specifications or other information which the director of public works considers to be pertinent. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.170; Ord. No. 1062, § 1, 10-13-99) 
Sec. 20-46. - Classes of permits. 
    There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer permits as follows: 
(1)  Class A, for residential and commercial service; 
(2)  Class B, for service to establishments producing industrial wastes. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.170) 
Sec. 20-47. - Written permit required. 
    No unauthorized person shall uncover, remove or make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof, without first obtaining a written permit from the director of public works or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 808, § 1, 10-23-91; Ord. No. 1052, § 1, 10-13-99; Ord. No. 1062, § 1, 10-13-99) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 808, § 1, adopted October 23, 1991, amended § 20-47 to read as set out herein. Prior to such amendment, § 20-47 pertained to permit fees and derived from § 11.08.170 of the 1969 Code; and § 2 of Ord. No. 795, adopted March 13, 1991. 
Sec. 20-48. - Costs and civil liability. 
    All costs and expense incident to the installation, excavation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer and all excavations relating thereto. 
(Code 1969, §§ 11.08.180, 11.08.510) 
Sec. 20-49. - Separate building sewer required. 
    A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building, except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one (1) building sewer. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.190) 
Sec. 20-50. - Use of old building sewers. 
    Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the director of public works, to meet all requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.200; Ord. No. 1062, § 1, 10-13-99) 
Sec. 20-51. - General building sewer specifications. 
    The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the A.S.T.M. and W.P.C.F. Manual of Practice No. 9 shall apply. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.210) 
Sec. 20-52. - Elevation of building sewer; lifts. 
    Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.220) 
Sec. 20-53. - Connection to public sewer. 
(a)  The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city, or the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the A.S.T.M. and the W.P.C.F. Manual of Practice No. 9. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the director of public works before installation. 
(b)  The connection shall be made under the supervision of the director of public works or his delegate. 
(Code 1969, §§ 11.08.240, 11.08.250; Ord. No. 1062, § 1, 10-13-99) 
Sec. 20-54. - Sewer pipes in same trench as other pipes. 
    No sanitary sewer pipe shall be laid in the same trench with water, gas or other pipes, and all sewer connections must be laid far enough from all others to admit of the repair or removal or relaying of any one without disturbing the others. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.410) 
Sec. 20-55. - Sanitary sewers in subdivisions. 
    Any construction of a sanitary sewer in a subdivision shall be put in under the specifications approved by the contracting engineer service; concrete tile may be allowed in special cases when approved by the contracting engineer service. Manholes shall be precast concrete; (both bottom section and barrel/s section/s shall be of the same material). Adherence to ASTM-C478 shall apply. All manholes shall have poured in place polypropylene covered steps for entrance and exit. All manholes shall be connected with the rolled butyl provided by the manufacturer. It shall be the contractors responsibility to ensure this is provided at the time of delivery. All manholes shall come with the flow line pre-poured and the applicable A-lock locations pre-installed by the manufacturer. Manhole covers and rings shall be Neenah R-series. The frame shall be solid, regular lid-type C. All service connections to the main sewer shall be WYE's and shall be stubbed into the property line. Each main sewer installation is to be inspected and approved by the contracting engineer service, before it will be accepted by the city as part of its sanitary sewer system. The provisions of section 20-57, as they pertain to sewer construction, preparation of plans and specifications, application for a construction permit and sewer inspection requirements shall apply to subdivision development. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.490; Ord. No. 1050, § 1, 10-13-99) 
Sec. 20-56. - Construction/extension of lateral or trunk line sewer within the city limits. 
(a)  Prior to construction and/or extension of any lateral or trunk line sewer, which connects to a city public sanitary sewer, the extendor or constructor must apply for a construction permit as required by the Iowa Department of Environmental Quality and have notification in writing the approval of said sewer construction permit. Plans and specifications for said construction/extension of a sanitary sewer shall be prepared by a licensed engineer, reviewed and approved by the contracting engineer service. The applicant must agree at the time of request to extend and/or connect to a public sewer, to dedicate the sewer to the city immediately upon completion and acceptance by the city of the same. However, any adjacent property owner wishing to make a connection to the lateral trunk sewer within a period of ten (10) years from completion of same shall pay a connecting fee to the city in the amount established by the city council and on file in the office of the city clerk, which amount shall be remitted by the city to the original proprietor of the lateral or trunk sewer. 
(b)  The construction of any sanitary sewer shall be inspected by the contracting engineer service during installation and, upon the completion of installation, testing of the sewer will be done as specified by the city in accordance with DEQ requirements. A letter of certification from the contracting engineer service certifying proper installation and that the sewer satisfactorily meets tests as required by the city must be on file with the city prior to acceptance of any sewer. 
(c)  Costs involved in the preparation and/or review of plans/specifications, obtaining a construction permit from DEQ and sewer inspection shall be the financial responsibility of the constructor or extender. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to subdivision development. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.130; Ord. No. 1053, § 1, 10-13-99) 
Sec. 20-57. - Connection of sanitary sewer to city public sanitary sewer that serves property outside of city limits. 
(a)  Any person desiring to connect a sanitary sewer to public sewer system that serves property outside the city limits shall make a request to the city council for same and shall be subject to the same requirements that pertains to sewer construction, preparation of plans and specifications, application for a construction permit and sewer inspection requirements. However, the city need not necessarily require that a sewer outside the city limits be dedicated to the city. 
(b)  In addition thereto, the applicant shall pay the city a connection fee, to be agreed upon by the applicant and the city council. In arriving at the fee, the city shall be governed by the nature of the business of the user, the estimated amount of sewage to be placed in the city sewer system by the user, the cost of operation of the sewage disposal plant, the original cost of the sewage disposal plant, the estimated cost of additions to the sewage disposal plant, the assessed valuation of the property to be connected to the sewer system, and the tax rate imposed by the city upon city property for maintenance of the sewage disposal plant. The city may require the fee to be paid on a yearly basis or in one-lump sum. In addition thereto, the applicant shall agree that no other user shall connect onto his connection at any time unless the user makes application to the city therefor. In acting upon such application, the city council shall apply the same rules as provided for the original applicant. 
(c)  The minimum sewer rate charged for users outside the corporate city limits shall be double the rate fixed for uses within the corporate city limits, which rate shall include the base charge plus the usage fee. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.140; Ord. No. 749, § 1, 7-26-89) 
Sec. 20-58. - Notice when ready to connect. 
    The applicant for a building sewer permit shall notify the director of public works when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.250; Ord. No. 1062, § 1, 10-13-99) 
Sec. 20-59. - Excavations. 
    All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.260) 
Sec. 20-60. - Abandoned sewer. 
    Whenever a building sewer is to be abandoned, it shall be the responsibility of the owner to properly seal the sewer line to prevent the intrusion of groundwater to the sanitary sewer. The seal will be placed at the closest practical point between the building and the sanitary sewer or at the direction of the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 697, § 1, 10-28-87) 
Secs. 20-61-20-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PROHIBITED DISCHARGES 

Sec. 20-71. - Discharges into natural outlets. 
    It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city any sewage or other polluted waters except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.040) 
Sec. 20-72. - Discharges of stormwater, groundwater or industrial cooling water. 
(a)  Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the director of public works. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, on approval of the director of public works, to a storm sewer, combined sewer or natural outlet. 
(b)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any storm water, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(c)  No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater into a public sanitary sewer or into a building sewer or building drain which is connected, directly or indirectly, to a public sanitary sewer. 
(d)  No groundwater shall be drained into the public sanitary sewers, nor into the sanitary sewer of any house, or branch sewer that connects with the public sanitary sewer of the city. No open, jointed, footing drain or farm drain tile shall be permitted to be connected to such sewer of the city. However, the water from cellar floors may be admitted therein, provided that a good and approved bell trap or other metal trap, with tight metal covers are screwed into the floor. All such cellar floors having the traps shall be of solid concrete construction. 
(e)  No person shall make any connection from a submersible pump, or its discharge line, to a sanitary sewer or line to a sanitary sewer. 
(f)  All surface water runoff or groundwater collected by a roof drain or downspout, sump pump, exterior foundation or footing drain, stormwater drain or drainage tile, shall be directed to an established ditch, storm drain, drainage easement or public stream. Said collected surface water runoff or groundwater shall be dispersed entirely upon the grounds of the owner of the contributing property. In no event shall said collected surface water runoff or groundwater be conveyed to or discharged into any portion of the city street, other than directly into a storm drain. 
(g)  Exemption. The prohibition to discharge into any portion of the city street, as described in subsection (f), shall not apply to drainage systems that existed as of July 1, 2009. Said exempted drainage systems that drain into a city street shall be required to drain directly into a storm drain, if said system is modified, or at such time as the city replaces existing municipal storm drainage system adjacent to said real estate where the exempted drainage system is located. 
(Code 1969, §§ 11.08.230, 11.08.270, 11.08.280, 11.08.530, 11.08.540; Ord. No. 967, § 1, 1-8-97; Ord. No. 1062, § 1, 10-13-99; Ord. No. 1204, § 1, 6-10-2009) 
Sec. 20-73. - Items specifically prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following, described water or wastes to any public sewers: 
(1)  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas. 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant, including but not limited to cyanides in excess of two (2) milligrams per liter as CN in the wastes as discharged to the public sewer. 
(3)  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 6.0 or higher than 9.0, or any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and personnel of the sewage works. 
(4)  Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails and paper products, such as paper dishes, cups, milk containers, napkins, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.290; Ord. No. 884, § 1, 10-13-93) 
Sec. 20-74. - Items director of public works may prohibit. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described substances, materials, waters, or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the director of public works that such wastes can harm either the sewers, sewage treatment process or equipment, have an adverse effect on the receiving stream, or can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property, or constitute a nuisance. In forming his opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes, the director of public works will give consideration to such factors as quantities of subject wastes in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage treatment plant, degree of treatability of wastes in the sewage treatment plant and other pertinent factors. The substances prohibited are: 
(1)  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit (sixty-five (65) degrees Celsius). 
(2)  Any water or waste containing fats, wax, grease or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred (100) milligrams per liter or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between thirty-two (32) and one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit (zero and sixty-five (65) degrees Celsius). 
(3)  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to the review and approval of the director of public works. 
(4)  Any waters or wastes containing strong acid iron pickling wastes, or concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not. 
(5)  Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc and similar objectionable or toxic substances, or wastes exerting an excessive chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such material received in the composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the limits established by the director of public works for such materials. 
(6)  Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste- or odor-producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be established by the director of public works as necessary, after treatment of the composite sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal or other public agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters. 
(7)  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the director of public works in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations. 
(8)  Any waters or wastes having a pH in excess of 9.5. 
(9)  Materials which exert or cause: 
a.  Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, Fullers earth, lime, slurries and lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate), 
b.  Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions), 
c.  Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand or chlorine requirements in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewage treatment works, 
d.  Unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes constituting "slugs." 
(10)  Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.300; Ord. No. 1062, § 1, 10-13-99) 
Sec. 20-75. - Actions director of public works may take with reference to items he may prohibit. 
(a)  If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in section 20-70, and which in the judgment of the director of public works, may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, processes, equipment or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the director of public works may: 
(1)  Reject the wastes; 
(2)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; 
(3)  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or 
(4)  Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes, or sewer charges under the provisions of section 20-77. 
(b)  If the director of public works or responsible plant operating personnel permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the director of public works, and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, ordinances and laws. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.310; Ord. No. 1054, § 1, 10-13-99; Ord. No. 1062, § 1, 10-13-99) 
Sec. 20-76. - Special agreements. 
    No statement contained in this article shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern, whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment, subject to payment therefore, by the industrial concern. 
(Code 1969, § 11.08.360) 
Secs. 20-77-20-88. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RATES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 20-89. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this article shall be as follows: 
    BOD 5 (denoting the five-day Biochemical Oxygen Demand) shall mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
    Normal domestic wastewater shall mean wastewater that has a BOD concentration of not more than two hundred (200) milligrams per liter, a suspended solids concentration of not more than two hundred (200) milligrams per liter, and an ammonia nitrogen concentration of not more than twenty (20) milligrams per liter. 
    Operation and maintenance shall mean all expenditures during the useful life of the treatment works for materials, labor, utilities, and other items which are necessary for managing and maintaining the treatment works to achieve the performance for which such works were designed and constructed. 
    Pollutants shall mean any chemical or biological materials that are treatable at the wastewater treatment plant, the treatment of which results in a cost to the operation and maintenance of the treatment plant. 
    Replacement shall mean expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories, or appurtenances which are necessary during the useful life of the treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes replacement. 
    Residential contributor shall mean any contributor to the city's treatment works whose lot, parcel of real estate, or building is used for domestic dwelling purposes only. 
    SS (denoting suspended solids) shall mean solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, sewage, or other liquids and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Surcharge shall mean a special additional charge to reimburse the city for the costs of treating pollutants in excess of those normally found in domestic wastewater. 
    Toxic pollutants shall mean any material that would restrict the ultimate disposal of the treated wastewater or the treated sludge, or would adversely restrict the treatment efficiency of the treatment system. 
    Treatment works shall mean any devices or systems for the storage, treatment, recycling, and reclamation of municipal sewage, domestic sewage, or liquid industrial wastes. These include intercepting sewers, outfall sewers, sewage collection systems, individual systems, pumping, power, and other equipment and their appurtenances; extensions, improvement, remodeling, additions and alterations thereof, elements essential to provide a reliable recycled supply such as standby treatment units and clear well facilities; and any works, including site acquisition of the land that will be an integral part of the treatment process or is used for ultimate disposal of residues resulting from such treatment (including land for composting sludge, temporary storage of such compost, and land used for the storage of treated wastewater in land treatment systems before land application); or any other method or system for preventing, abating, reducing, storing, treating, separating, or disposing of municipal waste or industrial waste, including waste in combined stormwater and sanitary sewer systems, sewer systems. 
    Useful life shall mean the estimated period during which a treatment works will be operated. 
    User charge shall mean that portion of the total wastewater service charge which is levied in a proportional and adequate manner for the cost of debt retirement, operation, maintenance, and replacement of the wastewater treatment works. 
    Water meter shall mean a water volume measuring and recording device, furnished and/or installed by the city or furnished and/or installed by a user and approved by the city. 
(Ord. No. 538, Art. II, 7-2-80; Ord. No. 1166, § 1, 4-12-2006) 
Sec. 20-90. - Purpose. 
    It is determined and declared to be necessary and conducive to the protection of the public health, safety, welfare and convenience of the city to collect charges from all users who contribute wastewater to the city's treatment works. The proceeds of such charges so derived will be used for the purpose of operating, maintaining, and retiring the debt for such public wastewater treatment works. 
(Ord. No. 538, Art. I, 7-2-80) 
Sec. 20-91. - General basis and classification. 
(a)  The user charge system shall generate adequate annual revenues to pay costs of annual operation and maintenance costs, and the costs for debt retirement associated with financing the treatment works which the city by this article designates to be paid by the user charge system. 
(b)  Those portions of the total user charge collected which is designated for operation and maintenance purposes, replacement purposes and debt retirement purposes, as established in section 20-92 hereof, shall be deposited in a separate nonlapsing fund, to be known as the "sewer revenue fund," and shall be dispersed only as follows: 
(1)  Sewer utility fund. Money in the replacement fund shall first be disbursed to make deposits into a separate and special fund to pay current expenses. The fund shall be known as the "sewer utility fund." There shall be deposited in the sewer utility fund each month an amount sufficient to meet the current expenses of the month, plus an amount equal to one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) of the expenses payable on an annual basis, such as insurance. After the first day of the month, further deposits may be made to this account from the replacement fund to the extent necessary to pay current expenses accrued and payable to the extent that funds are not available in the surplus fund. 
(2)  Debt service. Money in the replacement fund shall next be disbursed to make deposits into a separate and special fund to pay principal of and interest on the bonds and parity bonds. The fund shall be known as the "sewer revenue bond and interest debt service fund." The required amount to be deposited in the debt service fund in any month shall be an amount equal to one-sixth ( 1/6 ) of the installment of interest coming due on the next interest payment date on the then outstanding bonds and parity bonds, plus one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) of the installment of principal coming due on such bonds on the next succeeding principal payment date until the full amount of such installment is on hand. If, for any reason, the amount on hand in the debt service fund exceeds the required amount, the excess shall forthwith be withdrawn and paid into the replacement fund. Money in the debt service fund shall be used solely for the purpose of paying principal of and interest on the bonds and parity bonds as the same shall become due and payable. 
(3)  Subordinate obligations. Money in the replacement fund may next be used to pay principal of and interest on (including reasonable reserves therefor) any other obligations which, by their terms, shall be payable from the revenues of the system but subordinate to the bonds and parity bonds, and which have been issued for the purposes of extensions and improvements to the system or to retire the bonds or parity bonds in advance of maturity, or to pay for extraordinary repairs or replacements to the system. 
(4)  Replacement fund. All money thereafter remaining in the replacement fund at the close of each month may be deposited in any of the funds created by this subsection to pay for extraordinary repairs or replacements to the system, or may be used to pay or redeem the bonds or parity bonds, any of them, or for any lawful purpose. 
Money in the replacement fund may next be used to pay principal and interest on (including reasonable reserves therefor) any other obligations which, by their terms, shall be payable from the revenues of the system but subordinate to the bonds and parity bonds, and which have been issued for the purpose of extensions and improvements to the system. 
(c)  Fiscal year-end balances in the operation and maintenance account, the replacement account, and the debt retirement account shall be carried over to the same accounts in the subsequent fiscal year, and shall be used for no other purposes than those designated for these accounts. Monies which have been transferred from other sources to meet temporary shortages in the operation, maintenance and replacement fund shall be returned to their respective accounts upon appropriate adjustment of the user charge rates for operation, maintenance and replacement. The user charge rate(s) shall be adjusted such that the transferred monies will be returned to their respective accounts within the fiscal year following the fiscal year in which the monies were borrowed. 
(Ord. No. 538, Art. III, 7-2-80; Ord. No. 616, § 1, 2-15-84; Ord. No. 729, § 1, 12-14-88; Ord. No. 1061, § 1, 10-13-99) 
Sec. 20-92. - Means of determination and specific rates. 
(a)  Each user shall pay for the services provided by the city based on his use of the treatment works. Water meter readings will be the normal basis for computing usage. 
(b)  For industrial, commercial and residential contributors, use charges will be based on water used during the current month. If a commercial, industrial or residential contributor has a consumptive use of water or in some other manner uses water which is not returned to the wastewater collection system, the user charge for that contributor may be based upon wastewater meters or separate water meters installed and maintained at the contributor's expense and in a manner acceptable to the city. 
(c)  The minimum charge per month shall be in the amount established in section 25-11(a). In addition, each contributor shall pay a user charge rate for operation and maintenance, including replacement, in the amount established in section 25-11(a), the same to be calculated per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water (or wastewater) as determined in the preceding subsection. 
(d)  For those contributors who contribute wastewater, the strength of which is greater than normal domestic sewage, a surcharge in addition to the normal user charge will be collected. The surcharge for operation and maintenance, including replacement is as follows: 
(1)  Charge per pound BOD as established in section 25-11(a)(2)a. 
(2)  Charge per pound SS as established in section 25-11(a)(2)b. 
(3)  Charge per pound of ammonia nitrogen as established in section 25-11(a)(2)c. 
(e)  Any user which discharges any toxic pollutants which cause an increase in the cost of managing the effluent of the sludge from the city's treatment works, or any user which discharges any substance which singly or by interaction with other substances caused identifiable increases in the cost of operation, maintenance or replacement of the treatment works, shall pay for such increased costs. The charge to each such user shall be as determined by the responsible plant operating personnel and approved by the city council. 
(f)  The user charge rate established in this section shall apply to all users within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 538, Art. IV, 7-2-80; Ord. No. 550, § 1, 3-18-81; Ord. No. 642, § 1, 3-20-85; Ord. No. 725, § 1, 9-14-88; Ord. No. 749, § 1, 7-26-89; Ord. No. 850, § 1, 11-11-92) 
Sec. 20-93. - Billing date; due date; penalty for late payment. 
(a)  All users shall be billed monthly. Payments are due and payable when the billings are made. Any payments not received within twenty (20) days after the billing is made shall be delinquent. 
(b)  A late payment penalty of one and one-half (11/2) percent per month of the user charge bill will be added to each delinquent bill. When any bill is thirty (30) days in default, water and/or sewer service to such premises may be discontinued until such bill is paid following due notice and opportunity for hearing. Bills sixty (60) days in default shall be certified by the city clerk and submitted to the county treasurer as a tax lien against the property. 
(Ord. No. 538, Art. V, 7-2-80; Ord. No. 540, §§ 1, 2, 8-20-80; Ord. No. 608, § 2, 9-7-83) 
Sec. 20-94. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1061, § 2, adopted Oct. 13, 1999, deleted former § 20-94 of the Code, which pertained to annual review and notice and derived from Ord. No. 538, Art. VI, adopted July 2, 1980. 
Secs. 20-95-20-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 735, § 1, adopted Apr. 12, 1989, amended the Code and has been codified herein by the editor as Art. VI, §§ 20-101-20-104. 
Cross reference- Police department, Ch. 18. 

Sec. 20-101. - Purpose. 
    In order to reduce the danger to public health, safety and welfare from the spills of hazardous substances, these regulations are promulgated to establish responsibility for the removal and cleanup of spills within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-12-89) 
Sec. 20-102. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, these words have the following meanings: 
    Cleanup means the same as set out in Section 455B.381(6), Code of Iowa. 
    Hazardous condition means the same as set out in Section 455B.381(2), Code of Iowa. 
    Hazardous substance means any substance as defined in Section 455B.381(1), Code of Iowa. 
    Hazardous waste means those wastes which are included by the definition in Section 455B.411(3)(a), Code of Iowa, and the rules of the Iowa Department of Natural Resources. 
    Person having control over a hazardous substance means the same as set out in Section 455B.381(8), Code of Iowa. 
    Treatment means a method, technique or process, including neutralization designed to change the physical, chemical or biological character or composition of a hazardous substance so as to neutralize it or to render the substance nonhazardous, safe for transport, amenable for recovery, amenable for storage or to reduce it in volume. Treatment includes any activity or processing designed to change the physical form or chemical composition of a hazardous substance to render it nonhazardous. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-12-89) 
Sec. 20-103. - Cleanup required. 
    Whenever a hazardous condition is created by the deposit, injection, dumping, spilling, leaking or placing of a hazardous waste or substance so that the hazardous substance or waste or a constituent of the hazardous waste or substance may enter the environment or be emitted into the air or discharged into any waters, including groundwaters, the responsible person shall cause the condition to be remedied by a cleanup, as defined in the preceding section, as rapidly as feasible to an acceptable, safe condition. The costs of cleanup shall be borne by the person having control over a hazardous substance. If the person having control over a hazardous substance does not cause the cleanup to begin in a reasonable time in relation to the hazard and circumstances of the incident, the city may proceed to procure cleanup services and bill the responsible person. If the bill for those services is not paid within thirty (30) days, the city attorney shall proceed to obtain payment by all legal means. If the cost of the cleanup is beyond the capacity of the city to finance it, the authorized officer shall report to the council and immediately seek any state or federal funds available for said cleanup. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-12-89) 
Sec. 20-104. - Notifications. 
    The first city officer or employee who arrives at the scene of an incident involving hazardous substances, if not a peace officer, shall notify the police department which shall notify the proper state office in the manner established by the state. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 1, 4-12-89) 
Chapter 21 - SOLID WASTES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- City administrator, § 2-22; litter, Ch. 11; sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 20; solid waste charges, § 25-13; refuse in mobile home parks, App. C, § 31. 
State Law reference- Solid waste disposal, I.C.A. § 435B.75 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter the following terms shall have the meaning indicated below: 
    Bulky rubbish: Nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of combustible or noncombustible waste materials from dwelling units, commercial, industrial, institutional or agricultural establishments which are either too large or too heavy to be safely and conveniently loaded in solid waste collection vehicles by solid waste collectors, with the equipment available therefor. The following materials/items are specifically defined as "bulky rubbish": sod resulting from lawn renovation, debris resulting from construction/repair of residences, car bodies and car parts that exceed the fifty-pound weight limit, water heaters, heating system duct materials, bed springs, mattresses, dressers, couches, davenports, chairs, tables, washers, dryers, television sets, ironers, refrigerators, freezers, stoves, air conditioners, patio and yard furniture and other household items of a similar nature, tires and carpets that exceed fifty (50) pounds. The following materials/items will be classified as "bulky rubbish" unless placed in suitable containers with acceptable handles not weighing more in aggregate in any combination or more than the fifty-pound limit. Materials/items in this classification are concrete, asphalt, dirt, rock, sand, gravel, or bricks. Trees/tree limbs, shrubs and bushes shall be classified as "bulky rubbish" unless securely tied in bundles not larger than forty-eight (48) inches long and eighteen (18) inches in diameter, when not placed in a storage container. 
    Collection: The removal and transportation of solid waste from its place of storage to its place of processing or disposal. 
    Commercial refuse: Solid waste resulting from the operation of any commercial, industrial, institutional or agricultural establishment and multiple housing facilities with more than four (4) dwelling units. 
    Commission: The Des Moines County Solid Waste Management Commission. 
    Demolition and construction waste: Waste materials from the construction or destruction of residential, industrial or commercial structures. 
    Director: The director of public works or the designee. 
    Disposable solid waste plastic bags. A disposable solid waste plastic bag that does not exceed forty-five (45) pounds in weight and thirty-three (33) gallons in bulk capacity when filled with solid waste. 
    Dwelling unit: Any room or group of rooms located within a structure, and forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are used, or are intended to be used, for living, sleeping, cooking and eating. 
    Garbage: Putrescible animal or vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, serving or consumption of food. 
    Hazardous wastes: The term "hazardous wastes" shall include but not be limited to explosive wastes, pesticides, pesticide containers, toxic or radioactive materials. 
    Health authority: The county board of health or its duly authorized representative. 
    Multiple housing facility: A housing facility containing more than four (4) dwelling units under one roof. 
    Processing: The use of incinerators, balers, shredders or any other process employed to reduce the volume of or change the characteristics of solid waste prior to sanitary landfilling. 
    Refuse: Unwanted or discarded material resulting from commercial, industrial and agricultural operations and from normal community activities. Waste refuse includes in part the following: garbage; rubbish; ashes and other residue after burning; street refuse; dead animals; animal waste; abandoned vehicles; agricultural, commercial and industrial waste; construction and demolition waste and sewage treatment residue. Refuse shall mean all solid waste. 
    Residential premises: Single dwelling units and any multiple dwelling units up to and including four (4) separate dwelling units. 
    Residential refuse: Solid waste resulting from the maintenance and operation of dwelling units, excluding multiple housing facilities with more than four (4) dwelling units. 
    Sanitary landfill: A controlled method of disposing of refuse on land without creating air, land and water pollution or nuisances or hazards to public health or safety, by utilizing the principles of engineering to confine the refuse to the smallest practical volume, and to cover it with a layer of earth at the conclusion of each day's operation, or at more frequent intervals as may be necessary. 
    Solid waste: All garbage, refuse and yard wastes. Rubbish is not solid waste. 
    Solid waste container. A tied disposable solid waste plastic bag used by a person to store solid waste during the interval between solid waste collections which does not exceed forty-five (45) pounds in weight and thirty-three (33) gallons in bulk capacity when filled with solid waste. 
    Solid waste disposal: The process of discarding or getting rid of unwanted material. In particular, the final disposition of solid waste by man. 
    Solid waste management: The entire solid waste system of storage, collection, transportation, processing and disposal. 
    Storage: The keeping, maintaining or storing of solid waste from the time of its production until the time of its collection. 
    Yard wastes: Grass clippings, leaves, tree trimmings and other organic materials as approved by the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 454, §§ 2, 4.6, 12-17-75; Ord. No. 480, §§ 1, 3, 6-1-77; Ord. No. 787, § 1, 8-24-90; Ord. No. 792, § 1, 12-12-90; Ord. No. 1068, § 1, 1-12-00; Ord. No. 1093, §§ 1-3, 5-23-2001) 
Sec. 21-2. - Collection. 
    The city shall provide for the collection of solid waste as follows: 
(1)  The city shall provide for the collection of residential solid waste in the city for all residences utilizing the garbage sticker system. 
(2)  The city may provide collection services by contracting with a person, commission, county or other city or a combination thereof, for the entire city or portions thereof, as deemed to be in the best interests of the city. 
(3)  The council may by resolution designate special solid waste collection or trash collection days, when collection of solid waste other than what is specified in this section is collected, by the city or other council-approved collectors. 
(4)  The city shall provide for the collection of commercial solid waste in the city for all commercial establishments that are utilizing the garbage sticker system. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 4.1, 12-17-75; Ord. No. 794, § 1, 2-27-91) 
Sec. 21-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 805, § 1, adopted July 24, 1991 amended the Code by repealing § 21-3. Prior to such amendment, § 21-3 pertained to a permit for private collection and disposal services and derived from Ord. No. 454, § 7, adopted Dec. 17, 1975 and Ord. No. 787, § 2, adopted Aug. 24, 1990. 
Sec. 21-4. - Tree limbs. 
    Tree limbs, which are less than two (2) inches in diameter, and brush shall be securely tied in bundles not larger than forty-eight (48) inches long and eighteen (18) inches in diameter when not placed in storage containers. The weight of any individual bundle shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 3.5, 12-17-75) 
Sec. 21-4.1. - Separation of yard wastes required. 
    All yard wastes shall be separated by the owner or occupant from all other garbage and refuse accumulated on the premises and shall be composted on the premises or placed in disposable solid waste containers and set out for collection on designated days by the city or set out for collection by an approved private contractor or transported by the occupant to the city yard waste area. 
(Ord. No. 792, § 2, 12-12-90) 
Sec. 21-5. - Interference with collectors or equipment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere in any manner with solid waste collection equipment, or with solid waste collectors in the lawful performance of their duties as such, whether such equipment or collectors are those of the city, or those of a solid waste collection agency operating under contract with the city. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 7, 12-17-75) 
Sec. 21-6. - Enforcement. 
    Failure to comply with this section by any person, or tenant in cases were a lease agreement gives specific responsibility for solid waste disposal to said tenant, shall be a municipal infraction. If a person violates the provisions of this section by transporting waste to a landfill not authorized by this chapter, each trip to the unauthorized landfill shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 11, 12-17-75; Ord. No. 1157, § 1, 9-13-2005) 
Sec. 21-7. - Sticker requirements for garbage pickup services. 
(a)  Each residential dwelling unit, including but not limited to houses, mobile homes or multifamily facilities, shall subscribe to the city's garbage pickup service, unless the occupant or owner of the residential dwelling unit provides for private garbage pickup. 
(b)  Each commercial establishment may subscribe to the city's garbage pickup service, unless the facility provides for private commercial collection. 
(c)  Each residential dwelling unit, including but not limited to houses, mobile homes or multifamily facilities, and each commercial establishment subscribing to the city's garbage pickup service, shall be required to purchase garbage stickers from participating city retailers. Participating retailers may purchase garbage stickers in bulk from the city. The cost of the stickers shall be in the amount established in section 25-13(a). Participating retailers may not increase the price per sticker to an amount above the price fixed by the city council. Nothing in this subsection, however, will be construed to prohibit a retailer from charging less per sticker than the amount fixed by the city council, such lesser amount to be set at the retailer's discretion. The purchase locations and the charge per sticker may be adjusted from time to time, as needed, by resolution of the city council. 
(d)  All persons or businesses shall affix a sticker approved by the city to each tied disposable solid waste plastic bag. Any disposable solid waste plastic bags that do not have a sticker affixed to it will not be collected. 
(e)  Collectable tree limbs, as defined in this chapter, that are properly bundled will require a sticker. 
(f)  Any disposable solid waste containers or permanent solid waste containers that are used for yard waste, with the exclusion of bagged leaves that are collected on designated dates by the city, shall require the placement of a sticker. 
(g)  Leaves that have been collected in disposable solid waste containers will be collected by the city twice each year, on dates to be determined by the city administrator, and no stickers will be required to be placed on the collected bags. 
(h)  Free disposal of all tied plastic bags of yard waste or any other organic bulky rubbish, whether tied, secured or otherwise, is available to persons transporting the same to the city's yard waste collection area, which location is to be designated by the city administrator.
