(Ord. No. 454, § 6, 12-17-75; Ord. No. 509, § 1, 6-20-79; Ord. No. 524, § 1, 3-19-80; Ord. No. 552, § 1, 4-15-81; Ord. No. 711, § 1, 3-23-88; Ord. No. 714, § 1, 5-11-88; Ord. No. 787, § 3, 8-24-90; Ord. No. 794, § 2, 2-27-91; Ord. No. 851, § 1, 11-11-92; Ord. No. 997, § 1, 10-8-97; Ord. No. 1068, § 1, 1-12-00; Ord. No. 1093, § 4, 5-23-2001) 
Sec. 21-7.1. - Mandatory monthly fee to residential, multifamily, commercial and other business premises. 
(a)  Each residential dwelling unit shall be billed a monthly collection charge in the amount established in section 25-13(c)(1), regardless of its participation or lack of participation in the city garbage pickup services. 
(b)  Each apartment unit or mobile home shall be billed a monthly collection charge in the amount established in section 25-13(c)(2), regardless of its participation or lack of participation in the city garbage pickup services. For those units or mobile homes that are on a shared meter system, the owner shall be billed the monthly amount determined herein multiplied by the number of units or mobile homes. 
(c)  Each commercial or business facility shall be billed a monthly collection charge in the amount established in section 25-13(c)(3), regardless of its participation or lack of participation in the city garbage pickup services. For those businesses that are on a shared meter system, the owner shall be billed the monthly amount determined herein multiplied by the number of commercial or business units. 
(d)  The collection charge described in this section shall be billed on the applicable owner's occupier's monthly utility statement. All payments for the collection charge shall be due twenty (20) days from the date the billing is mailed. 
(e)  Each residential dwelling unit, apartment unit, mobile home, commercial or business facility as described in paragraphs (a), (b) and (c), shall be billed a Henry County Landfill Commission surcharge of one dollar ($1.00) per month, or such other amount as is determined by resolution of the city council, the same to be billed to the owner's monthly utility statement in the manner described in paragraph (d). 
(f)  Each residential dwelling unit, apartment unit, and mobile home, shall be billed a monthly collection charge in the amount established in section 25-13(c)(4), which sum shall represent a recycling fee that has not otherwise been included in the garbage pickup fee described in paragraph (a), supra. The collection charge shall be billed as described in paragraph (d), supra. 
(Ord. No. 787, § 4, 8-24-90; Ord. No. 794, § 2A, 2-27-91; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-29-92; Ord. No. 849, § 1, 11-11-92; Ord. No. 1006, § 1, 1-28-98) 
Sec. 21-8. - Exemption. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall apply to: 
(1)  The filling, leveling or grading of land with earth, sand, ashes, cinders, slag, gravel, rock or similar inert wastes, provided these materials are not contaminated or mixed with other waste materials; 
(2)  The disposal of animal and agricultural wastes on farm land. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 5.6, 12-17-75) 
Secs. 21-9-21-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONTAINERS 

Sec. 21-20. - Required, maintenance. 
    The owner of every dwelling and, in the case of a private dwelling, the occupant of every dwelling unit and the owner of every institutional, commercial or business, industrial or agricultural establishment producing solid waste within the city shall provide sufficient and adequate solid waste containers for the storage of all solid waste, except bulky rubbish and demolition and construction waste, to serve each dwelling unit or establishment and maintain such containers in good repair and in a secure location. The city administrator shall have the authority to determine the acceptability of a container and notify the owner of their need to replace any nonacceptable containers. Solid wastes that are placed in containers that do not meet city approval will not be collected. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 3.1, 12-17-75; Ord. No. 787, § 5, 8-24-90) 
Sec. 21-21. - Sanitation. 
    The owner of every dwelling and in the case of a private dwelling, the occupant of every dwelling unit and of every institutional, commercial, industrial, agricultural or business establishment shall place all solid waste to be collected in proper solid waste containers, except as otherwise provided herein, and shall maintain such solid waste containers and the area surrounding them in a clean, neat and sanitary condition at all times. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 3.2, 12-17-75) 
Sec. 21-22. - Outdoor containers. 
    Residential solid waste (excluding yard waste) which is stored in a building shall be placed in a metal or equivalent container that shall be leakproof, waterproof and fitted with a flyproof lid. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 3.3, 12-17-75; Ord. No. 1068, § 1, 1-12-00) 
Sec. 21-23. - Commercial waste. 
    Commercial solid waste shall be stored in solid waste containers as approved by the director. The containers shall be waterproof, leakproof and covered at all times except when depositing waste therein or removing the contents thereof, and shall meet all applicable requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 3.4, 12-17-75) 
Sec. 21-24. - Yard waste. 
    Persons choosing not to compost their yard wastes on their own property or at the yard waste collection area may place yard wastes in disposable solid waste containers. The weight of any individual container and contents shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 3.6, 12-17-75; Ord. No. 792, § 3, 12-12-90) 
Sec. 21-25. - Transportation. 
    Solid waste containers that by their nature are subject to transportation over the roads of this city shall be subject to rules and regulations promulgated by the health authority. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 3.7, 12-17-75) 
Sec. 21-26. - Placing solid wastes in another's container. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit solid waste in any solid waste container other than his own without the written consent of the owner of such container. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 7, 12-17-75) 
Sec. 21-27. - Placing solid wastes in public receptacles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or dispose of their collective residential solid wastes in a public receptacle in lieu of utilizing the required sticker method of disposal. 
(Ord. No. 787, § 6, 8-24-90) 
Secs. 21-28-21-37. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COLLECTION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-38. - Placement of refuse for collection. 
    Collectible tree limbs and yard wastes shall be placed at the curb for collection. Solid waste containers shall be placed at the curb or other specified locations as designated by resolution of the council for collections. Any solid waste containers, tree limbs, yard wastes or other solid wastes permitted by this chapter to be placed at the curb for collection shall not be so placed prior to 6:00 p.m. immediately preceding the regularly scheduled collection day. Solid waste containers shall be removed from the right-of-way within twenty-four (24) hours of collection of the solid waste. 
(Ord. No. 454, §§ 4.3, 4.6, 12-17-75; Ord. No. 480, § 3, 6-1-77; Ord. No. 787, § 7, 8-24-90; Ord. No. 1341, § 1, 1-10-2018) 
Sec. 21-39. - Items city will collect. 
    All solid waste from premises to which collection services are provided by the city shall be collected except bulky rubbish; provided, however, that bulky rubbish will be collected if tied securely in bundles not exceeding reasonable limitations of weight and bulk as described in the definition if bulky rubbish contained in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 454, §§ 4.2, 4.6, 12-17-75; Ord. No. 480, § 3, 6-1-77; Ord. No. 787, § 8, 8-24-90) 
Sec. 21-40. - Title to collected waste. 
    When solid waste is loaded into collection equipment, it shall become the property of the collection agency. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 4.2, 12-17-75) 
Sec. 21-41. - Intervals. 
(a)  All residential solid waste, other than bulky rubbish, shall be collected by the city garbage pickup services or by a licensed private hauler, at least once weekly. 
(b)  All commercial solid waste shall be collected by the city garbage pickup services or by a licensed commercial hauler, at least once weekly. Collection at such lesser intervals may be fixed by the city administrator upon a determination that lesser intervals are necessary for the preservation of the public health and safety. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 4.5, 12-17-75; Ord. No. 787, § 9, 8-24-90; Ord. No. 794, § 3, 2-27-91) 
Sec. 21-42. - Vehicles. 
    All vehicles used for the collection of solid wastes or the transportation and disposal of demolition or construction wastes shall be maintained in a safe, clean and sanitary condition, and shall be so constructed, maintained and operated as to prevent spillage or loss of solid waste or demolition or construction wastes. 
(Ord. No. 454, §§ 4.7, 4.9, 12-17-75) 
Secs. 21-43-21-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESERVED[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1060, § 1, adopted Oct. 13, 1999, deleted Ch. 12, Art. III, Div. 2, in its entirety. Former Div. 2, §§ 21-46-21-52, pertained to collection permits and derived from Ord. No. 782, §§ 1-7, adopted June 27, 1990; Ord. No. 804, § 1, adopted July 24, 1991; Ord. No. 853, § 1, adopted Nov. 11, 1992; and Ord. No. 956, § 1, adopted Jan. 10, 1996. 

Secs. 21-46-21-53. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DISPOSAL 

Sec. 21-54. - Generally. 
    Solid wastes shall be disposed of at a processing facility or disposal area approved by the commission and complying with all requirements of the state department of health or department of environmental quality. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 5.1, 12-17-85) 
Sec. 21-55. - Use of approved facility required. 
    All of the city's solid waste disposed of within the State of Iowa shall be transported to the Des Moines County Regional Landfill unless the contractor obtains a written waiver from the city to deposit waste at an alternate site identified and included in the comprehensive plan of the Des Moines County Regional Solid Waste Commission. 
    No person shall engage in the collecting, transporting, or disposing of solid waste, other than his own, within the city without first obtaining from the Des Moines County Regional Waste Commission an annual permit. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 7, 12-17-75; Ord. No. 1157, § 2, 9-13-2005; Ord. No. 1158, § 1, 9-28-2005) 
Sec. 21-56. - Hazardous wastes. 
    The commission or health authority may classify certain wastes as hazardous wastes which will require special handling and shall be disposed of only in a manner acceptable to the commission or health authority and which will meet all local, state and federal regulations. 
(Ord. No. 454, §§ 5.1, 5.2, 12-17-75) 
Sec. 21-57. - Disposing of garbage or refuse in the city. 
    No person shall dispose of garbage or refuse of any kind within the city. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 5.5, 12-17-75) 
Sec. 21-58. - Private landfills prohibited. 
    There shall be no private landfills operated in the city. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 5.4, 12-17-75) 
Sec. 21-59. - Incinerators. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or to install any device intended for use as a garbage or refuse burner or incinerator unless the intended user of such a device has secured a permit from the state and a license to operate such a device from the health authority, or when the device will be operated by or for the city. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 5.7, 12-17-75) 
Sec. 21-60. - Burning. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to burn, incinerate or permit the burning or incineration of any garbage or bulky rubbish, as defined in section 21-1 herein. For the purpose of this section "garbage" and "bulky rubbish" shall not include leaves, garden debris, tree and bush trimmings with a diameter no larger than two (2) inches. No burning shall be permitted 1) on public sidewalks, 2) the public right-of-way, 3) city parks, except where designated by the city or 4), within twenty-five (25) feet of any buildings, including garages and storage sheds. Any burning shall be attended by an adult with a charged water hose. Burning is permitted only when it can be done in a safe manner and without smoke being blown beyond the property where the burning is being done. This section shall not apply to any person operating under a state permit and a license granted by a health authority, or any incinerator operated by or for the city, or any burning conducted under the direction of the fire department, or ceremonial fires authorized by the city. 
(Ord. No. 454, §§ 5.8, 7, 12-17-75; Ord. No. 715, § 1, 5-11-88; Ord. No. 1067, § 1, 1-12-00; Ord. No. 1232, § 1, 1-26-11) 
Sec. 21-61. - Violation of solid waste disposal provisions. 
    Any person, business or corporation in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall have committed a municipal infraction and shall be subject to civil penalty as described in section 1-8.1 of the Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 787, § 10, 8-24-90) 
Chapter 22 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Moving of buildings, § 6-184 et seq.; peddlers, Ch. 16; subdivisions, Ch. 23; street rates and charges, § 25-12; franchises, App. A. 
State Law reference- Municipal home rule powers, I.C.A. § 364.1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Streets generally. 
    The streets of the city shall be assigned by ordinance. 
(Code 1969, § 10.24.010) 
Sec. 22-2. - Use of newly laid street or sidewalk. 
    No person shall walk or drive a vehicle upon any newly laid pavement or sidewalk which has not been opened to traffic. In addition, such a person shall be liable for any damage done to the paving or sidewalk. 
(Code 1969, § 7.40.020) 
Sec. 22-3. - Obstructions. 
    Except as otherwise provided, it shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct any street or sidewalk without the permission of the council. Any person obstructing streets or sidewalks with the permission of the council shall take such measures to guard the obstruction as the council deems necessary. 
(Code 1969, §§ 7.40.080, 7.40.140, 7.40.150) 
Sec. 22-4. - Blocking railroad crossings. 
    No person shall cause any locomotive, engine, car or railroad car to stop at or remain upon, or in any manner obstruct any railroad crossing for more than ten (10) consecutive minutes. 
(Code 1969, § 7.40.050; Ord. No. 481, § 2, 7-20-77) 
Sec. 22-5. - Open areaways and cellar doors. 
    No person shall leave open any cellar door, grating, areaway or other covering for a cellar, stairway, coal hole or other similar excavation in any sidewalk, alley or street without properly and securely guarding it. 
(Code 1969, § 7.08.100) 
Sec. 22-6. - Removal of barriers. 
    No person shall remove or interfere with any barrier protecting any street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1969, § 7.40.020) 
Sec. 22-7. - Injuring, defacing, etc., street signs. 
    No person shall injure, deface, break, take down or remove, or in any manner interfere with any street sign placed by authority of the council. 
(Code 1969, § 7.40.040) 
Sec. 22-8. - Planting, placing or removing vegetation, fences or other materials. 
(a)  It shall be a municipal infraction for any person to plant or remove trees, shrubs, plants or vines, or place or remove a fence, in any street or upon any city parking place or between the property line and the curbline of any street, without the permission of the council. 
(b)  It shall be a municipal infraction for any person to place or remove any other materials not described in subsection (a), including but not limited to gravel or cement, on any street or upon any city parking place or between the property line and the curbline of any street, without the permission of the council. 
(Code 1969, § 10.20.020; Ord. No. 801, § 1, 6-12-91) 
Cross reference- Tree ordinance, Ch. 23.7. 
Sec. 22-9. - Painting signs on sidewalks. 
    No person shall paint a sign or any advertising matter on any sidewalk. 
(Code 1969, § 7.40.180) 
Sec. 22-10. - Drains on sidewalks. 
    No person shall permit any spout, trough, gutter or balcony extending from any building owned or leased to discharge or conduct water on the surface of any sidewalk. 
(Code 1969, § 7.40.230) 
Sec. 22-11. - Datum plane established. 
    All grades are established and reckoned in feet and decimals of feet above an imaginary horizontal plane known as the datum plane. The datum plane is sea level which is seven hundred thirty three and fifty-two one hundredths (733.52) feet below the top of an iron monument known as the city bench mark, erected in the northeast corner of the public park in the public square. The elevations established herein are the grades at the point named, and the grade points shall be connected by straight lines, unless vertical curves can be used to better advantage. 
(Code 1969, § 10.12.010) 
Sec. 22-12. - Damaging, defacing benchmarks, monuments, etc. 
    No person shall remove, break, injure, deface, destroy or interfere with in any manner any grade stake, stone or other marker or monument within the city, set by the city engineering service or federal or state authorities to designate grade, corners, lines or benchmarks. 
(Code 1969, § 7.40.170; Ord. No. 1069, § 1, 1-12-2000) 
Sec. 22-13. - Certain activities prohibited in streets, sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall engage in any sport, activity or exercise likely to hinder the passage of motor vehicles on the roadway of any street or alley in the city. 
(b)  No person shall ride roller skates, skateboards, sleds, or ride in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle, pushcart or similar device upon the roadway of any street or alley in the city except while crossing a roadway on a crosswalk; and when so crossing, such person shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. 
(c)  No person shall ride roller skates, skateboards or bicycles upon the sidewalk or driveway, located on real estate owned by the city, with the exception of designated recreational trails. The city may grant exceptions for participation in programs approved by the city. 
(d)  No person shall ride roller skates, skateboards, bicycles, sleds, or ride in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle, pushcart or similar device upon the sidewalks of the central business district. For the purposes of this section, the perimeters of the central business district shall include the area in the boundary from the east side of Jackson Street to the west side of Adams Street; and the south side of Madison Street to the north side of Clay Street. 
(e)  No person shall rake, blow or otherwise cause leaves, debris or other vegetation to be deposited on a public sidewalk, public right-of-way or city park. 
(f)  Any person in violation of any provision under this section shall have committed a simple misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 768, § 1, 3-14-90; Ord. No. 799, § 1, 5-22-91; Ord. No. 836, § 1, 11-11-92; Ord. No. 1214, § 1, 1-13-2010; Ord. No. 1231, § 1, 1-26-11) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 12; bicycles and skateboards, § 12-101 et seq.; community services unit officer, § 18-9. 
Sec. 22-14. - Maintenance of right-of-way. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the abutting property owner to maintain all property outside the lot and property lines to the center of unimproved right-of-way property, which includes but is not limited to the cutting of grass, destruction of weeds or other growth which constitutes a health, safety or fire hazard, except that the property owner shall not be required to remove diseased trees or dead wood on the publicly owned property or right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 1169, § 1, 5-31-2006) 
Secs. 22-15-22-23. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION, REPAIR, MAINTENANCE, ETC. 

Sec. 22-24. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to clarify the responsibilities of the city and the owners of abutting property for the maintenance, repair, replacement, or reconstruction of sidewalks. 
Sec. 22-25. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms have these meanings: 
    Defective sidewalk: Any public sidewalk exhibiting one or more of the following characteristics: 
(1)  Vertical separations equal to three-fourths (3/4) inch or more; 
(2)  Horizontal separations equal to three-fourths (3/4) inch or more; 
(3)  Holes or depressions equal to three-fourths (3/4) inch or more and at least four inches in diameter. 
(4)  Spalling over fifty (50) percent of the surface of a single square of the sidewalk with one (1) or more depressions equal to one-half (1/2) inch or more; 
(5)  Spalling over less than fifty (50) percent of a single square of the sidewalk with one (1) or more depressions equal to three fourths (3/4) inch or more; 
(6)  A single square of sidewalk cracked in such a manner that no part thereof has a piece greater than one (1) square foot; 
(7)  A sidewalk with any part thereof missing to the full depth; 
(8)  A change from design or construction grade equal to or greater than three-fourths (3/4) inch per foot. 
    Owner: The person owning the fee title or the contract purchaser for purposes of notification required herein. For all other purposes, "owner" shall include the lessee, if any. 
    Sidewalk improvements: The reconstruction, repair, replacement, or removal of a public sidewalk or the excavating, filling, or depositing of material in the public right-of-way in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 5-14-97) 
Sec. 22-26. - Specifications for construction of sidewalks. 
    Sidewalks constructed under the provisions of this Chapter shall meet the following specifications: 
(1)  The director of public works shall be notified at least forty eight (48) hours in advance of the construction or reconstruction of a sidewalk, so that the city can establish the location and grade. 
(2)  Portland cement concrete of a type approved by the director of public works shall be the only concrete used in the construction or reconstruction of sidewalks. 
(3)  Sidewalks shall be on one-course construction. 
(4)  The concrete may be placed directly on compacted and well-drained soil. Where soil is not well-drained, a two-inch sub-base of compact, clean, course gravel or sand shall be laid. The adequacy of the soil drainage shall be determined by the director of public works. 
(5)  The sidewalk bed shall be graded to the established grade. 
(6)  Residential sidewalks shall be at least four (4) feet wide and four (4) inches thick, except sidewalks for crossing driveways shall be at least six (6) inches thick and each section shall be no more than four (4) feet in length. Business district sidewalks shall be at least five (5) feet wide and four (4) inches thick, except sidewalks crossing driveways shall be six (6) inches thick and no more than five (5) feet in length. 
(7)  All sidewalks, where possible, shall be four (4) to six (6) inches above the top of the curb. 
(8)  All sidewalks, unless otherwise approved by the director of public works, shall slope one-fourth (1/4) inch per foot toward the curb. 
(9)  All sidewalks shall have a "broom" finish. 
(10)  A three-fourths (3/4) inch piece of bituminous expansion joint material shall be placed between an existing or new curb and all sidewalks poured against such curb and transversely across sidewalks at no greater spacing than fifty (50) feet or the property line, whichever is applicable. Expansion joints shall be placed a minimum of one-eighth ( 1/8 ) inch below the top of the sidewalk. 
(11)  Forms for sidewalks may be standard two (2) inch by four (4) inch wood, but the party installing the sidewalk shall be required to excavate below the bottom edge of the form to produce a minimum of four (4) inch thickness. 
(12)  Sidewalks that are repaired shall be of the same width as the original sidewalk or driveway, but shall meet all of the other above specifications. Sidewalks or driveways replaced or constructed shall meet all of the existing specifications of the section 22-26, including a minimum width of four (4) feet. The word "replaced" as it is used in this paragraph shall mean the reconstruction or repair of sixty (60) percent or more of a sidewalk on any side of a property. 
(13)  Whenever the proposed sidewalk or reconstruction is in an area of unusual topography, size or shape, or is surrounded by such unusual conditions that the strict application of these specifications would result in substantial hardship or injustices, the director of public works may vary or modify such specifications so that the sidewalk may be constructed or reconstructed in a reasonable manner, provided in all instances that the public welfare and interest of the city and surrounding area is protected. 
(14)  For new subdivisions, the subdivider shall provide for the installation of sidewalks as described in the Mt. Pleasant Municipal Code section 23-58. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 5-14-97) 
Sec. 22-27. - Permits for construction or removal. 
    No person shall make any sidewalk improvements unless such person shall obtain a sidewalk permit from the director of public works. The permit shall state that the person will comply with the ordinances of the city and with the specifications for sidewalks adopted by the city. All such permits shall be issued without charge and a copy thereof, with the application, shall be filed and preserved in the office of the director of public works. The permit shall state when the work is to be commenced and when the work is to be completed. The time of completion for the sidewalk improvements may be extended by the director of public works. All permits for sidewalk improvements not ordered by resolution of the city council shall be issued in compliance with this chapter. The director of public works may withhold the issuance of any permit for any sidewalk improvements for a sufficient period to determine the necessity for the proposed improvements or when weather conditions will adversely affect the sidewalk improvements. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 5-14-97) 
Sec. 22-28. - Failure to obtain permit; remedies. 
    Whenever any sidewalk improvements are made that do not conform to the provisions of this chapter and with the specifications, or when any sidewalk improvements are made without a permit, the director of public works shall serve notice to obtain a permit upon the property owner and upon the contractor doing the work. If the sidewalk is in the course of construction, the notice, shall order the work to stop until a permit is obtained and the work is corrected to comply with the specifications. If the sidewalk work has been completed, the owner shall obtain a permit immediately and perform any needed corrections within five (5) days from receipt of the permit. If the owner fails to comply with this notice, the director of public works shall have the work completed and the costs assessed to the property owner as provided in sections 22-37, 22-38 and 22-39. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 5-14-97) 
Sec. 22-29. - Inspection and approval. 
    Upon final completion, the director of public works shall inspect the work. Corrections may be ordered if the work does not meet specifications. When the work does meet all requirements of this chapter, the specifications, and the permit, the director of public works shall indicate this on both copies of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 5-14-97) 
Sec. 22-30. - Barricades and warning lights. 
    Proper warning lights and barricades shall be placed to protect persons from materials, equipment, and dangerous conditions. Placement and maintenance of adequate warning is the responsibility of the constructor, the owner, and lessee of the property. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 5-14-97) 
Sec. 22-31. - Notification of utilities. 
    The party installing the sidewalk shall notify the director of public works at least forty-eight (48) hours in advance if any utility fixtures need adjustment due to sidewalk construction. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 5-14-97) 
Sec. 22-32. - Interference with sidewalk improvements. 
    No person shall knowingly or willfully drive any vehicle upon any portion of any sidewalk or approach thereto while it is in the process of being improved, or upon any portion of any completed sidewalk or approach thereto, or shall remove or destroy any part or all of any sidewalk or approach thereto, or shall remove, destroy, mar, or deface any sidewalk at any time or destroy, mar, remove or deface any notice or warning device provided by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 5-14-97) 
Sec. 22-33. - Repairing defective sidewalks. 
    It shall be the duty of the abutting property owner at any time, or upon receipt of thirty days notice from the city, to repair, replace or reconstruct all broken or defective sidewalks in the street right-of-way abutting his or her property. If, after the expiration of the thirty days as provided in the notice, the required work has not been done or is not in the process of completion, the director of public works shall proceed to repair, replace or reconstruct the sidewalk. Upon completion of the work, the director of public works shall submit to the city council an itemized and verified statement of expenditures for material and labor, and the legal description of the property abutting the sidewalk on which the work has been performed. These costs shall be assessed to the property as taxes. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 5-14-97) 
Sec. 22-34. - Ordering sidewalk improvements. 
    The director of public works may order the reconstruction, repair, or replacement of permanent sidewalks upon any street or court. Notice of this order shall be sent to the owner by certified mail. The notice shall include the fact that the owner may request a hearing by the city council within fifteen (15) days of receipt of the notice. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 5-14-97) 
Sec. 22-35. - Notice of inability to repair or barricade. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner of the property abutting the sidewalk, or of the contractor or agent of the owner, to notify the city immediately in the event the owner is unable to make necessary sidewalk improvements or to install or erect warning barricades as required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 5-14-97) 
Sec. 22-36. - Cleaning snow, ice and accumulations. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner to keep sidewalks abutting the property clear of the natural accumulations of snow or ice. If the owner fails to do so within a reasonable time, the director of public works may have the natural accumulations of snow or ice removed without notice to the property owner. The director of public works shall give the city council an itemized and verified statement of the costs and a legal description of the property. The costs shall be assessed against the property as taxes. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 5-14-97) 
Sec. 22-37. - Notice of assessment for repair or cleaning costs. 
    When the director of public works submits a bill for sidewalk improvements or for removal of accumulations as provided in sections 22-33 and 22-36 of this chapter, the city clerk shall send a notice of such facts to the owner of the abutting property. The notice may be given either by personal service or by certified mail to the last known address of the owner. The notice shall contain a statement of the work performed, the cost of the work that is being assessed, a description of the property affected, and the fact that the person may pay the amount assessed by a certain date without interest or penalty. The notice also shall indicate that the person may object to such assessment and give the place and time at which council will hear such objections. The time set for hearing shall be at least fifteen (15) days after the service or mailing of the notice. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 5-14-97) 
Sec. 22-38. - Hearing and assessment. 
    At the time and place designated in the notice, the council shall consider all objections to the assessment, correct all errors or omissions, and adopt a corrected list as the amounts to be assessed against the property. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 5-14-97) 
Sec. 22-39. - Billing and certifying to county. 
    Thirty (30) days after the council's decision, the city clerk shall certify any unpaid amounts to the county auditor. The unpaid assessments shall constitute a lien against the property and shall be collected by the county treasurer in the same manner as other taxes. Any assessment that exceeds one hundred twenty dollars ($120.00) may be paid in installments as set by council, not exceeding ten, in the same manner and at the same interest rates as for special assessments under Chapter 384 of the Iowa Code. No interest shall be charged for assessments, or parts thereof, paid within thirty (30) days of the time the council determined the final amounts. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 5-14-97) 
Sec. 22-40. - Liability of abutting owners. 
    In the event the owners of property abutting any public sidewalk fails or refuses to perform any act required of them by this chapter and in the event an action is brought against the city for personal injuries alleged to have been caused by a defect in or the condition of the sidewalk, the city may notify in writing the abutting owners that it claims the injury was caused by their negligence and/or their failure to repair the defect or eliminate the condition complained of. The notice shall state the pendency of the action, the name of the plaintiff, the name and location of the court where the action is pending, a brief statement of the alleged facts from which the cause arose, that the city believes that the person notified is liable to it for any judgement rendered against the city, and asking the person to appear and defend. 
    A judgement obtained in the suit is conclusive in any action by the city against any person so notified, as to the existence of the defect or other cause of the injury or damage, as to the liability of the city to the plaintiff in the first-named action, and as to the amount of the damage or injury. The city may maintain an action against the person notified to recover the amount of the judgement together with all the expenses incurred by the city in the suit. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 5-14-97) 
Sec. 22-41. - Penalty. 
    Anyone violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a simple misdemeanor and upon conviction, be subject to imprisonment not exceeding thirty days or a fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 5-14-97) 
ARTICLE III. - HOUSE ADDRESSING 

Sec. 22-42. - Addressing system for buildings, structures and approved plats, which were in existence prior to adoption of this article. 
    Main Street and Monroe Street shall constitute the base lines from which the numbering of buildings from either side thereof shall commence, and even numbers shall be on the east and south sides of the street, and odd numbers shall be on the north and west sides of the street. The numbers shall alternate from side to side of the street, and shall run one hundred (100) to each block or the distance between two (2) street intersections on the same street. Where a street is being numbered and where the streets intersecting on the opposite sides of the street do not intersect at the same point, then the numbers shall continue to run on each side until an intersecting street is reached. All streets running north and south shall be divided by Monroe Street into "north" and "south" streets, and all streets running east and west shall be divided by Main Street into "east" and "west" street. 
(Ord. No. 1004, § 2, 1-28-98) 
Sec. 22-43. - Addressing system for new buildings, structures or plats, which are constructed or approved after the adoption of this article. 
    All new buildings, structures or plats, which are constructed or approved after the adoption of this article, shall be addressed according to the modified grid system adopted by the city council, except where a new building or structure has been constructed in an established area that is not subject to the modified grid system. 
(Ord. No. 1004, § 2, 1-28-98) 
Sec. 22-44. - Directional prefix. 
    All street signage shall indicate the directional prefix assigned to the block as described in section 22-42 and Sec. 22-43, and the property owner shall be required to use directional prefixes when referencing the address of the property. 
(Ord. No. 1004, § 2, 1-28-98) 
Sec. 22-45. - Multiple unit structure. 
    A single building or structure with more than two (2) residences or businesses, shall share the same address, but each residence or business shall receive a number designation specific to its location in the building or structure. 
    The lowest level shall always commence with 100, and move sequentially, as follows: 
Below ground level-100, 101, 102 etc. 
Ground level (if lowest level)-100, 101, 102 
Above ground level-200, 201, 202 
EXAMPLE: John Doe 202 N. Liberty, Apt. 101. 
(Ord. No. 1004, § 2, 1-28-98) 
Sec. 22-46. - Complex developments. 
    Developments which have two or more separate buildings which are in close proximity to one another shall receive a single street address for the complex; a building identification number; and an individual number for each apartment or unit, such individual number based upon its location in the complex. 
    The apartments or units in the lowest level of the complex shall always commence with 100, and move sequentially, as follows: 
Below ground level-100, 101, 102 
Ground level (if the lowest level)-100, 101, 102 
Above ground level-200, 201, 202 
EXAMPLE: John Doe 202 N. Liberty Bldg. #2 Apt. 100. 
(Ord. No. 1004, § 2, 1-28-98) 
Sec. 22-47. - Adjoining units. 
    A building or structure which is immediately adjacent to another building or structure, and which has it's own separate entrance, shall have a separate number. 
(Ord. No. 1004, § 2, 1-28-98) 
Sec. 22-48. - Street frontage. 
    A building or structure shall be addressed according to the street on which the front of the building or structure faces. 
(Ord. No. 1004, § 2, 1-28-98) 
Sec. 22-49. - Street curves. 
    For streets that have a curved configuration, the numbering of the building or structure shall be according to the grid of the longest portion unless the shorter portion is longer than five hundred (500) feet. 
(Ord. No. 1004, § 2, 1-28-98) 
Sec. 22-50. - Numbering within the city limits. 
    All structures or buildings located within the city limits shall conform to the city addressing requirements, including structures or buildings located adjacent to a public highway. 
(Ord. No. 1004, § 2, 1-28-98) 
Sec. 22-51. - Street names. 
(a)  Similar names. No more than two (2) streets shall have the same principal names. This provision shall not apply to streets with similar names that were in existence prior to the adoption of this article, unless a majority of the property owners residing on a street request a name change. 
(b)  Restrictions. No public street shall be referred to or designated as a "lane". A "lane" shall be reserved for private roads. 
(c)  All others names shall conform to the existing policy of the city council and shall require the approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1004, § 2, 1-28-98) 
Sec. 22-52. - Placement and size of numbers. 
    The numbers required herein shall be placed in a conspicuous location in close proximity to the primary entrance of the main building, and the figures for each number shall be no less than four (4) inches in height. Each figure shall be plain and legible, and of a contrasting color to the background. The numbers shall be maintained in such condition at all times. 
(Ord. No. 1004, § 2, 1-28-98) 
Sec. 22-53. - House numbering by city. 
    If a property owner fails to number a building or structure in accordance with the provisions of this article, then the city may number said building or structure, after notice of the violation has been given to the property owner. For the purpose of giving notice, the property owner shall be that person named in the records at the county auditor's office. Such notice shall be mailed by certified mail. The city's costs may be certified to the county auditor and assessed against the property for collection in the same manner as a property tax. 
(Ord. No. 1004, § 2, 1-28-98) 
State Law reference- House numbering by city, I.C.A. § 364.12(3)(h). 
Sec. 22-54. - Violations. 
    A violation of this article, shall be considered a municipal infraction, with penalties as described in Sec. 1-8.1 of the municipal code. 
(Ord. No. 1004, § 2, 1-28-98) 
State Law reference- Power of city to require numbering of buildings, I.C.A. § 364.12(3)(d). 
Secs. 22-55-22-58. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARADES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Parade permit fees, § 25-22. 

Sec. 22-59. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article the following terms shall mean as indicated below: 
    Parade: Any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant, or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, park or other public place in this city. 
    Parade permit: A permit as required by this article. 
Sec. 22-60. - Permit required. 
    No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade, unless a parade permit shall have been obtained from the police chief. 
(Code 1969, §§ 4.20.010, 7.08.180) 
Sec. 22-61. - Permit application. 
(a)  A person seeking issuance of a parade permit shall file an application with the police chief on forms provided by such officer not less than five (5) days nor more than ten (10) days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade. 
(b)  The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade; 
(2)  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization. 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairman and who will be responsible for its conduct; 
(4)  The date when the parade is to be conducted; 
(5)  The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point; 
(6)  The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute such parade; the type of animals, and description of the vehicles; 
(7)  The hours when such parade will start and terminate; 
(8)  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed; 
(9)  The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade; 
(10)  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly area or areas; 
(11)  The interval of space to be maintained between units of such parade; 
(12)  If the parade is designed to be held by, and on behalf of or for, any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the chief of police a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf. 
(13)  Any additional information which the police chief shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should issue. 
(c)  The police chief, where good cause is shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider any application hereunder which is filed less than five (5) days before the date such parade is proposed to be conducted. 
Sec. 22-62. - Permit fee. 
    There shall be paid at the time of filing the application for a parade permit a fee in the amount established in section 25-22. 
(Ord. No. 854, § 1, 11-11-92) 
Sec. 22-63. - Standards for permit issuance. 
    The police chief shall issue a permit as provided for hereunder when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route; 
(2)  The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of this town to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to this city; 
(3)  The conduct of such parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of this town other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto; 
(4)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas; 
(5)  The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of fire-fighting equipment en route to a fire; 
(6)  The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance; 
(7)  The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route; 
(8)  The parade is not be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, cause, goods or event and is not designed to be held purely for private profit. 
No such permit, however, shall be granted unless a bond in an amount as has been fixed by the council has first been filed with the city as security for the payment of any damages or injury which may occur as the result of the parade. 
Sec. 22-64. - Notice of permit denial. 
    If the police chief disapproves the application, he shall mail to the applicant within two (2) days after the date upon which the application was filed, a notice of his action. 
Sec. 22-65. - Alternative permit. 
    The police chief, in denying an application for a parade permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time, or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within two (2) days after notice of the action of the chief, file a written notice of acceptance with the chief. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of, and shall have the effect of a parade permit under, this article. 
Sec. 22-66. - Contents of permit. 
    Each parade permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  Starting time; 
(2)  Minimum speed; 
(3)  Maximum speed; 
(4)  Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade; 
(5)  The portions of the street to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade; 
(6)  The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof; 
(7)  Such other information as the police chief shall find necessary to the enforcement of this article. 
Sec. 22-67. - Revocation of permit. 
    The police chief shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit issued hereunder, after a hearing conducted in accordance with the procedures set forth in the Mt. Pleasant Administrative Code. 
(Ord. No. 957, § 1, 1-10-96) 
Sec. 22-68. - Posession of permit. 
    The parade chairman or other person heading or leading such activity shall carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade. 
Sec. 22-69. - Compliance with permit, laws, etc., required. 
    A permittee hereunder shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
Sec. 22-70. - Appeals from decision of police chief. 
    A person aggrieved by a decision of the police chief made pursuant to the provisions of this article may, within five (5) days of receipt of such decision, appeal it to the city council. Such appeal hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures set forth in the Mt. Pleasant Administrative Code (chapter 2, article VIII). 
(Ord. No. 957, § 1, 1-10-96) 
Sec. 22-71. - Exceptions. 
    This article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Funeral processions; 
(2)  Students going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities, providing such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities; 
(3)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
Secs. 22-72-22-82. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - VISUAL OBSTRUCTIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Tree ordinance, Ch. 23.7. 

Sec. 22-83. - Definitions. 
    When used in this article the following terms shall mean as follows: 
    Commercial exit: Any vehicular exit from any automobile service station, shopping center, store, medical or professional center, or other similar public place. 
    Critical visibility zone: The area within which the presence of obstructions to vision such as trees, shrubbery and signs could prevent the driver of a motor vehicle which is stopped behind the stop line of any street, highway, alley or commercial exit at its intersection with any other street or highway from seeing any other vehicle which is approaching on the intersection street or highway and is within two hundred (200) feet of the intersection. 
    Shrubbery: Any bush, hedge, flowering or ornamental plant, weed growth, low-growing evergreen or other form of vegetation. 
    Sign: Any temporary or permanent structure, banner, pennant or string of pennants, used for advertising or decorative purposes. 
    Stop line: The actual obedience line if there be one. If there is none, one shall be assumed to exist four (4) feet before the nearest edge of the intersection street or highway. 
    Tree: A large, woody, perennial plant having a clearly recognizable trunk. 
Sec. 22-84. - Signs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place or cause to be placed in any critical visibility zone any sign of which any part thereof is higher than thirty-six (36) inches above grade level, unless the lowest portion of the sign exclusive of a supporting structure no wider than twelve (12) inches in its greatest dimension is at least eight (8) feet above grade level. 
Sec. 22-85. - Trees or shrubbery. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person owning or controlling property to cause or permit any tree, shrubbery, plant or vine within any critical visibility zone to grow to a height greater than thirty-six (36) inches above ground. 
(Code 1969, § 10.20.010) 
Sec. 22-86. - Obstruction to traffic signs or signals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person owning or controlling property to permit the foliage of any tree or shrubbery growing on said property to obscure any driver's view of any lawfully placed stop sign or traffic-control signal during any part of the last two hundred (200) feet of his approach to said sign or traffic-control device. 
Sec. 22-87. - When person subject to penalty. 
    Any person violating any section of this article shall, upon receipt of official notification from the director of public works that a violation has taken place, correct the cause of the violation within fourteen (14) days from the date of notification, or be subject to the penalties provided by this Code. 
Secs. 22-88-22-98. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - DRIVEWAY CONSTRUCTION OR REPAIR 

Sec. 22-99. - Definition. 
    As used in this article the term "driveway" means an area which primarily serves or intends to serve as a vehicular and pedestrian access to abutting property of a designated street or alley, and shall also include the "driveway apron", as described in this article. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 1, 6-21-78; Ord. No. 1001, § 1, 12-23-97) 
Sec. 22-99.1. - Driveway apron. 
(a)  A driveway apron shall be that portion of a driveway which abuts a city street or alley, and extends back to a line which is even with the far side of the sidewalk, or alternatively if there is no sidewalk on the city right-of-way, then to the adjoining property line. 
(b)  A driveway apron which abuts a paved or asphalt city street or alley, shall be constructed out of concrete or asphalt. 
(Ord. No. 1001, § 1, 12-23-97) 
Sec. 22-100. - Permit generally. 
(a)  No person shall construct, build, establish or maintain any driveway over, across or upon any portion of the public sidewalk or public parkway without first having obtained a written permit to do so from the director of public works or his designated representative. A permit shall be obtained from the city council where the driveway is for other than residence or dwelling house use, or where it is necessary to elevate or depress the established grade of public sidewalks or parkways. No such permit shall be issued for construction or establishment of any such driveway except in accordance with the provisions herein contained. 
(b)  Application for permit must be made in writing upon forms furnished by the city. Said application shall contain the name and address of the person, firm or corporation making the application, the name of the contractor or person who is to construct said driveway and the proposed location and dimensions of such driveway. Complete plans and specifications shall be submitted to the department of streets and public improvements at least seventy-two (72) hours before permit shall issue. 
(c)  The applicant shall prior to submitting a request for a permit contact if necessary Call One as to the proposed work. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 2, 6-21-78; Ord. No. 1069, § 1, 1-12-00) 
Sec. 22-101. - Standards for issuance of permit. 
    The director of public works shall issue a permit hereunder when he finds: 
(a)  That the plans for the proposed construction have been approved by the director of public works. 
(b)  That the work shall be done according to the standard specifications of the city for public work of like character. 
(c)  That the operation will not unreasonably interfere with vehicular and pedestrian traffic, the demand and necessity for parking spaces, and the means of egress to and from the property affected and adjacent properties. 
(d)  That the health, welfare and safety of the public will not be unreasonably impaired. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 9, 6-21-78) 
Sec. 22-102. - Bonds. 
    The following bonds shall accompany an application for a permit hereunder: 
(a)  In cases where the estimated cost of the project shall exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) the director of public works shall have the authority to require a maintenance and construction bond to be filed with the application for a permit hereunder in an amount to one-half of the estimated cost of the project and conditioned that such work shall be done in accordance with the city's standard specifications. In any case where a permittee hereunder shall be in default or shall fail to comply with the requirements of this article the director of public works shall order the completion of the work by the city and shall recover the cost from permittee as required by law. 
(b)  The director of public works shall require an applicant hereunder to file evidence of contractual liability insurance or a bond to protect and save harmless the city from all claims for damages or injury to other persons by reason of such alteration work. Such insurance or bond shall be in the minimum amounts for bodily injury of one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00) per person, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) each occurrence, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) aggregate and for property damage the minimum amount shall be twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for each occurrence and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) aggregate. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 8, 6-21-78) 
Sec. 22-103. - Supervision and inspection. 
    All permitted work shall be done under the jurisdiction of the director of public works and in accordance with all ordinances of the city; and shall be inspected upon completion by members of such departments. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 3, 6-21-78; Ord. No. 1069, § 1, 1-12-00) 
Sec. 22-104. - Construction procedures. 
(a)  When a driveway of concrete or asphalt is constructed or replaced that abuts with a paved or asphalt city street or alley, and where provisions have not been made for a "driveway return", the contractor or property owner shall where the removal of an existing curb is necessary, be required to make a "saw cut" of the area to be removed. The cut out area will be squared on each side of the proposed driveway at a point to include the full width of the driveway. The saw cut shall be a minimum of twelve (12) inches back from the gutter line of the street or alley and further back when determined by the director of public works or superintendent of streets, in order to prevent the driveway from intersecting with street or alley in the natural gutter line. The saw cut operations shall be performed in such a manner so as to avoid or minimize any unnecessary breaks or premature spalling. 
(b)  Excavation and compaction of subsurface shall be adequately performed in order to prevent washout under driveway, unnecessary settling and/or cracking of concrete and shall meet the requirements of the city, prior to placing concrete or asphalt materials in driveway. Replacement material shall be the same thickness and reinforced as well as appears in existing street or alley. As a minimum "expansion joint" shall be placed at a point where driveway and street or alley intersect. The driveway return shall be placed separately in the form of a half-curb so as to join existing curb on either side of driveway. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 4, 6-21-78) 
Sec. 22-105. - Other specifications and requirements. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of the contractor or property owner to make provisions for and accomplish permitted work at their expense. Such work shall include removal of material from cut out area and clean up of area in general. 
(b)  The city shall not be responsible for replacement or repair of faulty driveway or areas, when determined that "inadequate construction standards" were the cause of such defects or in such cases where it is determined that this article has not been complied with. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the person performing driveway construction to properly and adequately furnish and place barricades for safety reasons at construction site. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 5, 6-21-78) 
Sec. 22-106. - Grade of surface. 
    No driveway shall be so constructed or graded as to leave a step, sharp depression or other obstruction on the sidewalk. The grade shall be as nearly as possible the same as that of the adjoining sidewalk. It shall be unlawful to have the surface finish of any driveway where the same crosses the sidewalk constructed of such material as to render it slippery or hazardous to pedestrians, or to have the grade of such portion vary from the grade of the sidewalk, or to be other than level. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 6, 6-21-78) 
Sec. 22-107. - Repair. 
    It shall be the duty of the person maintaining the driveway to keep the same in good repair where it crosses the sidewalk, and free from obstructions and openings. 
(Ord. No. 497, § 7, 6-21-78) 
Secs. 22-108-22-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 22-121. - Permit required; waiver of article. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to tunnel under or to make any excavation in any street, alley or other public place in the city without having obtained a permit as is herein required, or without complying with the provisions of this article or in violation of or variance from the terms of any such permit. In emergency situations the requirements of this ordinance may be waived. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 1, 6-21-78) 
Sec. 22-122. - Application for permit. 
    Applications for permits required herein shall be made to the director of public works or his designated representative, and shall describe the location of the intended excavation or tunnel, the size thereof, the purpose therefor, and the person doing the actual excavating work and the name of the person for whom or which the work is being done, and shall contain an agreement that the applicant will comply with all ordinances and laws relating to the work to be done. Applicant shall prior to submitting a request for a permit contact Call One as to the proposed work. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 2, 6-21-78; Ord. No. 1069, § 1, 1-12-00) 
Sec. 22-123. - Bonds. 
    The following bonds shall accompany an application for a permit hereunder: 
(a)  In cases where the estimated cost of the project shall exceed twenty-five hundred dollars ($2500.00), the director of public works shall have the authority to require a maintenance and construction bond to be filed with the application for a permit hereunder in an amount to one-half (1/2) of the estimated cost of the project and conditioned that such work shall be done in accordance with the city's standard specifications. In any case where a permittee hereunder shall be in default or shall fail to comply with the requirements of this article, the director of public works shall order the completion of the work by the city and shall recover the cost from permittee as required by law. 
(b)  The director of public works shall require an applicant hereunder to file evidence of contractual liability insurance or a bond to protect and save harmless the city from all claims for damages or injury to other persons by reason of such excavation. Such insurance or bond shall be in the minimum amounts for bodily injury of one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00) per person, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) each occurrence, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) aggregate, and for property damage, the minimum amount shall be twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for each occurrence and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) aggregate. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 3, 6-21-78) 
Sec. 22-124. - Supervision and inspection. 
    The director of public works shall from time to time inspect or cause to be inspected all excavations and tunnels being made in or under any public street, alley or other public place in the city to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this article. The director of public works shall have the authority to promulgate and cause to be enforced such rules and regulations as may be reasonably necessary to enforce and carry out the intent of this article. Notice shall be given to him at least eight (8) hours before the work of refilling any such tunnel or excavation commences. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 6, 6-21-78) 
Sec. 22-125. - Manner of excavating. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to make any such excavation or tunnel in any way contrary to or at variance with the terms of the permit therefor. Proper bracing shall be maintained to prevent the collapse of adjoining ground; and in excavations the excavation shall not have anywhere below the surface any portion which extends beyond the opening at the surface. 
(b)  No injury shall be done to any pipes, cables or conduits in the making of such excavations or tunnels; and notice shall be given to the persons maintaining any such pipes, cables or conduits or to the city department or officer charged with the care thereof, which are or may be endangered or affected by the making of any such excavation or tunnel before such pipes, cables or conduits shall be disturbed. 
(c)  No unnecessary damage or injury shall be done to any tree or shrub or the roots thereof. 
(d)  When an excavation is required in a paved, concrete-or asphalt-covered street or alley within the City of Mt. Pleasant for any reason, a saw cut is required around the excavated area prior to placement of concrete or asphalt material in the excavated area. The excavated area will be backfilled with gravel and properly compacted prior to placing the concrete or asphalt material in it. The thickness of the replacement material will be at least as thick as the existing street or alley or as otherwise specified. When the surface material is concrete, dowel bars will be used between the existing and new material. The spacing, placement and size will be as specified in the IDOT Manual of "Standard Specifications for Highway and Bridge Construction." 
(e)  When an excavation is required in a gravel street or alley within the city, such street or alley will be repaired to the extent that the condition of same is as good as before excavation was done. 
(f)  When excavation is required under a sidewalk and as a result, replacement or repair of sidewalk is necessary, it shall be the same thickness, width and elevation as the previous sidewalk unless otherwise specified. 
(g)  When excavation is required on city property and/or right of way, the area shall be restored in comparison to its original condition and seeded when appropriate or as otherwise specified. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 4, 6-21-78; Ord. No. 698, § 1, 11-10-87) 
Sec. 22-126. - Sidewalks. 
    If any sidewalk is blocked by any permitted work, a temporary sidewalk shall be constructed or provided which shall be safe for travel and convenient for users. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 5, 6-21-78) 
Sec. 22-127. - Tunneling required. 
    It shall be unlawful to make any excavation in any portion of a street or sidewalk in the city which is paved with a concrete or asphalt paving without a permit. Where necessary and where a proper permit has been secured, tunnels may be driven or excavated under any such pavement; provided that upon completion of the work involved, the tunnel shall be backfilled with compacted sand. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 7, 6-21-78; Ord. No. 1069, § 1, 1-12-00) 
Sec. 22-128. - Protective measures and routing traffic. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every person cutting or making an excavation in or upon any public place to place and maintain barriers and warning devices necessary for the safety of the general public. 
(b)  Barriers, warning signs, lights, etc., shall conform to the requirements of the city council. Warning lights shall be flares, torches, lanterns, electrical markers or flashers used to indicate a hazard to traffic from sunset of each day to sunrise of the next day. Torches shall be open wick or flame flares or bombs generally used in connection with roadway repairs or construction and operating on kerosene or similar fluid. 
(c)  Lanterns shall burn kerosene or a similar fluid and have clear red or ruby globes. Electrical markers or flashers shall emit light at sufficient intensity and frequency to be visible at a reasonable distance for safety. Reflectors or reflecting material may be used to supplement, but not replace, light sources. The city council may restrict the use of lanterns or open flame devices in fire hazard areas. 
(d)  The permittee shall take appropriate measures to assure that during the performance of the excavation work, traffic conditions as near normal as possible shall be maintained at all times so as to minimize inconvenience to the occupants of the adjoining property and to the general public. 
(e)  When traffic conditions permit, the director of public works may, by written approval, permit the closing of streets and alleys to all traffic for a period of time prescribed by him if, in his opinion, it is necessary. Such written approval may require that the permittee give notification to various public agencies and to the general public. In such cases, such written approval shall not be valid until such notice is given. 
(f)  Warning signs shall be placed far enough in advance of the construction operation to alert traffic within a public street and cones, or other approved devices shall be placed to channel traffic in accordance with the instructions of the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 8, 6-21-78) 
Sec. 22-129. - Clearance for vital structures. 
    The excavation work shall be performed and conducted so as not to interfere with access to fire hydrants, fire stations, fire escapes, water gates, underground vaults, valve housing structures, and all other vital equipment as designated by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 9, 6-21-78; Ord. No. 1069, § 1, 1-12-00) 
Sec. 22-130. - Protection of traffic. 
    A permittee hereunder shall maintain safe crossings for two (2) lanes of vehicle traffic at all street intersections where possible and safe crossings for pedestrians at intervals of not more than three hundred (300) feet. If any excavation is made across any public street, alley or sidewalk, adequate crossings shall be maintained for vehicles and for pedestrians. If the street is not wide enough to hold the excavated material without using part of the adjacent sidewalk, a passageway at least one-half (1/2) of the sidewalk width shall be maintained along such sidewalk line. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 10, 6-21-78) 
Sec. 22-131. - Relocation and protection of utilities. 
    A permit hereunder shall not interfere with any existing facility without the written consent of the director of public works and the owner of the facility. If it becomes necessary to relocate an existing facility, this shall be done by its owner. No facility owned by the city shall be moved to accommodate the permittee, unless the cost of such work is borne by the permittee. The cost of moving privately owned facilities shall be similarly borne by the permittee, unless it makes other arrangements with the person owning the facility. The permittee shall support and protect, by timbers or otherwise, all pipes, conduits, poles, wires or other apparatus which may be in any way affected by the excavation work, and do everything necessary to support, sustain and protect them under, over, along or across said work. The permittee shall secure approval of the method of support and protection from the owner of the facility. In case any of said pipes, conduits, poles, wires or apparatus should be damaged, and for this purpose pipe coating or other encasement or devices are to be considered as a part of a substructure, the permittee shall promptly notify the owner thereof. All damaged facilities shall be repaired by the agency or person owning them and the expense of such repairs shall be charged to the permittee. It is the intent of this paragraph that the permittee shall assume all liability for damage to the facilities and any resulting damage or injury to anyone because of such facility damage, and such assumption of liability is a contractual obligation of the permittee. The only exception will be such instances where damage is exclusively due to the negligence of the owning utility. The city shall not be made a party to action because of this section. The permittee shall inform itself as to the existence and location of all underground facilities and protect the same against damage. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 11, 6-21-78) 
Sec. 22-132. - Prompt completion of work. 
    After an excavation is commenced, a permittee shall prosecute with diligence and expedition all excavation work covered by the excavation permit and shall promptly complete such work and restore the street to its original condition, or as near as may be, so as not to obstruct the public place or travel thereon more than is reasonably necessary. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 12, 6-21-78) 
Secs. 22-133-22-139. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - STREET MAINTENANCE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 22-140-22-149. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DURING WINTER MONTHS 

Sec. 22-150. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this division is to establish this city's policy and level of service in respect to clearance of snow or ice and maintenance of its street and road system during the winter months, as provided in HF 2487, Section 10(2), Acts of the 63rd General Assembly, Second Session, and pursuant to the provisions of Section 309.67, Code of Iowa. This policy and level of service are to be implemented within the amount of money budgeted for this service, and as contained in this city's secondary road budget as submitted to and approved by the Iowa Department of Transportation and adopted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 647, § 1, 4-3-85) 
Sec. 22-151. - Level of service. 
(a)  Clearance of snow or ice and maintenance of the street and road system during the winter months is primarily for the benefit of the local residents of this city. Each storm has individual characteristics and must be dealt with accordingly. The portion of the roadway improved for travel will have upon it snow and ice in a compacted condition. These conditions may be continuous, or they may be more concentrated on hills, in valleys, curves, and/or intersections. The city's existing snow removal equipment will be utilized for this purpose. All clearance of snow and ice, sanding, salting, and other maintenance respecting winter conditions shall be accomplished within the amount of money budgeted for this service. The entire width of that portion of the road improved for travel may not be cleared of snow, ice, compacted snow and ice, or frost. Snow cleared from that part of the roadway improved for travel shall be placed on or in the adjacent shoulder, ditch, or right-of-way. Snow can be expected to accumulate adjacent to the traveled portion to the extent that a motorist's sight distance to both the left and right may be greatly reduced or impaired. The snow removed from intersections will be piled in its corners in piles of unequal height. The line of sight, sight distance, or visibility of motorists approaching these intersections may be greatly reduced or impaired. The city shall not be responsible for snow pushed or otherwise placed on the roadway or shoulder by others. 
(b)  Motorists shall drive their vehicles during these conditions with additional caution and watchfulness, especially in respect to the surface of the roadway and reduced or impaired visibility, and are advised to reduce their speed at least ten (10) miles per hour below that legally permitted or advised under normal conditions. In respect to roadways that have only one (1) lane open, further extreme watchfulness and caution should be exercised by the motorist, and their speed should not exceed ten (10) miles per hour. 
(c)  During these conditions, no additional warning or regulatory signs will be placed that warn of impaired sight distances, visibility at intersections, road blockages, one-lane conditions, or that the road surface is slick or slippery, or what the advised speed should be. 
(Ord. No. 647, § 2, 4-3-85) 
Sec. 22-152. - Sequence of service. 
(a)  Director of public works. In the implementation of snow and ice removal and other maintenance of the city's street and road system during the winter months, the director of public works or his designee shall select the actual sequence of roads to be cleared as provided for in this section of this division, and shall determine when drifting, wind velocity, and additional snow or snowstorms require that the snow removal equipment be removed from the roadway, or that additional clearance of paved routes be accomplished prior to the clearance of gravel and dirt roads. The director of public works or his designee's professional judgment shall prevail unless it is clearly erroneous. 
(b)  Paved routes. 
(1)  The initial effort will be to get all routes open to one-lane traffic as soon as possible. 
(2)  After one-lane travel is possible, subsequent snow removal will be carried on during normal working hours. 
(3)  The truck-mounted snow plows and spreaders will not normally be in operation between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. The trucks may be called off the road if snow and/or blowing snow reduces visibility to hazardous working conditions, in the professional judgement of the director of public works or his designee. 
(4)  When required, due to drifting snow, motor graders may be used to keep the paved roads open and the opening of gravel roads may be delayed. 
(5)  It is not the policy of the city to provide a "dry" pavement condition. 
(6)  After roads have been plowed as provided in this section, intersections, hills, and curves may have placed on them salt, sand or other abrasives. These intersections, hills and curves will not be resanded, resalted, or have other abrasives replaced on them between snowstorms. This sequence of service shall be performed only between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. each day, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays observed by city employees. 
(c)  Unpaved roads. 
(1)  The initial effort will be to get all routes opened to one-lane traffic as soon as possible after a storm has passed. 
(2)  After one-lane travel is possible, subsequent snow removal will be carried on during normal working hours. 
(3)  Motor graders and/or truck plows will not normally be in operation between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Gravel roads may not be plowed if the wind is causing continual drifting. 
(d)  Private drives and private parking lots. The city will not clear snow from private drives or private parking lots. Normal snow removal operations may result in snow being deposited in private drives or along private parking lots. Snow from sidewalks, private drives or private parking lots shall not be placed on or left remaining on sidewalks, roadways, or shoulders, with the exception that snow accumulating on sidewalks in the following areas may be deposited into the street: 
(1)  Monroe St. between Jackson St. and Adams St. 
(2)  Washington St. between Jackson St. and Adams St. 
(3)  Jefferson St. between Washington St. and Madison St. 
(4)  Main St. between Washington St. and Madison St. 
    There is no time limit after a snowstorm in which any of the above sequence of clearance on paved or unpaved roads shall take place 
(Ord. No. 647, § 3, 4-3-85; Ord. No. 1008, § 1, 2-25-98; Ord. No. 1069, § 1, 1-12-2000; Ord. No. 1078, § 1, 7-26-2000) 
Sec. 22-153. - Limitation of service. 
    The policy and level of service provided for in this division shall not include the performance of the following services: 
(1)  Sanding, salting, or placing of other abrasives upon the roadway that are slick, slippery, and dangerous due to the formation of frost. 
(2)  Sanding, salting, or placing other abrasives upon paved roadway due to freezing precipitation that occurs outside the city's usual working hours. 
(3)  Placing of additional warning or regulatory signs warning of impaired sight distances, visibility at intersections, road blockages, one-lane conditions, or that the road surface is slick or slippery, or what the advised speed should be. 
(Ord. No. 647, § 4, 4-3-85) 
Sec. 22-154. - Emergency conditions. 
(a)  The sequence of service may be suspended during "emergency" conditions. An "emergency" condition shall be considered as one where loss of life is probable, where a serious injury has occurred, or where extensive loss of property is imminent. The condition should be verified through the police department. The city shall respond to all "emergency" conditions either during or after a snowstorm. 
(b)  The provisions of this division shall be further suspended in the event the governor, by proclamation, implements the state disaster plan, or the mayor of the city, by proclamation, implements the city disaster plan. If such occurs, the city personnel and equipment shall be immediately subject to the direction of the governor or the mayor of the city. 
(Ord. No. 647, § 5, 4-3-85) 
Secs. 22-155, 22-156. - Reserved.
